original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Sīmavisodhanī
analyzed: sīma visodhanī
translated: The Purification of the Monastic Boundary🔽The giver of boons, the boon, the foremost,

original: Varadaṃ varadaṃ aggaṃ, diccaṃ diccaṃva vanajaṃ;
analyzed: vara dam vara dam aggam diccam diccam va vana jam
translated: The sun, the sun, like the forest-born,🔽The enlightener, the enlightener, the living being,

original: Bodhakaṃ bodhakaṃ pāṇaṃ, deva’devaṃ namāma’haṃ.
analyzed: bodhakam bodhakam pāṇam devadevam namām aham
translated: The god of gods, I pay homage.🔽The peaceful, the peaceful, always the wheel,

original: Santaṃ santaṃ sadā vaṭṭaṃ, pajaṃ’bhave sutaṃ;
analyzed: santam santam sadā vaṭṭam sutam
translated: The people, in existence, well-known,🔽The enlightened, the enlightened, the star,

original: Nibbudaṃ nibbudaṃ tāraṃ, dhammavaraṃ namāma’haṃ.
analyzed: nibbudam nibbudam tāram dhamma varam namām aham
translated: The excellent Dhamma, I pay homage.🔽The heard, the heard, in the abode,

original: Sutaṃ sutaṃ bhavane yaṃ, natanaṃ natanā’rahaṃ;
analyzed: sutam sutam bhavane yam natanam natanāraham
translated: The dance, the dance, the worthy one,🔽The humans and non-humans, always the group,

original: Narā’narā sadā’kaṃsu, saṅghavaraṃ namāma’haṃ.
analyzed: saṅgha varam namām aham
translated: The excellent Saṅgha, I pay homage.

original: Icceva’maccantanatassaneyyaṃ, natayyamāno ratanattayaṃ yaṃ;
analyzed: natayyamānaḥ ratanattayam yam
translated: Thus, having paid homage to the Triple Gem, which is worthy of homage,

original: Puññābhivaḍḍhiṃ mahagghaṃ alatthaṃ, tassānubhāvena hatantarāyo.🔽Vinaye sati ṭhite yaṃ, sāsanaṃ saṇṭhitaṃ bhave;
analyzed: puñña abhivaḍḍhim mahaggham alattham tassa anubhāvena hata antarāyaḥ  vinaye sati ṭhite yam sāsanam saṇṭhitam bhave
translated: By whose power obstacles are destroyed, I have attained great merit.🔽When there is truth in the Monastic Law, the Dispensation is established in the world.

original: Vinaye sati naṭṭhe yaṃ, vinaṭṭhaṃ sāsanaṃ bhave.
analyzed: vinaye sati naṭṭhe yam vinaṭṭham sāsanam bhave
translated: When there is no truth in the Monastic Law, the Dispensation is destroyed in the world.

original: Tasmā dittaṃ mame’dāni, jotayitvāna sāsane;
analyzed: tasmai dittam mama idāni sāsane
translated: Therefore, having illuminated the Dispensation, which has been seen by me,

original: Bhinditvā dveḷhakaṃ vādaṃ, ekībhāvaṃ karoma’haṃ.
analyzed: bhinditvā dveḷhakam vādam ekībhāvam karomaham
translated: Having split the two-fold dispute, I will bring about unity.

original: Attukkaṃsana-bhāvañca, paravambhanakampica;
analyzed: attukkaṃsana bhāvam ca paravambhana kampi ca
translated: And self-praise and disparaging others,

original: Tesu cittaṃ apesetvā, sāsanassa suvuḍḍhiyā.
analyzed: tesu cittam a pesetvā sāsanassa su vuḍḍhiyā
translated: Without setting the mind on these, for the good growth of the Dispensation.

original: Yadi me īdisaṃ cittaṃ, bhaveyyuṃ pāpasaṅkappā;
analyzed: yadi me īdisam cittam bhaveyyum pāpa saṅkappā
translated: If I had such a mind, there would be evil thoughts,

original: Paccissaṃ niraye bhayaṃ, hīna’jjhāsayakāraṇā.🔽Sāsanassa sulabhaṃ’va patthayanto satā’cāro;
analyzed: niraye bhayam  sāsanassa sulabham iva patthayanto sata ācāro
translated: I would be subject to the fear of hell, because of the low disposition.🔽Seeking the easy attainment of the Dispensation, with a mind that is mindful,

original: Saṃsandissamahaṃ dāni, ciraṃ saddhamma’suddhiyā.
analyzed: saṃsandissam aham dāni ciram saddhamma suddhiyā
translated: I will now compose, after a long time, for the purification of the True Dhamma.

original: Sudullabhaṃ labhitvāna, pabbajjaṃ jinasāsane;
analyzed: su dullabham labhitvāna pabbajjam jina sāsane
translated: Having obtained the difficult to obtain going forth in the Dispensation of the Victor,

original: Sambuddhassa varaṃ vādaṃ, katvā dveḷhaka’mekikaṃ.🔽Sīmavisodhaniṃ nāma, nānāganthasamāhaṭaṃ;
analyzed: sambuddhassa varam vādam katvā dveḷhaka mekikam  sīmavisodhanim nāma nānā gantha samāhaṭam
translated: Having made the excellent statement of the Sambuddha, in two parts and one part,🔽I will make (this work) called the ‘Sīma Visodhanī’, which is compiled from various texts,

original: Karissaṃ me nisāmentu, sādhavo kavipuṅgavā.
analyzed: karissam me sādhavaḥ kavi puṅgavā
translated: May the good, the best of poets, listen to me.

original: Pāḷiṃ aṭṭhakathañceva, mātikaṃ padabhājaniṃ;
analyzed: pāḷim aṭṭhakatham ca iva mātikam pada bhājanim
translated: The text, the commentary, the mātikā, and the padabhājaniya,

original: Ogāhetvāna taṃ sabbaṃ, punappunaṃ asesato.🔽Attanomatiganthesu, ṭīkāgaṇṭhipadesuca;
analyzed: ogāhetvāna tam sabbam punappunam asesataḥ  atta no mati ganthesu ṭīkā gaṇṭhi padesu ca
translated: Having understood all of that, again and again, without remainder,🔽In the Atthakathā texts, in the tīkā, and in the gaṇṭhi passages,

original: Vinicchayavimatīsu, mātikā’ṭṭhakathāsupi.
analyzed: vinicchaya vimatīsu mātikā aṭṭhakathāsu pi
translated: In the Vinicchaya and Vimati, in the mātikā and the commentaries,

original: Sabbaṃ asesakaṃ katvā, saṃsanditvāna ekato;
analyzed: sabbam asesakam katvā saṃsanditvānaḥ ekatas
translated: Having done everything without remainder, having composed it all together,

original: Pavattā vaṇṇanā esā, tosayantī vicakkhaṇeti.
analyzed: pavattā vaṇṇanā esā tosayantī vicakkhaṇā iti
translated: This is the commentary on the arising of the Thread.

original: Buddhuppādo hi dullabho, tato pabbajjā ca upasampadā ca, vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: buddhuppādaḥ hi dullabhaḥ tatas pabbajjā ca upasampadā ca vuttam ha etam
translated: The arising of a Buddha is hard to find, and so too is the going forth and the full admission. As it is said:

original: Buddho ca dullabho loke, saddhammasavanampi ca;
analyzed: buddho ca dullabhaḥ loke saddhamma savanam pi ca
translated: “A Buddha is hard to find in the world, and so too is the hearing of the True Idea,

original: Saṅgho ca dullabho loke, sappūrisā’tidullabhā.
analyzed: saṅghaḥ ca dullabhaḥ loke sappūri sāti dullabhā
translated: And a Community is hard to find in the world, and so too are those who are well-fulfilled.

original: Dullabhañca manussattaṃ, buddhuppādo ca dullabho;
analyzed: dullabham ca manussattam buddhuppādaḥ ca dullabhaḥ
translated: Human birth is hard to find, and so too is the arising of a Buddha,

original: Dullabhā khaṇasampatti, saddhammo paramadullabho’ti.
analyzed: dullabhā khaṇa sampatti saddhammo parama dullabhaḥ ti
translated: And the opportunity is hard to find, and so too is the True Idea supremely hard to find” .

original: 1. Upasampadākaṇḍo
analyzed: upasampadā kaṇḍo
translated: The Chapter on the Full Admission

original: Imasmiñhi ṭhāne ṭhatvā buddhaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttāya kathāya vuccamānāya sādhūnaṃ cittasampahaṃsanañceva,🔽imasseva pakaraṇassa anummattavacanabhāvo ca bhaveyya, anummattavacanatte ca siddhe
analyzed: imasmin hi ṭhāne ṭhatvā buddha guṇa paṭisaṃyuttāya kathāya vuccamānāya sādhūnam citta sampahaṃsanam ca iva  imassa iva pakaraṇassa anummattavacana bhāvaḥ ca bhaveyya anummattavacana tte ca siddhe
translated: For when this is the place to stand in, then when the talk is about the special qualities of the Enlightened One, it is the heart’s content of the good,🔽and it is the talk of one who is not mad,

original: sotabbaṃ maññissanti, tasmā buddhaguṇaṃ vaṇṇayissāma. Amhākaṃ kira bhagavā brahmadevabuddhamādiṃ
analyzed: sotabbam maññissanti tasmai buddha guṇam vaṇṇayissāma amhākam kira bhagavā brahma deva buddha mādim
translated: and when that is established, they will think it is worth hearing, and so we shall extol the special qualities of the Enlightened One. The Blessed One, it seems, was first of all a being in the Pure Abodes called Sumedha, who, beginning with the Enlightened One Dipankara,

original: katvā yāva porāṇasakyagotamā manopaṇidhivasena, kaṭṭhavāhanajātakaṃādiṃkatvā yāva
analyzed: katvā porāṇa sakya gotamāḥ manaḥ upaṇidhi vasena kaṭṭhavāhana jātakam ādiṃkatvā yāva
translated: made his aspiration for the supreme enlightenment, and beginning with the Katthahari Jataka,

original: majjhimadīpaṅkarā vācaṅgavasena majjhimadīpaṅkarapādamūlato paṭṭhāya kāyavācaṅgavasena
analyzed: majjhima dīpaṅkarāḥ vācaṅga vasena majjhima dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya kāya vācaṅga vasena
translated: or from the foot of the Middle-Indian-Radiant-One, by means of the speech of the Middle-Indian-Radiant-One,

original: sabbaṃ sampiṇḍetvā yāva vessantarattabhāvā vīsati asaṅkhyeyyāni pāramiyo pūrentassa
analyzed: sabbam sampiṇḍetvā yāva vessanta ratta bhāvāḥ vīsati asaṅkhyeyyāni pāramiyaḥ pūrentassa
translated: having combined all (the gifts) together, from the time of the Great Being Vessantara, for twenty incalculable (eons) he fulfilled the Perfections,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇatthāya yeva alaṅkataṃ sīsaṃ chinditvā dentassa sabbaññubodhisattassa🔽sīsaṃ jambudīpavāsīnaṃ uddhanatopi bahutaraṃ, añjitanayanaṃ uppāṭetvā dentassa nayanaṃ🔽ajaṭākāse gaganatale tārāgaṇatopi bahutaraṃ, hadayamaṃsaṃ vā dakkhiṇabāhuṃ vā chinditvā
analyzed: sabbaññu taññāṇa tthāya yā iva alaṅkatam sīsam chinditvā dentassa sabbaññu bodhisattassa  sīsam jambudīpa vāsīnam uddhanataḥ api bahutaram añjita nayanam uppāṭetvā dentassa nayanam  ajaṭā kāse gagana tale tārā gaṇataḥ api bahutaram hadaya maṃsam vā dakkhiṇa bāhum vā chinditvā
translated: and for the sake of the knowledge of omniscience, having cut off his decorated head and given it, of the omniscient Bodhisatta,🔽the head was more numerous than the people living in India, having torn out his anointed eyes and given them, the eyes🔽were more numerous than the multitude of stars in the sky above the hairless (head), having cut out the flesh of his heart or his right arm

original: dentassa maṃsaṃ chanahuta aṭṭhasa hassādhikasatasahassapamāṇasinerurājatopi bahutaraṃ,
analyzed: dentassa maṃsam bahutaram
translated: and given it, the flesh was more numerous than the golden mountain Sineru, which is 99,999 leagues (in height),

original: lohitaṃ uppāṭetvā dentassa ruhiraṃ catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakatopi bahutaraṃ, maddīsadise
analyzed: lohitam uppāṭetvā dentassa ruhiram catūsu mahā samuddesu udakataḥ api bahutaram maddī sadise
translated: having torn out his blood and given it, the blood was more numerous than the water in the four great oceans, having given his wife, who was like me,

original: ca bhariye jālīkaṇhājinasadise ca putte paresaṃ dāsatthāya dentassa gaṇanapathaṃ
analyzed: ca bhariye jālī kaṇha ajina sadise ca putte paresam dāsa tthāya dentassa gaṇana patham
translated: and his son, who was like Jāli and Kaṇhājinna, to others as slaves, the number of his gifts

original: vītivattā. Evaṃ pāramiyo pūrentasseva.
analyzed: vītivattāḥ evam pāramiyaḥ pūrentassa iva
translated: and so he fulfilled the pāramīs.🔽Thinking of Buddhahood for seven incalculables,

original: Cintitaṃ sattasaṅkhyeyyaṃ, navasaṅkhyeyya’vācakaṃ;
analyzed: cintitam satta saṅkhyeyyam nava saṅkhyeyya vācakam
translated: and for nine, speaking of it,🔽and for four, fulfilling them by body and speech,

original: Kāyavācā catukhyātaṃ, buddhattaṃ samupāgamīti.🔽Jātattakīsotattakiyā vuttanayena asūro hutvā buddhattaṃ cintentasseva sattaasaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: kāya vācā catu khyātam buddha ttam samupāgami iti  vutta nayena asūraḥ hutvā buddhattam cintentassa iva satta asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: he reached Buddhahood.

original: vītivattāni. Atisūro ahutvā vācāmattameva nava asaṅkhyeyyāni vītivattāni. Atisūro🔽hutvā kāyaṅgavācaṅgavasena pūrentassa cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni vītivattāni. Imāni cattāri🔽asaṅkhyeyyāni dīpaṅkarapādamūlato paṭṭhāya veditabbāni. Satasahassakappamatthake
analyzed: vītivattāni atisūraḥ a hutvā vācāmattam eva nava asaṅkhyeyyāni vītivattāni atisūraḥ  hutvā kāyaṅga vācaṅga vasena pūrentassa cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni vītivattāni imāni cattāri  asaṅkhyeyyāni dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya veditabbāni sata sahassa kappa matthake
translated: Thinking of Buddhahood as a non-hero, he fulfilled the pāramīs for seven incalculable periods. As a hero, but only speaking of it, he fulfilled them for nine incalculable periods. As a hero,

original: pana ajjhattapāramī pūritāti veditabbā. Vessantarattabhāvena ca sattakamahādānaṃ
analyzed: pana ajjhatta pāramī pūritā iti veditabbā vessanta ratta bhāvena ca sattaka mahā dānam
translated: fulfilling them by body and speech, he fulfilled them for four incalculable periods. These four incalculable periods should be understood to have begun from the time of the Buddha Dīpaṅkara. But the fulfillment of the pāramīs in their highest sense should be understood to have begun a hundred thousand eons ago.🔽As Vessantara, he gave the Great Giving of the Seven Lots, shook the earth seven times, went to the Forest of Thorns, and gave his two children, who were like his eyes,

original: datvā sattakkhattuṃ pathaviṃ kampetvā vaṅkapabbataṃ gantvā nayanasadise dve putte
analyzed: datvā satta kkhattum pathavim kampetvā vaṅka pabbatam gantvā nayana sadise dve putte
translated: to a brahmin.

original: brāhmaṇassa dāsatthāya datvā dutiyadivase brāhmaṇavaṇṇena āgatassa sakkassa devarañño
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa dāsa tthāya da tvā dutiya divase brāhmaṇa vaṇṇena āgatassa sakkassa deva rañño
translated: and on the second day, after giving his daughter Maddi to Sakka, the King of the Gods, who had come in the guise of a brahmin,

original: attasamaṃ maddiṃ nāma bhariyaṃ datvā tasmiṃ bhave aparimeyyāni puññāni katvā tato
analyzed: attasamam maddim nāma bhariyam da tvā tasmin bhave aparimeyyāni puññāni katvā tatas
translated: and after making immeasurable merit in that existence, he went to the Tusita heaven,

original: tusitapuraṃ gantvā tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā dasahi cakkavāḷasahassehi āgantvā devatāvisesehi.
analyzed: tusitapuram gantvā tattha yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā dasahi cakkavāḷa sahassehi āgantvā devatā visesehi
translated: and after remaining there for the full life-span, he came down from the Tusita heaven with the most excellent gods from ten thousand world-spheres,

original: Kālo deva mahāvīra, uppajja mātukucchiyaṃ;
analyzed: kālaḥ deva mahāvīraḥ uppajja mātukucchiyam
translated: and (the gods) said: “The time has come, O God, Great Hero, to be conceived in your mother’s womb;

original: Sadevakaṃ tārayanto, bujjhassu amataṃ padanti.
analyzed: sa devakam tārayantaḥ bujjhassu amatam padanti
translated: Delivering the world with its gods, you will awaken to the Deathless State.”

original: Yāciyamāno kālaṃ dīpañca desañca kulaṃ mātaramevacāti imāni pañca mahāvilokanāni🔽viloketvā tusitapurato cavitvā mahāsammatavaṃsajassa okkākarañño puttānaṃ kusalambhedabhayena
analyzed: kālam dīpam ca desam ca kulam mātaram eva ca ati imāni pañca mahā vilokanāni  viloketvā tusita puratas cavitvā mahāsammatavaṃsajassa okkākarañño puttānam kusalambheda bhayena
translated: Having been asked, (he considered) the time, the country, the family, and the mother, and these five great considerations🔽having been considered, he passed away from the Tusita heaven, and having heard that the sons of King Okkāka, of the Mahāsammata lineage, were making marriages with their sisters,

original: bhaginīhiyeva saddhiṃ āvāhakaraṇaṃ sutvā sakyā vata bho rājakumārāti okkākamahārājena
analyzed: bhaginī hiyā iva saddhim āvāha karaṇam sutvā sakyāḥ vata bho rāja kumārāḥ ati okkāka mahārājena
translated: and having heard the words of the Great King Okkāka: “Sakyans, indeed, are the princes,”

original: vuttavacanaṃ pavattanimittaṃ katvā sakyāti laddhanāmānaṃ rājūnamabbhantare pavattassa
analyzed: vutta vacanam pavatta nimittam katvā sakyāti laddha nāmānam rājūnam abbhantare pavattassa
translated: and having made the words spoken by the Great King Okkāka the reason for the name, the Sakyans, who were kings within the Sakyan lineage,

original: suddhodanamahārājassa jeṭṭhamahesiyā sirimahāmāyāya kucchimhi nibbattitvā dasamāsaccayena
analyzed: suddhodana mahārājassa jeṭṭha mahesiyā sirimahāmāyāya kucchimhi nibbattitvā dasa māsa cayena
translated: and was conceived in the womb of Queen Mahāmāyā, the chief queen of King Suddhodana,

original: devadahanagarassa kapilavatthussa ca majjhe lumbinīvane mātukucchito nikkhamitvā
analyzed: devadaha nagarassa kapilavatthussa ca majjhe lumbinī vane mātukucchitaḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: and after ten months had passed, he was born in the Lumbini Grove, between the cities of Devadaha and Kapilavatthu,

original: jātakkhaṇeyeva uttarābhimukhaṃ sattapadavītihārena gantvā achambhivācaṃ nicchāretvā🔽pitaraṃ vandāpetvā anukkamena soḷasavassuddesikakāle rajjasiriṃ anubhavitvā rāhulabhaddassa
analyzed: jātakkhaṇeyā iva uttara abhimukham satta padavī tihārena gantvā achambhi vācam nicchāretvā  pitaram vandāpetvā anukkamena soḷasa vassuddesika kāle rajjasirim anubhavitvā rāhulabhaddassa
translated: and at the very moment of his birth, he took seven steps in the northern direction, uttered the lion’s roar,🔽and after making his father pay homage to him, in due course, when he was sixteen years old, he experienced the glory of kingship, and after Rāhulabhaddā

original: jātadivase nikkhamitvā chabbassāni dukkaracariyaṃ caritvā vesākhapuṇṇamadivase anuttaraṃ
analyzed: jāta divase nikkhamitvā cha bassāni dukkara cariyam caritvā vesākha puṇṇama divase anuttaram
translated: was born, he went forth on the day of his birth, practiced austerities for six years, and on the full moon day of the month of Āsāḷhā, he attained supreme

original: sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhitvā pañcacattālīsa vassāni devamanussānaṃ ratanadāmaṃ
analyzed: sammāsambodhim abhisambujjhitvā pañcacattālīsa vassāni deva manussānam ratana dāmam
translated: perfect enlightenment, and for forty-five years, like one who bestows a garland of jewels upon gods and humans,

original: ganthento viya dhammaratanavassaṃ vassāpetvā yāva subhaddaparibbājakavinayanā katabuddhakicce
analyzed: ganthentaḥ viya dhammaratana vassam vassāpetvā yāva subhadda paribbājaka vinayanā kata buddha kicce
translated: he rained down the rain of the jewel of the Dhamma, and after the Buddha’s work was done, up to the taming of the wanderer Subhadda,

original: kusinārāyaupavaṭṭane mallānaṃ sālavane vesākhapuṇṇamadivase paccūsasamaye anupādisesāya
analyzed: kusinārāya upavaṭṭane mallānam sālavane vesākhapuṇṇama divase paccūsa samaye an upādisesāya
translated: on the full moon day of the month of Jeṭṭha, at the time of dawn, in the Makuṭabandhana shrine in the city of Kusinārā, in the Sāla Grove of the Mallas, without remainder,

original: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbute bhagavatilokanāthe subhaddena vuḍḍhapabbajitena “alaṃ🔽āvuso mā socittha mā paridevittha, sumuttā mayaṃ tena mahāsamaṇena, upaddutā ca homa’idaṃ
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbute bhagavati loka nāthe subhaddena vuḍḍha pabbajitena alam  āvuso mā socittha mā paridevittha su muttā mayam tena mahā samaṇena upaddutā ca
translated: after the Blessed One, the Protector of the World, had attained Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that has no substrate remaining, Subhadda, who had gone forth in old age, said this: “Enough, friends, do not grieve, do not lament, well-freed are we indeed through the Great Ascetic, we are not oppressed by him,

original: vo kappati idaṃ vo na kappatī’ti. Idāni pana mayaṃ yaṃ icchissāma taṃ karissāma,🔽yaṃ na icchissāma na taṃ karissāmā”ti vuttavacanaṃ sallakkhetvā gaṇapāmokkhānaṃ sattannaṃ
analyzed: vaḥ kappati idam vaḥ na kappati iti idāni pana mayam yam icchissāma tam karissāma  yam naḥ icchissāma na tam karissāma ati vutta vacanam sallakkhetvā gaṇa pāmokkhānam sattannam
translated: When the Blessed One, the Lord of the World, had attained final Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that has no substrate remaining for further existence, Subhadda, who had gone forth in old age, said: “Enough, friends, do not grieve, do not lament. We are well rid of the Great Ascetic. We were always troubled by his saying: ‘This suits you, this does not suit you.’ But now we can do what we like, and not do what we do not like.”

original: ehi bhikkhubhāvāya upanissayasampannaṃ puggalaṃ disvā rattapaṃsukūlantarato suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ🔽dakkhiṇahatthaṃ nīharitvā brahmaghosaṃ nicchārento “ehi bhikkhu cara brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: ehi bhikkhu bhāvāya upanissaya sampannam puggalam disvā ratta paṃsu kūla antarataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam  dakkhiṇa hattham nīharitvā brahmaghosam nicchārentaḥ ehi bhikkhu cara brahmacariyam
translated: seeing a person who has the requisite support for the state of a bhikkhu,🔽extends his right arm, which is marked with the wheel, and, uttering the Brahma voice, he says, “Come, bhikkhu, practice the holy life,”

original: sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti vadati. Tassānantarameva gihiliṅgaṃ antaradhāyitvā.
analyzed: sammā dukkhassa anta kiriyāya iti vadati tassa anantaram eva gihi liṅgam antaradhāyitvā
translated: and immediately the other’s layman’s marks disappear and are replaced by the thirty-two marks of a bhikkhu.

original: Ticīvarañca patto ca, vāsi sūcica bandhanaṃ;
analyzed: ticīvaram ca patto ca vāsi sūci ca bandhanam
translated: The three robes, the bowl, the razor, the needle, the belt,🔽and the water strainer—these are the requisites

original: Parissāvanamaṭṭhete, yuttayogassa bhikkhunoti.
analyzed: yutta yogassa bhikkhuno ti
translated: of the bhikkhu who is intent on the practice.

original: Evaṃ vuttehi aṭṭhahiparikkhārehi sarīre paṭimuttoyeva vassasatikatthero viya iriyāpathasampanno
analyzed: evam vuttehi aṭṭhahi parikkhārehi sarīre vassasatika theraḥ viya iriyāpatha sampanno
translated: When this is said, he stands there with the deportment of a bhikkhu of a hundred years, like the Elder Assagutta, who was endowed with the thirty-two marks of a bhikkhu of a hundred years.

original: buddhācariyako buddhupajjhāyako sammāsambuddhaṃ vandamānova tiṭṭhati. Ayaṃ ehi bhikkhūpasampadā
analyzed: buddha ācariyakaḥ buddha upajjhāyakaḥ sammāsambuddham vandamānaḥ iva tiṭṭhati ayam ehi bhikkhu upasampadā
translated: He is a pupil of the Buddha, a disciple of the Buddha, and he stands there paying homage to the Buddha, the Perfect Sambuddha. This is called “ordination by the going forth.”

original: nāma. Bhagavā hi paṭhamabodhiyaṃ etasmiṃ kāle ehi bhikkhupasampadāya eva upasampādeti.
analyzed: nāma bhagavā hi paṭhama bodhiyam etasmin kāle ehi bhikkhu pasampadāya eva upasampādeti
translated: For the Blessed One at that time only admitted people to the Order by the admission formula beginning with “Come, bhikkhu.”

original: Tāni pana pañcavaggiyādayo aṅgulimālattherapariyosānā.
analyzed: tāni pana pañcavaggiya ādayaḥ
translated: But the group of five, etc., ended with the Elder Aṅgulimāla.

original: Tīṇisataṃ sahassañca, cattālīsaṃ punāparo;
analyzed: sahassam ca cattālīsam
translated: Three thousand two hundred and forty,🔽And one wise elder as well:

original: Eko ca thero sappañño; Sabbe te ehi bhikkhukāti.
analyzed: ekaḥ ca theraḥ sappaññaḥ sabbe te ehi bhikkhukā ti
translated: All were admitted by the words “Come, bhikkhu.”

original: Ete vinayapiṭake niddiṭṭhaehibhikkhū nāma vinayapiṭake aniddiṭṭhā pana tisataparivāraselabrāhmaṇādayo.
analyzed: ete vinaya piṭake niddiṭṭha ehibhikkhū nāma vinaya piṭake aniddiṭṭhā pana ti sata parivāra sela brāhmaṇa ādayo
translated: These are called “admitted by the words ‘Come, bhikkhu’” as shown in the Vinaya Piṭaka. But those not so shown are the three hundred and twenty-five brahmans beginning with Selā.

original: Sattavīsa sahassāni, tīṇiyeva satāni ca;
analyzed: sattavīsa sahassāni tīṇi yā iva satāni ca
translated: Twenty-seven thousand three hundred

original: Ete hi sabbe saṅkhātā, sabbe te ehibhikkhukāti.
analyzed: ete hi sabbe saṅkhātā sabbe te ehibhikkhukā ati
translated: All are called “admitted by the words ‘Come, bhikkhu.’”

original: Taṃ sabbaṃ sampiṇḍetvā aṭṭhavīsasahassāni chasatāni ekacattālīsuttarāni ca honti. Paṭhamabodhica nāmesā vīsativassāni honti.
analyzed: tam sabbam sampiṇḍetvā aṭṭhavīsa sahassāni cha satāni ekacattālīsa uttarāni ca honti vīsati vassāni honti
translated: All these, when added together, come to twenty-eight thousand six hundred and forty-one. And the first enlightenment lasted twenty years.

original: Bhagavā hi anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattetvā aṭṭhārasakoṭibrāhmaṇānaṃ amataṃ pāyetvā
analyzed: bhagavā hi anuttaram dhammacakkam pavattetvā aṭṭhārasa koṭi brāhmaṇānam amatam pāyetvā
translated: For after setting the unsurpassed Wheel of the Dhamma rolling and giving the Deathless to eighteen koṭis of brāhmaṇas, the Blessed One, it seems, went to the brahmin village of Upacālā in the Koliyan country.

original: paṭhamavassaṃ vasi. Dutiyatatiyacatutthavassesu rājagahe veḷuvanavihāre vassaṃ vasi,
analyzed: paṭhama vassam vasi dutiya tatiya catuttha vassesu rājagahe veḷuvana vihāre vassam vasi
translated: and he spent the first Rains Retreat there. In the second, third and fourth Rains Retreats he spent the Rains Retreat in the Bamboo Monastery at Rājagaha.

original: bhagavā hi āsāḷhinakkhattapuṇṇamiyaṃ bārāṇasiyā isipatane migadāye paṭhamavassaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā hi āsāḷhinakkhattapuṇṇamiyam bārāṇasiyā isipatane migadāye paṭhama vassam
translated: For the Blessed One, having spent the first Rains Retreat in the Deer Park at Isipatana near Bārāṇasī on the full-moon day of the Āsāḷha moon,

original: vasitvā phagguṇamāse phagguṇapuṇṇamiyaṃ rājagahaṃ patvā bimbisāraraññā kārite veḷuvana
analyzed: vasitvā phagguṇa māse phagguṇapuṇṇamiyam rājagaham patvā bimbisāra raññā kārite veḷuvana
translated: having gone to Rājagaha on the full-moon day of the Āsāḷhi moon in the month of Phālguna, and having stayed for a month in the Bamboo Monastery which was built by King Bimbisāra,

original: vihāre ekamāsamattaṃ vasitvā citramāse vīsatikhīṇāsavasahassaparivuto kapilavatthuṃ
analyzed: vihāre eka māsa mattam vasitvā citra māse vīsati khīṇāsava sahassa parivutaḥ kapilavatthum
translated: surrounded by twenty thousand perfected ones in the month of Citta, having gone to Kapilavatthu,

original: gantvā asītiyā ñātisahassānaṃ majjhe vippaṭipannānaṃ rājūnaṃ matthake paṃsurajaṃ🔽okiritvā te vandāpetvā pokkharavassañca vassāpetvā tamāgamma asītiyā ñātisahassānaṃ🔽vessantara jātakaṃ kathetvā rāhulamātaramāgamma candakinnarījātakañca kathetvā pitaraṃ
analyzed: gantvā asītiyāḥ ñāti sahassānam majjhe vippaṭipannānam rājūnam matthake paṃsu rajam  okiritvā te vandāpetvā pokkhara vassam ca vassāpetvā tam āgamma asītiyāḥ ñāti sahassānaṃ  vessantara jātakam kathetvā rāhula mātaram āgamma canda kinnarī jātakam ca kathetvā pitaram
translated: having sprinkled the dust of his feet on the heads of the kings who were his relatives,🔽having had them pay homage to him, and having had Pokkharasādi rain down, having gone to the mother of Rāhula,

original: anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhāpetvā rājagahameva āgantvā vāsaṃ kappesi, tena vuttaṃ dutiya
analyzed: anāgāmi phale patiṭṭhāpetvā rājagaham eva āgantvā vāsam kappesi tena vuttam dutiya
translated: and having told the story of the Moon Kinnara, and having established his father in the fruit of non-returner, he returned to Rājagaha and made his dwelling there, therefore it was said: second

original: tatiya catuttha vassesu rājagahe veḷuvanavihāre vassaṃ vasī”ti. Pañcame pana vesāliyaṃ
analyzed: vassesu rājagahe veḷuvana vihāre vassam vasīti pañcame pana vesāliyam
translated: But in the fifth he stayed in Vesālī,🔽and in the sixth he stayed in the Makula mountain.

original: ekavāsaṃ vasi. Chaṭṭhe makuḷapabbate ekavāsaṃ vasi. Puṇṇo vā tattha. Tatrāyaṃ anupubbikathā
analyzed: eka vāsam vasi chaṭṭhe makuḷapabbate eka vāsam vasi puṇṇaḥ vā tattha tatra ayam anupubbi kathā
translated: Here is the story.

original: sunāparantaraṭṭhe kira ekasmiṃ vāṇijakagāme dve bhātaro. Tesu kadāci jeṭṭho pañcasakaṭasatāni
analyzed: kira ekasmin vāṇijaka gāme dve bhātaro tesu kadāci jeṭṭhaḥ pañca sakaṭa satāni
translated: In the Sunāparanta country, it seems, there were two brothers in a certain merchant village.

original: gahetvā janapadaṃ gantvā bhaṇḍaṃ āharati, kadāci kaniṭṭho. Imasmiṃ pana samaye kaniṭṭhaṃ🔽ghare ṭhapetvā jeṭṭhabhātiko pañca sakaṭasatāni gahetvā janapadacārikaṃ caranto anupubbena🔽sāvatthiṃ patvā jetavanassa avidūre pañcasakaṭasatāni ṭhapetvā bhuttapātarāso parijanaparivuto
analyzed: gahetvā janapadam gantvā bhaṇḍam āharati kadāci kaniṭṭhaḥ imasmin pana samaye kaniṭṭham  ghare ṭhapetvā jeṭṭha bhātiko pañca sakaṭa satāni gahetvā janapada cārikam carantaḥ anupubbena  sāvatthim patvā jetavanassa avidūre pañca sakaṭa satāni ṭhapetvā bhutta pāta rāso parijana parivutaḥ
translated: Sometimes the elder would take five hundred carts and go to the country and bring back goods, and sometimes the younger would do so.🔽But on this occasion,🔽after leaving the younger one at home, the elder brother took five hundred carts and went wandering through the country. Eventually🔽he reached Sāvatthī and stopped his five hundred carts not far from Jeta’s Wood. After taking his breakfast, he sat down in a comfortable place surrounded by his retinue.

original: phāsukaṭṭhāne nisīdi. Tena ca samayena sāvatthivāsino bhuttapātarāsā uposathaṅgāni
analyzed: phāsuka ṭṭhāne nisīdi tena ca samayena sāvatthi vāsinaḥ bhutta pāta rāsāḥ uposathaṅgāni
translated: And at that time the people of Sāvatthī, after taking their breakfast, were on their way to the Uposatha house to hear the Uposatha recitation.

original: adhiṭṭhāya suṭṭhuttarāsaṅgā gandhapupphādihatthā yenabuddho, yenadhammo, yenasaṅgho,
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāya suṭṭhu uttarāsaṅgā gandha puppha ādi hatthā yena buddhaḥ yena dhammaḥ yena saṅghaḥ
translated: and then, with their upper robes well arranged, and carrying perfumes, flowers, etc., they went to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.

original: tanninnā tappoṇā tappabbharā hutvā dikkhiṇadvārena nikkhamitvā jetavanaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: tad ninnā tad poṇā tad pabbharā hutvā dikkhiṇa dvārena nikkhamitvā jetavanam gacchanti
translated: They were devoted to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha, and they went out by the southern gate of the city and entered Jetavana.🔽Seeing them, the treasurer asked a certain man, “Where are these people going?”

original: So te disvā “kahaṃ ime gacchantī”ti ekaṃ manussaṃ pucchi. Kiṃ tvaṃ ayyo na jānāsi,
analyzed: saḥ te disvā kaham ime gacchanti iti ekam manussam pucchi kim tvam ayyaḥ na jānāsi
translated: “Do you not know, treasurer?

original: loke buddhadhammasaṅgharatanāni nāma uppannāni, icceva mahājano satthusantike dhammakathaṃ
analyzed: loke buddha dhamma saṅgha ratanāni nāma uppannāni icca iva mahā janaḥ satthu santike dhamma kathaṃ
translated: In the world have appeared the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha, and therefore the multitude is going to hear the Law in the presence of the Teacher.”

original: sotuṃ gacchatīti. Tassa “buddho”ti vacanaṃ chavicammādīni chinditvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca
analyzed: sotum gacchati iti tassa buddho ti vacanam chavi camma ādīni chinditvā aṭṭhimiñjam āhat ca
translated: The word “Buddha” cut through his skin, his flesh, his sinews, and his bones, and penetrated to the marrow.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Atha attano parijanaparivuto tāya parisāyasaddhiṃ vihāraṃ gantvā satthāmadhurassarena
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi atha attano parijana parivutaḥ tāya parisāya saddhim vihāram gantvā
translated: Then, surrounded by his retinue, he went to the monastery with the multitude, and standing at the edge of the assembly, he heard the Teacher preach the Law in a voice sweet as the voice of the kalaviṅka bird.

original: dhammaṃ desentassa parisa pariyante ṭhito dhammaṃ sutvā pabbajjāya cittaṃ uppādesi.
analyzed: dhammaṃ desentassa parisa pariyante ṭhitaḥ dhammaṃ sutvā pabbajjāya cittam uppādesi
translated: And as he listened to the Law, he conceived the desire to become a monk.

original: Atha tathāgatena kālaṃ viditvā parisāya uyyojitāya satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā
analyzed: atha tathāgatena kālam viditvā parisāya uyyojitāya satthāram upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā
translated: Then the Tathāgata, perceiving that the time was opportune, dismissed the assembly. The treasurer approached the Teacher, paid obeisance to him,🔽and said,

original: svātanāya nimantetvā dutiyadivase maṇḍapaṃ karetvā āsanāni paññāpetvā buddhappamukhassa
analyzed: svātanāya nimantetvā dutiya divase maṇḍapam karetvā āsanāni paññāpetvā buddha ppamukhassa
translated: and invited him to stay for the morrow. On the following day he had a pavilion erected, had seats prepared,

original: saṅghassa mahādānaṃ datvā bhattakiccāvasāne bhagavā anumodanaṃ katvā pakkami. Bhuttapātaraso
analyzed: saṅghassa mahādānam da tvā bhatta kicca avasāne bhagavā anumodanam katvā pakkami bhutta pāta rasaḥ
translated: and gave a great gift to the Order with the Buddha at its head. When the meal was finished, the Buddha pronounced the words of thanksgiving, and then departed. After breakfast,

original: uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ pakkosāpetvā “ettakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ vissajjitaṃ
analyzed: uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya bhaṇḍāgārikam pakkosāpetvā ettakam bhaṇḍam vissajjitam
translated: having determined upon the Observance, he summoned the treasurer and said to him, “So much property have I distributed,

original: ettakaṃ pana na vissajjita”nti sabbaṃ ācikkhitvā “imaṃ sāpateyyaṃ mayhaṃ kaniṭṭhassa
analyzed: ettakam pana na vissajjitanti sabbam ācikkhitvā imam sāpateyyam mayham kaniṭṭhassa
translated: and so much have I not distributed.” Having thus informed him of everything, he said to him, “Give this property to my younger brother,

original: dehī”ti sabbaṃ niyyotetvā satthu santike pabbajitvā kammaṭṭhāna parāyaṇo ahosi. Athassa🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ na upaṭṭhāti, tato cintesi “ayaṃ janapado
analyzed: dehi iti sabbam niyyotetvā satthu santike pabbajitvā kammaṭṭhāna parāyaṇaḥ ahosi athassa  kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontassa kammaṭṭhānam na upaṭṭhāti tatas cintesi ayam janapadaḥ
translated: and make over to him all that I have.” Having thus made over to him all his property, he retired from the world in the presence of the Teacher and devoted himself to the practice of meditation.

original: mayhaṃ asappāyo, yaṃnūnāhaṃ satthu santike kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā sakaṭṭhānameva gaccheyya”nti.
analyzed: mayham asappāyaḥ yat nūna aham satthu santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā saka ṭṭhānam eva gaccheyyanti
translated: But as he applied his mind to the practice of meditation, the practice of meditation did not appear to him in due order. Thereupon he thought to himself, “This country is not suitable for me. Suppose I were to go to my own country and there obtain the practice of meditation?”

original: Atha pubbaṇhasamaye piṇḍāya caritvā sāyanhasamaye paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: atha pubbaṇha samaye piṇḍāya caritvā sāyanha samaye paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ bhagavantam
translated: So in the morning he went his round for alms, and in the evening, when he had come out from his retirement,🔽he went to the Teacher and said to him, “Reverend Sir, this country is not suitable for me. I desire to go to my own country and there obtain the practice of meditation.”

original: upasaṅkamitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathāpetvā satthā sīhanādaṃ naditvā pakkami. Atha kho
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā kammaṭṭhānam kathāpetvā satthā sīha nādam naditvā pakkami atha kho
translated: and after he had come and had had the meditation subject explained to him, the Teacher roared his lion’s roar and went away. Then the venerable Puṇṇa,

original: āyasmā puṇṇo sūnāparantaraṭṭhaṃ patvā sammatapabbataṃ nāma pavisitvā vāṇijakagāmaṃ
analyzed: āyasmā puṇṇaḥ sūnāparantaraṭṭham patvā sammatapabbatam nāma pavisitvā vāṇijaka gāmam
translated: having reached the country of Sunāparanta, entered a place called Sammata Mountain and went into the village of the merchants

original: piṇḍāya pāvisi. Atha naṃ kaniṭṭhabhātā sagehaṃ netvā bhikkhaṃ datvā “bhante aññattha
analyzed: piṇḍāya pāvisi atha nam kaniṭṭha bhātā sa geham netvā bhikkham da tvā bhante aññattha
translated: for alms. Then his younger brother took him home and gave him alms and made him promise to stay there, saying, “Venerable sir, do not go anywhere else,

original: agantvā idheva vasathā”ti paṭiññaṃ kāretvā vasāpesi. Tato samuddagirivihāraṃ nāma
analyzed: a gantvā idha iva vasatha ati paṭiññam kāretvā vasāpesi tatas samuddagirivihāram nāma
translated: stay here.” So he stayed there. Then he went to a dwelling place called Samudda Mountain.

original: agamāsi. Tattha samuddavīciyo āgantvā ayakaṇṭapāsāṇesu paharitvā mahāsaddaṃ karonti.
analyzed: agamāsi tattha samudda vīciyaḥ āgantvā ayakaṇṭa pāsāṇesu paharitvā mahā saddam karonti
translated: There the waves of the ocean came and dashed against the rocks and made a great noise.

original: Thero kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto na phāsuvihāro hotīti samuddaṃ nisaddaṃ katvā adhiṭṭhāsi.🔽Tato mātulagiriṃ nāma āgamāsi. Tattha sakuṇasaṅgho ussanno rattiñca divā ca saddo
analyzed: theraḥ kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ na phāsu vihāraḥ hoti iti samuddam nisaddam katvā adhiṭṭhāsi  tatas mātulagirim nāma āgamāsi tattha sakuṇa saṅghaḥ ussannaḥ rattim ca divā ca saddo
translated: The elder found it was no place for him to attend to his meditation subject, so he resolved that the ocean should be soundless.🔽Then he went to a place called Mātula Mountain. There a flock of birds was noisy and made a noise

original: eko baddho hoti. Thero “idaṃ ṭhānaṃ aphāsukanti tato makuḷakārāmavihāraṃ nāma gato.
analyzed: ekaḥ baddhaḥ hoti theraḥ idam ṭhānam tatas makuḷakārāmavihāram nāma gataḥ
translated: day and night. The elder thought, “This is no place for me,” and so he went to a dwelling place called Makulaka Monastery.

original: So vāṇijagāmassa nātidūro nāccāsanno gamanāgamanasampanno vivitto appasaddo. Thero🔽“idaṃ ṭhānaṃ phāsuka”nti tattha rattiṭṭhānadivāṭhāne caṅkamanādīni kāretvā vassaṃ
analyzed: saḥ vāṇija gāmassa na ati dūraḥ na acca āsannaḥ gamana āgamana sampannaḥ vivittaḥ appasaddaḥ thero  idam ṭhānam phāsukanti tattha ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭhāne caṅkamana ādīni kāretvā vassam
translated: The place was neither too far from the village nor too near it, and it was convenient for coming and going. It was secluded and free from noise. The Elder

original: upagacchati. Evaṃ catūsu ṭhānesu vihāsi. Athekadivasaṃ tasmiṃyeva antovasse pañca
analyzed: upagacchati evam catūsu ṭhānesu vihāsi atha eka divasam tasmin yeva antovasse pañca
translated: thought, “This is a comfortable place,” and he had a night quarters and a day quarters built there, and he entered upon the rains. Thus he lived in four places. Then one day, while the rains were still current,

original: vāṇijakasatāni “parasamuddaṃ gacchāmā”ti nāvāya bhaṇḍaṃ pakkhipiṃsu. Nāvārohanadivase
analyzed: vāṇijaka satāni para samuddam gacchāma ati nāvāya bhaṇḍam pakkhipiṃsu nāvā ārohana divase
translated: five hundred merchants, saying, “We will go to the other ocean,” loaded their ship with merchandise. On the day when they were to set out on the voyage,

original: therassa kaniṭṭhabhātā theraṃ bhojetvā therassa santike sikkhāpadāni gahetvā gacchanto
analyzed: therassa kaniṭṭha bhātā theram bhojetvā therassa santike sikkhāpadāni gahetvā gacchantaḥ

translated: The Teacher left that place and went to the mountain Saccabandha. When he had gone there, he said to Saccabandha, “You have caused a great multitude to enter upon the road that leads to the Downfall. You must remain here and give up the gains that you have received, and cause them to enter upon the road that leads to Extinction.” He also asked the Teacher to give him a place where he might dwell. The Teacher pointed out to him the place where he had left his footprint on the rock at Ghanapindiya, and said to him, “There is a place where you may dwell.” Thus in the kingdom of Sūnaparanta two shrines containing relics of the Buddha’s foot were established, and remained there until the disappearance of the Faith.🔽In the seventh year of his ministry the Teacher, while residing at Sāvatthi in the root of a Kandala tree,

translated: The Teacher left there and went to the Saccabandha mountain, and said to Saccabandha, “You have caused a great multitude to be plunged into the road that leads to the states of woe. You must remain here and give up the gains that they have given you, and cause them to be established in the road that leads to Nibbāna.” He asked the Teacher to take care of him. The Teacher pointed out to him the Cetiya of the Footprint, as if he had marked it with a lump of fresh clay on a flat stone. Thus he established two Cetiyas of the Wheel in the kingdom of Sūnaparanta, and they remained there until the religion disappeared. In the seventh year, while the Teacher was performing the Twin Miracle and confounding the heretics at the foot of the Kaṇḍamba tree at Sāvatthi, and was preaching the Abhidhamma to the deities who had assembled from ten thousand world systems, and had caused his mother to become a Witness of the Dhamma, he spent the rainy season in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, at the foot of the pāricchattaka tree, on the Silver Rock. In the eighth year he spent the rainy season in the city of Saṃsumāra. In the ninth year he spent the rainy season at Kosambī.
