translated: Why is the water-throwing to be done by the extent of the gathering?

original: Apare evaṃ vadanti pubbe udakukkhepoyeva pamāṇaṃ, puna udakukkhepakiccaṃ natthi,
analyzed: apare evam vadanti pubbe udakukkhepaḥ yā iva pamāṇam puna udakukkhepa kiccam natthi
translated: Others say that the water-throwing is the measure only at first; there is no further need for water-throwing.

original: kathinatthatasāṭakadānakammavācāviya tathā hi kathinatthatasāṭakadānakāle vuttakammavācā
analyzed: tathā hi kathinattha tasa āṭaka dāna kamma vācā
translated: For just as, when the robe-cloth for the kaṭhina is given, the announcement of the transaction

original: ekāyevavaṭṭati, atthateyeva kathine puna varasāṭakaṃ labhitvā kammavācāya dānakiccaṃ
analyzed: kathine puna vara sāṭakam labhitvā kamma vācāya dāna kiccam
translated: is only done once, and when the kaṭhina has been spread, there is no further need for the announcement of the transaction when another piece of cloth is obtained,

original: natthi evameva etthāpi pubbe udakukkhepoyeva pamāṇaṃ, puna udakukkhepakiccaṃ natthīti
analyzed: natthi evam eva ettha api pubbe udakukkhepo yā iva pamāṇam puna udakukkhepa kiccam natthi iti
translated: so too here the water-throwing is the measure only at first; there is no further need for water-throwing.”

original: te upacārasīmāyamiva maññitvā vadanti upacārasīmāyañhi purisāya nisinnaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: te upacāra sīmāyam iva maññitvā vadanti upacāra sīmāyam hi purisāya nisinna ṭṭhānam eva
translated: They say this thinking of the area of access, for in the area of access the place where a man is sitting is the measure.

original: upacārasīmābhāvena vaḍḍhati idha pana parisapariyantato udakukkhepappamāṇena vaḍḍhatiyeva
analyzed: upacāra sīmā bhāvena vaḍḍhati idha pana parisa pariyantataḥ udakukkhepa ppamāṇena vaḍḍhatiyā iva
translated: It increases by the extent of the surrounding space of the zone of influence. But here it increases by the extent of the throwing of the water.

original: na udakukkhepaṃ vināva ijjhate “kathaṃ pana udakaṃ ukkhipitabbaṃ yathā akkhadhuttā
analyzed: na udakukkhepam vinā avaḥ ijjhate katham pana udakam ukkhipitabbam yathā akkhadhuttā
translated: It does not succeed without the throwing of the water. But they break the text of the commentary when it says, “How is the water to be thrown? As the dice-throwers

original: dāruguḷaṃ khipanti, evaṃ udakaṃ vā vālikaṃ vā hatthena gahetvā thāmamajjhimena purisena🔽sabbathāmena khipitabbaṃ, yattha evaṃ khittaṃ udakaṃ vā vālikaṃ vā patati, ayameko
analyzed: dāru guḷam khipanti evam udakam vā vālikam vā hatthena gahetvā thāma majjhimena purisena  sabbathāmena khipitabbam yattha evam khittam udakam vā vālikam vā patati ayam ekaḥ
translated: throw a die, so the water or the sand should be taken with the hand and thrown by a man of average strength.🔽Where the water or the sand falls, that is one throwing of the water.”

original: udakukkhepo”ti aṭṭhakathāvacanaṃ bhindanti nāma. Kimivāti ce, ye pana “kammameva
analyzed: udakukkhepaḥ ti aṭṭhakathā vacanam bhindanti nāma kim iva ati ce ye pana kammam eva
translated: And what do they say? Those who say, “Only kamma

original: kammakaraṇaṃ karoti, natthi nirayapālā”ti vadanti, te “atthi bhikkhave niraye nirayapālā”ti
analyzed: kamma karaṇam karoti natthi niraya pālā ati vadanti te atthi bhikkhave niraye niraya pālā ati
translated: does the deed of kamma; there are no warders of hell” break the text of the Devadūta Sutta when it says, “There are, bhikkhus, warders of hell” .

original: devadūtasuttaṃ bhindanti viyāti. Evañcapana vadeyya ye udakukkhepena saha ijjhanti,🔽tepi “sacepi hi bhikkhusahassaṃ tiṭṭhati, tassa ṭhitokāsassa bāhirantato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: deva dūta suttam bhindanti viya ati evañca pana vadeyya ye udakukkhepena saha ijjhanti 🔽te pi sace pi hi bhikkhu sahassam tiṭṭhati tassa ṭhita ukāsassa bāhirantataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: But those who say that it succeeds with the throwing of the water should say that it succeeds for those who throw the water,🔽and that the extent of the surrounding space of the zone of influence is the extent of the throwing of the water. And they should say that the extent of the surrounding space of the zone of influence is the extent of the throwing of the water for those who throw the water, and that it is the extent of the throwing of the water for those who do not throw the water.

original: bhikkhūnaṃ vaggakammaparihāratthaṃ sīmāpekkhāya uppannāya tāya saha sayameva sañjātā🔽sattabbhantarasīmā samānasaṃvāsakāti adhippāyo. Yattha pana khuddake araññe mahantehi
analyzed: bhikkhūnam vagga kamma parihāra attham sīmā apekkhāya uppannāya tāya saha sayam eva sañjātā  satta abbhantara sīmā samāna saṃvāsakā ti adhippāyaḥ yattha pana khuddake araññe mahantehi
translated: The intention is that the seven-league zone arises together with the expectation of a zone, which has arisen for the purpose of avoiding a schism among the bhikkhus.

original: vā bhikkhūhi paripuṇṇatāya vaggakammasaṅkābhāvena sattabbhantarasīmāpekkhā natthi,🔽tattha sattabbhantarasīmā na uppajjati, kevalāraññasīmāyameva tattha saṅghena kammaṃ
analyzed: vā bhikkhūhi paripuṇṇa tāya vagga kamma saṅkā abhāvena satta bbhantara sīmā apekkhā natthi  tattha satta bbhantara sīmā na uppajjati kevala arañña sīmā ayam eva tattha saṅghena kammaṃ
translated: But where there is no expectation of a seven-league zone because of the absence of any fear of a schism due to the smallness of the forest or the largeness of the bhikkhus,🔽there the seven-league zone does not arise. The Sangha should do the legal procedure there within the zone of the whole forest. This is the method in the case of rivers, etc.”

original: kātabbaṃ nadīādīsupi esevanayo”ti vimati vinodaniyaṃ vuttavacanaṃ bhindanti nāmāti.
analyzed: kātabbam nadī ādīsu pi vimati vinodaniyam vutta vacanam bhindanti nāma ati
translated: They break the words of the Vinodaniya, which says this.

original: Taṃ na, tena no kā hāni evampi amhākaṃ vāde koci virodho na vijjateva. Kasmāti ce,
analyzed: tam na tena no kā hāni evam pi amhākam vāde koci virodhaḥ na vijjate iva kasmāt iti ce
translated: But what loss is there to us if we do it this way? In this way too there is no contradiction in our doctrine. If it is asked why,

original: ime dve saddaracanāpi asambandhāva bhinnalakkhaṇā bhinnavisayā cetā sīmā. Kathaṃ
analyzed: ime dve bhinna lakkhaṇā bhinna visayā sīmā kathaṃ
translated: these two verbal formulations are unrelated and have different characteristics and different spheres. How?

original: saddaracanā asambandhā. Yathā araññe tattha sattabbhantarasīmā na uppajjati, kevalāraññamevāti
analyzed: asambandhā yathā araññe tattha satta bhantara sīmā na uppajjati kevala āraññam eva ati
translated: The verbal formulations are unrelated. Just as the seven-league zone does not arise in the forest, so too the whole forest is the zone.

original: vuccati, eva meva “nadiyāpi sabbattha saṅgho nisīdati, udakukkhepasīmā nuppajjatī”ti
analyzed: vuccati eva mā eva nadiyā api sabbattha saṅghaḥ nisīdati udakukkhepa sīmā na uppajjati iti
translated: “The Saṅgha sits down everywhere on the river, and the water-enclosed sīmā does not come into existence” is said.

original: avatvā “udakukkhepasīmā kammaṃ natthī”ti kriyāparāmasanavasena vuttaṃ. Karitabbaṃ
analyzed: a vatvā udakukkhepa sīmā kammam na atthi iti kriyā parāmasana vasena vuttam karitabbam
translated: But without saying this, it is said by way of the criticism of the action: “There is no water-enclosed sīmā transaction.”

original: kammaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ, khipanaṃ. Evampi saddaracanā asambandhāva. “Vaggakammaparihāratthaṃ…pe…
analyzed: kammam kim tam khipanam evam pi
translated: The transaction that should be done is what? It is the throwing in. Even so, the verbal expression is not connected. “For the purpose of avoiding the transaction of a faction …

original: udakukkhepasīmā sattabbhantarasīmā uppajjati, nāsatī”ti ettha “nāsatī”ti imassa udakukkhepena
analyzed: udakukkhepa sīmā sattabbhantara sīmā uppajjati na asati iti ettha na asati iti imassa udakukkhepena
translated: the water-enclosed sīmā comes into existence within the seven-monas-terrace sīmā, and it does not come into existence” here, the meaning of “it does not come into existence” is suitable even without the water-enclosed sīmā.

original: vināpīti atthopi yujjateva. Kasmāti ce “sīmāpekkhāya satievā”ti iminā anulomanayavasena🔽“sīmāpekkhāya asati nuppajjatī”ti attho yujjateva. Kecipana “samantā abbhantaraṃ
analyzed: vinā api iti atthaḥ pi yujjatā iva kasmā iti ce sīmā apekkhāya sati eva ati iminā anulomana ya vasena  sīmā apekkhāya asati nuppajjati iti atthaḥ yujjatā iva samantā abbhantaram
translated: If it be said: “Why?” by way of the method of conformity with this, “when there is no sīmā to be expected,” the meaning is suitable even thus.

original: minitvā paricchedakaraṇeneva sīmā sañjāyati, na sayamevā”ti vadanti taṃ na gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: minitvā pariccheda karaṇena iva sīmā sañjāyati na sayam eva ati vadanti tam na gahetabbam
translated: But some say: “Having measured the inside all round, the sīmā is produced by the making of the boundary, not by itself.” That should not be accepted.

original: Yadi hi…pe… yathā cettha, evaṃ udakukkhepasīmāyapi nadīādīsupi tatthāpi hi majjhimapuriso
analyzed: yadi hipe yathā ca ittha evam nadī ādīsu pi tattha api hi majjhima purisaḥ
translated: If it were so, … as it is here, so also in the water-enclosed sīmā, and in the river, etc., there too the man in the middle

original: na ñāyati, tathā sabbathāmena khipananti imināpi vacanena ācariyavarassa udakukkhepena
analyzed: na ñāyati tathā khipananti iminā api vacanena ācariya varassa udakukkhepena
translated: “And by the throwing of water in every direction” : by this statement it is understood that the intention is that the water-throwing-boundary arises only when the boundary is being looked at, not when it is not.

original: saheva sīmāpekkhāya sati udakukkhepasīmā uppajjati, nāsatīti adhippāyo ñāyati. Kathaṃ
analyzed: saha iva sīmā apekkhāya sati udakukkhepa sīmā uppajjati na asatī iti adhippāyaḥ ñāyati katham
translated: How?

original: bhinnalakkhaṇā, gāmasīmasattabbhantaraudakukkhepasīmā kiñcāpi abaddhasīmasāmaññena
analyzed: bhinna lakkhaṇā gāma sīma satta abbhantara audakukkhepa sīmā kiñca api abaddha sīma sāmaññena
translated: The village-boundary, the seven-finger-breadth-internal-boundary, and the water-throwing-boundary have different characteristics. Although they are similar in that they are unfixed boundaries,

original: samānā, na pana samānalakkhaṇā tathā hi “asammatāya bhikkhave sīmāya aṭṭhapitāya
analyzed: samānā na pana samāna lakkhaṇā tathā hi asammatāya bhikkhave sīmāya aṭṭhapitāya
translated: they are not of the same characteristics. For in this training rule, “Monks, in an unconsecrated, unfixed boundary,

original: yaṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati, yā tassa gāmassa vā gāmasīmā, nigamassa🔽vā nigamasīmā, ayaṃ tattha samānasaṃvāsā ekūposathā”ti imasmiṃ sikkhāpade khuddako🔽vā mahanto vā sabbopi gāmapadeso gāmasīmāti anuññātā, na sattabbhantarasīmāya viya
analyzed: yam gāmam vā nigamam vā upanissāya viharati yā tassa gāmassa vā gāma sīmā nigamassa  vā nigama sīmā ayam tattha samāna saṃvāsā eka uposathā ti imasmim sikkhāpade khuddako  vā mahantaḥ vā sabbaḥ api gāma padesaḥ gāma sīmā ati anuññātā na satta bbhantara sīmāya viya
translated: whatever village or town they live near, the village boundary or town boundary of that village or town,🔽this is the common affiliation, the single Uposatha” , whether small or large, all the village area is permitted as the village boundary, not as the seven-finger-breadth-internal-boundary, which is permitted by the throwing of a ball all around.

original: samantā leḍḍupātukkhepena anuññātā abbhantarasīmāyapi agāmake ce araññe yaṃ nissāya
analyzed: samantā leḍḍu pātu khepena anuññātā abbhantara sīmāya api a gāmake ce araññe yam nissāya
translated: In the case of the internal boundary, “If in a wilderness without villages,

original: viharati, tassa araññassa araññasīmāti nānuññātā tathā nadīsamuddajātassaresupi gāmasīmāyamiva🔽sabbo nadīsamuddajātassarapadeso nadīsamuddajātassa rasīmāti evameva na anuññātā
analyzed: viharati tassa araññassa arañña sīmā ati na anuññātā tathā gāma sīmāyam iva  sabbaḥ nadī samudda jātassa ra padesaḥ nadī samudda jātassa ra sīmā ati evam eva na anuññātā
translated: And just as the area of the village is not allowed as the boundary of the river, the ocean, and the natural pond,🔽so the whole area of the river, the ocean, and the natural pond is not allowed as the boundary of the river, the ocean, and the natural pond.

original: tathā abbhantarasīmāyamiva samantā sattabbhantarāti vā nānuññātā evamimā gāmasīmasattabbhantaraudakukkhepasīmā
analyzed: tathā abbhantara sīmā ayam iva samantā satta bbhantarā ati vā na anuññātā evam imāḥ gāma sīma satta bbhantara odakukkhepa sīmā
translated: And just as the area of seven abbhantaras is not allowed as the boundary of the inside, so the area of seven abbhantaras is not allowed as the boundary of the inside.🔽Thus the area of the village, the area of seven abbhantaras, and the area of throwing water are different in characteristic.

original: bhinnalakkhaṇā, tasmā bhagavatā paññattasikkhāpadānusāreneva gāmasīmāyapi khuddako
analyzed: bhinna lakkhaṇā tasmai bhagavatā paññatta sikkhāpada anusārena iva gāma sīmāya api khuddako
translated: Therefore, in accordance with the training rules laid down by the Lord, the whole area of the village, whether small or large, is the area of the village.🔽And in accordance with the training rules laid down by the Lord, the area of seven abbhantaras is the area of seven abbhantaras.

original: vā mahanto vā sabbo gāmapadeso gāmasīmāva hoti, sattabbhantarasīmāyapi “samantā sattabbhantarā”ti🔽paññattasikkhāpadānusārena samantā sattabbhantarasīmā sīmāpekkhāya saha sayameva
analyzed: vā mahantaḥ vā sabbaḥ gāma padesaḥ gāma sīmā ava hoti samantā sattabbhantarā ati  paññatta sikkhāpada anusārena samantā satta abbhantara sīmā sīmā apekkhāya saha sayam eva
translated: The consideration of whether the area of seven abbhantaras is the area of seven abbhantaras or not is pointless.

original: uppajjatī”ti minanāminanavicāraṇā pana niratthakāva tathā udakukkhepasīmāyapi “majjhimassa
analyzed: uppajjati iti minana aminana vicāraṇā pana niratthakā eva tathā majjhimassa
translated: And in accordance with the training rules laid down by the Lord, the area of throwing water is the area of throwing water.

original: purisassa samantā udakukkhepā”ti paññattasikkhāpadānurūpaṃ udakukkhepena saheva uppajjatīti
analyzed: purisassa samantā uda kukkhepā ti paññatta sikkhāpada anurūpam uda kukkhepena saha iva uppajjati iti
translated: and the extent of the throwing of water by a man all round it.🔽So there is no point in considering whether it is thrown or not thrown.

original: natthi khipanākhipana vicāraṇāya payojananti. Kathaṃ bhinnavisayā sattabbhantarasīmā
analyzed: natthi khipana ākhipana vicāraṇāya payojanan ti katham bhinna visayā satta bbhantara sīmā
translated: How the seven kinds of adjacent territory have different spheres of influence

original: araññavisayā, udakukkhepasīmā nadīsamuddajātassaravisayā, evampi etā gāmasīmasattabbhantaraudakukkhepasīmā
analyzed: arañña visayā udakukkhepa sīmā nadī samudda jātassara visayā evam pi etāḥ gāma sīma satta bbhantarā odakukkhepa sīmā
translated: The adjacent territory of the monastery has the monastery as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the monastery zone has the monastery zone as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the village has the village as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the village zone has the village zone as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the river has the river as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the ocean has the ocean as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the lake has the lake as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the reservoir has the reservoir as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the water has the water as its sphere of influence. The adjacent territory of the throwing of water has the throwing of water as its sphere of influence.🔽In this way, the seven kinds of adjacent territory have different spheres of influence.

original: bhinnavisayāva tasmā “nadīādīsu eseva nayo”ti vuttepi sattabbhantarasīmā apekkhāya🔽saheva attano sabhāveneva sattabbhantarasīmā uppajjati yathā. Evameva udakukkhepasīmāyapi
analyzed: bhinna visayā ava tasmā nadī ādīsu esā iva nayo ti vutte pi  saha iva attanaḥ sabhāvena iva sattabbhantara sīmā uppajjati yathā evam eva udakukkhepa sīmāya api
translated: That is why, although it is said that “the same method applies to rivers, etc.,” the adjacent territory of the throwing of water comes into existence only in dependence on the adjacent territory of seven people.

original: apekkhāya saha udakukkhepaṃ katvāva vaggakammaparihāratthaṃ udakukkhepasīmā uppajjati,
analyzed: apekkhāya saha udakukkhepam katvā ava vagga kamma parihāra attham udakukkhepa sīmā uppajjati
translated: Just as the adjacent territory of seven people comes into existence only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the village, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the monastery, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the monastery zone, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the village zone, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the river, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the ocean, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the lake, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the reservoir, and only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the water,🔽so too the adjacent territory of the throwing of water comes into existence only in dependence on the adjacent territory of the throwing of water, and only in order to avoid the schism of a faction, and only after the throwing of water has been done.

original: na vināti sanniṭṭhānaṃ kātabbaṃ. Nanu ca mātikāṭṭhakathāyaṃ paricchedabbhantare hatthapāsaṃ
analyzed: na vinā iti sanniṭṭhānam kātabbam nanu ca mātikā aṭṭhakathā ayam pariccheda abbhantare hattha pāsam
translated: The resolution should not be invalidated.

original: vijahitvā ṭhitopi, paricchedā bahi aññaṃ tattakaṃyeva paricchedaṃ anatikkamitvā ṭhitopi
analyzed: vijahitvā ṭhitaḥ api paricchedāḥ bahi aññam tattakam yā iva paricchedam an atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ api
translated: And also if he stands outside the territory, not having crossed the other territory which is the same size as his own.

original: kammaṃ kopeti, idaṃ sabbaaṭṭhakathāsu sinniṭṭhāna’nti vuttavacane navirujjhatīti
analyzed: kammam kope ti idam sabba aṭṭhakathāsu sinniṭṭhānam ti vutta vacane na virujjhati iti
translated: This is the settled opinion in all the commentaries.🔽If it is asked: But is it not contradicted by the statement in the Abhidhamma Commentary?

original: ce. Taṃ na, mātikāṭṭhakathāyaṃ “sace pana dvesaṅghā visuṃvisuṃ uposathādikammaṃ karonti,
analyzed: ce tam na sace pana dvi saṅghāḥ visum visum uposatha ādi kammam karonti
translated: It is not contradicted, because in the Abhidhamma Commentary it is said: “But if the two Saṅghas perform the Uposatha and other transactions separately,

original: dvinnaṃ udakukkhepānaṃ antare añño eko udakukkhepo upacāratthāya ṭhapetabbo”ti dvinnaṃ🔽saṅghānaṃ visuṃ visuṃ kammakaraṇādhikāre vuttattā. Sāratthadīpaniyampi “tattha aññaṃ🔽tattakaṃyeva paricchedaṃ anatikkamitvā ṭhitopi kammaṃ kopetīti idaṃ neva pāḷiyaṃ,
analyzed: dvinnam udakukkhepānam antare aññaḥ ekaḥ udakukkhepaḥ upacāra atthāya ṭhapetabbaḥ iti dvinnam  saṅghānam visum visum kamma karaṇa adhikāre vutta ttā sārattha dīpaniyam pi tattha aññam  tattakam yā iva paricchedam an atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ api kammam kopeti iti idam na iva pāḷiyam
translated: between the two immersions of the bowl a third immersion of the bowl should be made for the purpose of the observance ceremony.”🔽This is said in the passage on the authority for the two Saṅghas to perform the transactions separately.🔽And in the Sārattha Dīpanī it is said: “Herein, it is not found either in the texts or in the commentaries that ‘also if he stands outside the territory, not having crossed the other territory which is the same size as his own, he halts the transaction.’

original: na aṭṭhakathāyaṃ upalabbhati. Yadi cetaṃ dvinnaṃ saṅghānaṃ visuṃvisuṃ uposathādikammakaraṇādhikāre
analyzed: na upalabbhati yadi ca itam dvinnam saṅghānam visum visum uposatha ādi kamma karaṇa adhikāre
translated: And if this is said because of the authority for the two Saṅghas to perform the Uposatha and other transactions separately,

original: vuttattā udakukkhepato bahi aññaṃ udakukkhepaṃ anatikkamitvā uposathādikaraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ttā udakukkhepataḥ bahi aññam udakukkhepam an atikkamitvā uposatha ādi karaṇa attham
translated: then it is for the purpose of performing the Uposatha and other transactions without crossing the other immersion of the bowl outside the immersion of the bowl.”

original: Ṭhito saṅgho sīmāsambhedasambhavato kammaṃ kopetīti iminā adhippāyena vuttaṃ siyā.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ saṅghaḥ sīmā sambheda sambhavataḥ kammam kopeti iti iminā adhippāyena vuttam siyā
translated: “The Sangha, when standing, cancels a transaction because of the possibility of a breach of the territory” is said with this intention.

original: Evaṃ sati yujjeyya, teneva mātikāṭṭhakathāyaṃ līnatthappakāsaniyaṃ aññaṃ tattakaṃyeva
analyzed: evam sati yujjeyya tena iva mātikā aṭṭhakathā ayam līna attha ppakāsaniyam aññam tattakam yeva
translated: If that is so, it would be right. In the commentary on the mātikā, in the explanation of the meaning of “obscure,” it is said:

original: paricchedanti dutiyaṃ udakukkhepaṃ anatikkamantopi kopeti. Kasmā, attano udakukkhepasīmāya
analyzed: dutiyam udakukkhepam an atikkamantaḥ api kopeti kasmai attanaḥ udakukkhepa sīmāya
translated: “The second throwing in of the water is not exceeded, but it is canceled. Why? Because the throwing in of the water of one’s own territory

original: paresaṃ udakukkhepasīmāya ajjhotthatattā sīmāsambhedo hoti, tasmā kopetī’ti “idaṃ
analyzed: paresam udakukkhepa sīmāya sīmā sambhedaḥ hoti tasmā kopeti iti idam
translated: is overlapped by the throwing in of the water of another’s territory, there is a breach of the territory, and that is why it is canceled.”

original: sabbaaṭṭhakathāsu sanniṭṭhāna”nti ca iminā adhippāyena vuttanti gahetabbaṃ. Sabbāsupi
analyzed: sabba aṭṭhakathāsu sanniṭṭhānam ti ca iminā adhippāyena vuttan ti gahetabbam sabbāsu pi
translated: This is the conclusion in all the commentaries. It should be understood that it is said with this intention. In all the commentaries,

original: aṭṭhakathāsu sīmāsambhedassa anicchitattā teneva attano ca aññesañca udakukkhepaparicchedassa
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāsu sīmā sambhedassa an icchita ttā tena iva attano ca aññesañca udakukkhepa paricchedassa
translated: because it is not intended that there should be a breach of the territory, it is said that “between one’s own throwing in of the water and another’s throwing in of the water,

original: antarā añño udakukkhepo sīmantarikatthāya ṭhapetabboti vuttaṃ. Aññe panettha aññathāpi
analyzed: antarā aññaḥ udakukkhepaḥ sīmantarika tthāya ṭhapetabbo ti vuttam aññe pana ittha aññathā api
translated: another throwing in of the water should be set up for the purpose of a boundary.” But others here explain it in another way,

original: papañcenti, taṃ na gahetabba’nti vatvā paṭikkhittaṃ. Tassa “antohatthapāsaṃ vijahitvā
analyzed: papañcenti tam na gahetabban ti vatvā paṭikkhittam tassa antohattha pāsam vijahitvā
translated: which should not be accepted. It is rejected. “Having left the range of arm’s reach,

original: ṭhito kammaṃ kopetī”ti iminā paricchedato bahi yatthakatthaci ṭhito kammaṃ na kopetīti🔽dīpetīti sāratthadīpanīvacanenāpi ekasmiṃ saṅghasannipāte paricchedato bahi aññaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ kammam kopeti iti iminā paricchedataḥ bahi yattha katthaci ṭhitaḥ kammam na kopeti iti  dīpeti iti sāratthadīpanī vacanena api ekasmin saṅgha sannipāte paricchedataḥ bahi aññam
translated: “Standing outside the boundary, he does not cancel the transaction” shows the delimitation.

original: tattakaṃyeva paricchedaṃ anatikkamitvā ṭhitopi kammaṃ na kopetīti veditabbametaṃ
analyzed: tad takam yeva paricchedam an atikkamitvā ṭhitaḥ api kammam na kopeti iti veditabbam etam
translated: By the words “showing the meaning of the essence” it should be understood that even standing within a single meeting of the Sangha, he does not cancel the transaction if he does not overstep the delimitation.

original: sāratthadīpaniyaṃyeva imamatthaṃ daḷhikaraṇavasena udakukkhepappamāṇā sīmantarikā
analyzed: imamattham daḷhi karaṇa vasena uda kukkhepa ppamāṇā sīmantarikā
translated: The meaning of this is confirmed by the words “The extent of the boundary is the extent of the throwing of the water-strainer.”

original: suviññeyyatarā hoti, sīmāsambhedasaṅkā ca na siyāti sāmicidassanatthaṃ añño udakukkhepo
analyzed: su viññeyyatarā hoti sīmā sambheda saṅkā ca na siyāti sāmi cit assana ttham aññaḥ udakukkhepo
translated: The boundary is more easily recognized and there is no danger of the boundary being divided.🔽Therefore, in order to show the boundary, another throwing of the water-strainer should be made for the purpose of the boundary.

original: sīmantarikatthāya ṭhapetabbo’ti vuttaṃ. Yattakena pana sīmāsambhedo na hoti, tattakaṃ
analyzed: sīmantarika atthāya ṭhapetabbo ti vuttam yattakena pana sīmā sambhedaḥ na hoti tattakam
translated: But it is allowable to make it the extent that does not cause confusion of the boundary.

original: ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva, tenāhu porāṇā “yattakena sīmasaṅkaro na hoti, tattakampi ṭhapetuṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetum tena āhu porāṇāḥ yattakena sīma saṅkaraḥ na hoti tattakam pi ṭhapetum
translated: Therefore the ancients said, “It is allowable to make it the extent that does not cause confusion of the boundary.🔽But it is not allowable to make it too small.”

original: vaṭṭati. Khuddakaṃ pana na vaṭṭatī”ti idampi udakukkhepasīmāya parisavasena vaḍḍhanato
analyzed: vaṭṭati khuddakam pana na vaṭṭati iti idam pi udakukkhepa sīmāya parisa vasena vaḍḍhanato
translated: This is because the boundary of the throwing of the water-strainer increases by the perimeter of the water-strainer.

original: sīmasambhedasaṅkā siyā. Taṃ nivāraṇatthameva vuttanti.🔽Pāḷiṃ aṭṭhakathañceva, ṭīkāvimatiādike;
analyzed: sīma sambheda saṅkā siyā tam nivāraṇa attham eva vuttam ti  pāḷim ṭīkā vimati ādike
translated: and the danger of the breaking of the territory would arise. It is said for the purpose of preventing that.🔽Having looked again and again at the text, the commentary,

original: Oloketvā punappunaṃ, maññantu kavipuṅgavāti;
analyzed: oloketvā punappunam maññantu kavi puṅgava iti
translated: and the sub-commentary, and the doubts, etc.,🔽let the best of poets think:

original: Ayamettha udakukkhepasīmāya vicāraṇā.
analyzed: ayam ettha udakukkhepa sīmāya vicāraṇā
translated: This is the discussion of the “throwing water” territory.

original: Janapadasīmā nāma ekassa rañño vijite pavatto mahāmaccānaṃ nivāsabhūto ekameko padeso janapadasīmā nāma.🔽Raṭṭhasīmā nāma kāsikosalādikā soḷasa mahājanapadā. “Soḷasamahānagara”ntipi tesaṃ
analyzed: janapada sīmā nāma ekassa raññaḥ vijite pavattaḥ mahā maccānam nivāsa bhūto ekamekaḥ padesaḥ janapada sīmā nāma  raṭṭhasīmā nāma kāsi kosala ādikā soḷasa mahā janapadā tesam
translated: The “country territory” is the name for each individual place in the realm of a king, which is the dwelling place of the ministers.

original: nāmaṃ. Tattha soḷasa mahājanapadāni nāma. Aṅgaraṭṭhaṃ, magadharaṭṭhaṃ, kosalaraṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: nāmam tattha soḷasa mahā janapadāni nāma aṅga raṭṭham magadha raṭṭham kosala raṭṭham
translated: The “kingdom territory” is the name for the sixteen great countries such as Kāsi, Kosala, etc. “The sixteen great cities” is also their name. Therein, the sixteen great countries are: Aṅga country, Magadha country, Kosala country,

original: vajjiraṭṭhaṃ, cetiyaraṭṭhaṃ, kururaṭṭhaṃ, pañcālaraṭṭhaṃ, majjharaṭṭhaṃ, surasenaraṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: vajjiraṭṭham cetiyaraṭṭham kururaṭṭham pañcālaraṭṭham majjharaṭṭham surasenaraṭṭham
translated: Vajji country, Cetiya country, Kuru country, Pañcāla country, Majjhima country, Surasenā country,

original: assakaraṭṭhaṃ, avantiraṭṭhaṃ, gandhālaraṭṭhaṃ, mallaraṭṭhaṃ, kambojaraṭṭhanti imāni
analyzed: assakaraṭṭham avantiraṭṭham gandhālaraṭṭham mallaraṭṭham kambojaraṭṭham imāni
translated: Assaka country, Avanti country, Gandhāra country, Malla country, Kamboja country. These are🔽the sixteen great countries.

original: soḷasamahājanapadāni nāma. Ime soḷasamahājanapadā majjhimapadeseyeva pavattā mahāraṭṭhā🔽nāma tadaññepi sunāparantaraṭṭhādikā bahutarāva. Tathā paccantavisayepi rāmaññādikā
analyzed: soḷasamahājanapadāni nāma ime soḷasa mahā janapadāḥ majjhima padeseya iva pavattāḥ mahā raṭṭhāḥ  nāma tad aññe pi bahutarā ava tathā paccanta visaye pi rāmañña ādikā
translated: These sixteen great countries are only in the Middle Country.🔽There are many more than these, such as the Sunaparanta country, etc.🔽And in the border regions there are many great countries such as Rāmañña, etc.🔽All these are called “country-boundaries.”

original: anekappabhedā mahāraṭṭhā attheva tepi sabbe raṭṭhasīmā nāma. Lokiyasatthesu pana
analyzed: aneka ppabhedāḥ mahā raṭṭhāḥ attha iva te pi sabbe raṭṭhasīmāḥ nāma lokiya satthesu pana
translated: But in worldly usage,

original: yasmiṃ padese khattiyabrāhmaṇavessasuddavasena catuvaṇṇāni vasanti, so padeso “mahāraṭṭho”ti
analyzed: yasmin padese khattiya brāhmaṇa vessa sudda vasena catuvaṇṇāni vasanti saḥ padesaḥ mahāraṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: the country in which the four castes, namely, nobles, brahmans, merchants, and laborers, are found, is called a “great country.”

original: pavuccati. Vuttañhe taṃ porāṇehi.
analyzed: pavuccati vuttañhe tam porāṇehi
translated: For this is said by the ancients:

original: “Pavattā catuvaṇṇānaṃ, yasmiṃ padese na vijjate;
analyzed: pavattā yasmin padese na vijjate
translated: “The country in which the four castes🔽Are not found is called a barbarian country;

original: So milakkhudeso vutto, puññabhūmi tato para”nti.
analyzed: so milakkhu desaḥ vutto puññabhūmi tatas paranti
translated: The land beyond that is a land of merit.”

original: Rajjasīmā nāma ekassa rañño āṇāpavattaṭṭhānaṃ rajjasīmā nāma.
analyzed: rajja sīmā nāma ekassa rañño āṇāpavatta ṭṭhānam rajja sīmā nāma
translated: A “kingdom-boundary” is the area within which the command of a king holds sway.

original: Dīpasīmā nāma samuddantare vā nadimajjhe vā pavattā dīpā dīpasīmā nāma. Yasmiṃ pana
analyzed: dīpa sīmā nāma samudda antare vā nadi majjhe vā pavattāḥ dīpāḥ dīpa sīmā nāma yasmim pana
translated: An “island-boundary” is an island in the ocean or in a river. But in the case of a country

original: dīpe gāmā vasanti, so gāmasīmātveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati, vakkhati hi sukkhe jātassare
analyzed: dīpe gāmāḥ vasanti saḥ gāma sīmā tvā iva saṅkhyam gacchati vakkhati hi sukkhe jātassare
translated: If villages are situated on an island, it is reckoned as a village boundary. For it is said: “In a dried-up lake.”

original: vāpiṃ vā khaṇanti vappaṃ vā karonti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ gāmakhettaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: vāpim vā khaṇanti vappam vā karonti tam ṭhānam gāma khettam hoti iti
translated: If villages are situated on an island, that island is reckoned as the boundary of the village. For it is said, “When a dry river-bed is flooded, or when they dig a canal or make a field,” that place is the field of the village.

original: Cakkavāḷasīmā nāma “āyāmato ca vitthārato ca yojanānaṃ dvādasasatasahassāni tīṇisahassāni cattārisatāni paññāsañcayojanāni.
analyzed: cakkavāḷasīmā nāma āyāmato ca vitthārato ca yojanānam dvādasa sata sahassāni tīṇi sahassāni cattāri satāni paññā sañca yojanāni
translated: The world-sphere boundary: “It is twelve thousand leagues in width and breadth, and thirty-six hundred and forty-five leagues in circumference.

original: Parikkhepato
analyzed: parikkhepato
translated: The circumference is

original: “Sabbaṃ satasahassāni, chattiṃsaparimaṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: sabbam sata sahassāni chattiṃsa parimaṇḍalam
translated: ‘All of it is a hundred thousand, thirty-six and a half leagues,

original: Dasañceva sahassāni, aḍḍhuḍḍhāni satānicā”ti.
analyzed: dasan ca iva sahassāni aḍḍhuḍḍhāni satāni ca ati
translated: and ten thousand, eight hundred and fifty.’

original: Vuttaṃ ekaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ cakkavāḷasīmā nāma. Evaṃ pannarasappabhedā hoti sīmā. Tattha
analyzed: vuttam ekam cakkavāḷam cakkavāḷa sīmā nāma evam pannarasa pabhedā hoti sīmā tattha
translated: This is said to be one world-sphere. This is called the world-sphere boundary. In this way, the boundaries are of fifteen kinds.

original: iddhimā puggalo yasmiṃ yasmiṃ vā sīme uposathādisaṅghakammaṃ karoti, tattha tattha
analyzed: puggalaḥ yasmim yasmim vā sīme uposatha ādi saṅgha kammam karoti tattha tattha
translated: If a person with supernormal power performs the Sangha’s legal procedures such as the Uposatha in any of these boundaries,

original: gate bhikkhū hatthapāsanayanaṃ vā bahisīmakaraṇaṃ vā kātuṃ chandārahānaṃ, chandaṃ
analyzed: gate bhikkhū hattha pāsa nayanam vā bahi sīmakaraṇam vā kātum chandāra hānam chandam
translated: the monks who are present there are not obliged to go to another boundary or to make that boundary outside the boundary. They are entitled to🔽give their consent.

original: āharitvā kātuṃ sakkuṇeyyabhāvoyeva pamāṇaṃ. Evamasakkonte aniddhimapuggale sandhāya
analyzed: āharitvā kātum pamāṇam evam a sakkonte aniddhim apuggale sandhāya
translated: and the measure is whether one can do it after bringing it.🔽If one cannot do it, it is with reference to a person who has no psychic power.

original: atimahantāraññe samantā sattabbhantarasīmā anuññātā. Tattha sīmāpekkhāya saha samantā
analyzed: atimahantāraññe samantā satta abbhantara sīmā anuññātā tattha sīmā apekkhāya saha samantā
translated: and the measure is whether or not one can go and come back in a day. If one cannot, then a boundary is allowed in a very large forest, seven leagues all round. There the boundary is considered to be the natural boundary all round,

original: sattabbhantarasīmā attano sabhāveneva jātā tathā nadīsamuddajātassaresupi majjhimassa🔽purisassa samantā udakukkhepasīmā anuññātā tatthapi vaggakammaparihāratthaṃ sīmāpekkhaṃ🔽katvā udakukkhepena saha udakukkhepasīmā uppajjati tathā gāmanigamajanapadanagararaṭṭharajjasīmāsupi
analyzed: satta abbhantara sīmā sabhāvena iva jātā tathā majjhimassa  purisassa samantā udakukkhepa sīmā anuññātā tattha api vagga kamma parihāra attham sīmā apekkham  katvā udakukkhepena saha udakukkhepa sīmā uppajjati tathā gāma nigama janapada nagara raṭṭha rajja sīmāsu pi
translated: seven leagues in extent. So too in rivers, seas, lakes, and streams, a boundary is allowed for the middle of a river, etc., seven leagues in extent,🔽and there the boundary is considered to be the middle of the river, etc., all round, seven leagues in extent. So too in villages, towns, countries, cities, kingdoms, and principalities, a boundary is allowed for the purpose of preventing schisms in a united Order,

original: vaggakammaparihāratthaṃ baddhasīmā anuññātā. Tato paresu pana gāmasīmasattabbhantaraudakukkhepasīmā
analyzed: vagga kamma parihāra attham baddha sīmā anuññātā tatas paresu pana gāma sīma satta abbhantara audakukkhepa sīmā
translated: and there the boundary is considered to be the boundary that is set by the proclamation. But in other villages, etc., a boundary is allowed seven leagues in extent, and in the middle of a river, etc., a boundary is allowed seven leagues in extent,

original: nuññātasuttānulomanayasāmatthiyato khuddakesu gāmanigamajanapadanagaresu tattha tattha
analyzed: khuddakesu gāma nigama janapada nagaresu tattha tattha
translated: because it is proper to follow the method of the allowance in the Khuddaka Texts. In the case of villages, towns, countries, and cities,

original: gate bhikkhū sodhetvā chandārahānaṃ chandaṃ āharitvā samaggassa saṅghassa anumatiyāva
analyzed: gate bhikkhū sodhetvā chandārahānam chandam āharitvā samaggassa saṅghassa anumatiyā ava
translated: When the monks have gone, he should purify the boundary, bring the consent of those who are present, and perform the Community’s transactions of the observance-day ceremony, etc., with the consent of the Community that is complete.

original: uposathādisaṅghakammaṃ kātabbameva tathā khuddake araññepi nadījātassarepi yathāsukhaṃ
analyzed: uposatha ādi saṅgha kammam kātabbam eva tathā khuddake araññe pi nadī jāta ssare pi yathāsukham
translated: And so too in a small wilderness, in a river, in a lake, he should perform the Community’s transactions of the observance-day ceremony, etc., as he likes.

original: uposathādisaṅghakammaṃ kātabbamevāti.
analyzed: uposatha ādi saṅgha kammam kātabbam eva ati
translated: The Community’s transactions of the observance-day ceremony, etc., should be performed.

original: Evaṃ paricchindanalakkhaṇena abhedepi baddhābaddhavasena duvidhā. Tappabhedena pannarasavidhā,🔽sarūpavasena pana khaṇḍasīmā, upacārasīmā, samānasaṃvāsasīmā, avippavāsasīmā, lābhasīmā,🔽gāmasīmā. Nigamasīmā, nagarasīmā, abbhantarasīmā, araññasīmā, udakukkhepasīmā, nadīsīmā,
analyzed: evam paricchindana lakkhaṇena abhede pi baddha abaddha vasena duvidhā tad pabhedena pannarasavidhā  sarūpa vasena pana khaṇḍa sīmā upacāra sīmā samāna saṃvāsa sīmā a vippavāsa sīmā lābha sīmā  gāma sīmā nigama sīmā nagara sīmā abbhantara sīmā arañña sīmā udakukkhepa sīmā nadī sīmā
translated: So, though there is no difference in the characteristic of defining, it is twofold as bound and unbound. It is fifteenfold by analysis of the kinds of transaction.

original: jātassarasīmā, samuddasīmā, janapadasīmā, raṭṭhasīmā, rajjasīmā, dīpasīmā, cakkavāḷasīmātiekūnavīsappabhede
analyzed: jātassara sīmā samudda sīmā janapada sīmā raṭṭha sīmā rajja sīmā dīpa sīmā cakkavāḷa sīmā ati ekūnavīsappa bhede
translated: But as to individual essence, there are nineteen kinds of boundary, that is to say: a boundary by definition, a boundary by proclamation, a common-claim boundary, a boundary by what is agreed upon, a boundary by the edge of a robe, a boundary by the edge of a field, a boundary by a path, a boundary by a river, a boundary by a lake, a boundary by a sea, a boundary by a village, a boundary by a town, a boundary by a city, a boundary by a country, a boundary by a region, a boundary by a kingdom, a boundary by an island, a boundary by a world-sphere, a boundary by throwing water, a boundary by a river, a boundary by a lake, a boundary by a sea.

original: pi sīme vipattilakkhaṇaṃ pahāya sampattilakkhaṇappakāsakaṃ sīmavisodhanīnāma pakaraṇaṃ samattaṃ.🔽Iti
analyzed: pi sīme vipatti lakkhaṇam pahāya sampatti lakkhaṇa ppakāsakam sīmavisodhanī nāma pakaraṇam samattam 🔽iti
translated: The chapter called “The Purification of the Boundaries,” which shows the characteristic of success in the boundaries, abandoning the characteristic of failure, is completed.

original: “Sīmavisodhaniṃ nāma, nānāganthasamāhaṭaṃ;
analyzed: sīmavisodhanim nāma nānā gantha samāhaṭam
translated: “The ‘Sīma-visodhani’ is a collection of various schools;

original: Karissaṃ me nisāmentu, sādhavo kavipuṅgavā.
analyzed: karissam me sādhavaḥ kavi puṅgavā
translated: I will make it, may the good, the best of poets, listen to it.

original: Pāḷiṃ aṭṭhakathañceva, mātikāpadabhājaniṃ;
analyzed: pāḷim aṭṭha katham ca iva mātikā pada bhājanim
translated: The text, the commentary, the mātikā, and the padabhājani;

original: Ogāhetvāna taṃ sabbaṃ, punappunamasesato.🔽Attanomatiganthesu, ṭīkāgaṇṭhipadesu ca;
analyzed: ogāhetvāna tam sabbam punappunam asesataḥ  atta no mati ganthesu ṭīkā gaṇṭhi padesu ca
translated: Having plunged into all of that again and again,🔽In the Atthanāmatīkā, the Gaṇṭhi, and the Padesa,

original: Vinicchayavimatīsu, mātikāṭṭhakathāsupi.
analyzed: vinicchaya vimatīsu mātikā aṭṭhakathāsu pi
translated: In the Vinicchaya, the Vimati, and the Mātikāṭṭhakathā,

original: Sabbaṃ asesakaṃ katvā, saṃsanditvāna ekato;
analyzed: sabbam asesakam katvā saṃsanditvānaḥ ekatas
translated: Having done everything completely, having combined them all together,

original: Pavattā vaṇṇanā esā, tosayantī vicakkhaṇe”ti.
analyzed: pavattā vaṇṇanā esā tosayantī vicakkhaṇā iti
translated: This commentary is presented, pleasing the wise.”

original: Imesaṃ gāthāpadānaṃ attho sabbaso saṃvaṇṇito hoti.
analyzed: imesam gāthā padānam attho sabbaso saṃvaṇṇitaḥ hoti
translated: The meaning of these verses is all explained.

analyzed: gaṇanā nāma bhūmīsu saṅkhyā evam pakāsitā ati  tad upari brahma pārisajja ādayo tayo brahmuno aṭṭha sahassa yojane
translated: The reckoning of the planes is thus declared.”🔽The three Brahmas, namely, the retinue of the Parittābhā Brahmas, etc., stand on a level plane five hundred and fifty thousand leagues in extent.

original: hi cattāro buddhā anubuddho, sāvakabuddho, paccekabuddho, sammāsambuddhoti. Tattha
analyzed: hi cattāraḥ buddhāḥ anubuddho sāvakabuddho paccekabuddho sammāsambuddho ti tattha
translated: Herein, the Buddha as discoverer is the one who discovers the Dhamma for himself and then teaches it to others.🔽The Buddha as disciple is the one who discovers the Dhamma for himself and then teaches it to others.

analyzed: pana paratas yosa vasena cattāri saccāni bujjhati bujjhana mattam eva vāti vacana atthena  bujjhana sabhā vattā sāvakabuddho nāma yaḥ pana khaggavisāṇa kappo sayambhū ñāṇena anañña bodhako
translated: but he awakens to the four truths by means of the “thus” in the sense of “thus it is” .🔽He is called a “lesser Buddha” because of his nature as one who awakens.

original: hutvā sāmaṃ bujjhanatthena paccekabujjhattā paccekabuddho nāma. Sambuddhotipi etasseva
analyzed: hutvā sāmam bujjhan atthena pacceka bujjha ttā paccekabuddhaḥ nāma sambuddhaḥ tipi etassa iva
translated: He is called a “solitary Buddha” because of his awakening by himself, without teaching by another, by means of his own knowledge, like the horn of the rhinoceros.🔽This is also his name.

analyzed: nāmam yaḥ pana saṅkhata asaṅkhata ppabhedam sakalam pi dhamma jātam yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇa ppaṭivedha vasena

analyzed: sabba dhamme bujjhi abujjhi aññāsi iti sammāsambuddhaḥ bhagavā saḥ uva loke dullabhaḥ paccekasambuddhānam pi
translated: and he was the Blessed One, the world’s supreme rare person.

original: hi ekasmiṃ kāle satasahassādivasena ekato pavattattā te dullabhāpi anacchariyajātattā
analyzed: hi ekasmin kāle sata sahassa ādi vasena ekatas pavatta tā te dullabhā api
translated: For although they are rare, they are not so very rare, since they occur together in one time, in one world-sphere, in one world-system, in one country, and in one person.

translated: Four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons is a world-dissolution, a world-dissolution period, a world-evolution, and an evolution period.🔽There are three kinds of world-dissolution: dissolution by water, by fire, and by wind.

original: āposaṃvaṭṭo, tejosaṃvaṭṭo, vāyosaṃvaṭṭo. Tisso saṃvaṭṭasīmā ābhassarā, subhakiṇhā,🔽vehapphalāti. Ayamettha uddeso. Tattha saṃvaṭṭo nāma parihāyamāno kappo. Tena saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyīpi

original: gahito hoti, taṃ mūlakattā. Vaḍḍhayamāno vivaṭṭakappo nāma. Tena vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīpi

translated: Good sirs, look after your mothers, look after your fathers, be respectful to the elders of the family.”

original: Tesaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena manussā ca bhummadevatā ca saṃvegajātā aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: tesam vacanam sutvā yebhuyyena manussā ca bhummadevatā ca saṃvega jātā aññamaññam
translated: Having heard their words, for the most part humans and the earth gods,

original: muducittā hutvā mettādīni puññāni karitvā devaloke nibbattanti. Tattha sudhābhojanaṃ🔽bhuñjitvā vāyo parikammaṃ katvā jhānaṃ paṭilabhanti, evaṃ nerayikasattāpi aparāpariyakammena🔽devalokaṃ nibbattanti. Ye pana niyatamicchādiṭṭhikā tesaṃ kammassa aparikkhayā aññacakkavāḷesu🔽attano kammānurūpaṃ vipākamanubhonti. Teneva ahosikamme micchādiṭṭhivasena akattabbaṃ
analyzed: mudu cittāḥ hutvā mettā ādīni puññāni karitvā deva loke nibbattanti tattha sudhā bhojanam  bhuñjitvā parikammam katvā jhānam paṭilabhanti evam nerayika sattā api apara apariya kammena  deva lokam nibbattanti ye pana niyatam icchādiṭṭhikā tesam kammassa aparikkhayāḥ añña cakkavāḷesu  attano kamma anurūpam vipākam anubhonti tena iva ahosi kamme micchādiṭṭhi vasena a kattabbam
translated: and having done meritorious deeds such as loving kindness, etc., they are reborn in the world of the gods. There they eat the food of merit,🔽and having made the wind their attendant, they attain jhāna. In this way, beings in hell are reborn in the world of the gods by the power of the merit they have made. But those who are fixed in wrong views, because their kamma is not exhausted, experience the results of their kamma in other world systems in accordance with their kamma. Therefore, in the case of the kamma that is to be experienced in some other birth, wrong view is not to be done.🔽

original: nāma pāpaṃ natthi, yato saṃsārakhāṇubhāvova nāma hotīti āha “diṭṭhi paramāni bhikkhave🔽vajjānī”ti. “Aparāpariyavedanīyakammarahitopi saṃsaranto satto nāma natthī”ti vuttattā.
analyzed: nāma pāpam natthi yatas nāma hoti iti āha diṭṭhi paramāni bhikkhave  vajjāni iti apara apariya vedanīya kamma rahitaḥ api saṃsarantaḥ sattaḥ nāma natthi iti vutta ttā
translated: and having done meritorious deeds such as loving kindness, etc., they are reborn in the world of the gods. There they obtain jhāna either by eating the food of merit or by making the wind their occupation. In this way, beings in hell are reborn in the world of the gods by the power of the merit they have made. But those who are fixed in wrong views experience the results of their kamma in other world-spheres in accordance with their kamma. Therefore it is said: “There is no evil deed so small as not to be feared” . Thus it is said: “Bhikkhus, wrong views are the worst of the wrongnesses” . “There is no being who wanders in saṃsāra without kamma that must be experienced either in this life or in some subsequent life.”🔽“One who wanders in saṃsāra without kamma that must be experienced either in this life or in some subsequent life does not exist.”

original: “Aparāpariyakammavasena yato micchādiṭṭhisamādānato sappurisūpanissayavasena virājetvā
analyzed: apara apariya kamma vasena yatas micchādiṭṭhi samādānato sappurisa upanissaya vasena virājetvā
translated: “One who wanders in saṃsāra without kamma that must be experienced either in this life or in some subsequent life does not exist.”

original: bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ nāma bhaveyyāti amhākaṃ khanti. Evaṃ devaloke paṭiladdhajjhānavasena
analyzed: bhavataḥ vuṭṭhānam nāma bhaveyyāti amhākam evam deva loke paṭiladdha jhāna vasena
translated: “The emergence from existence is yours, not ours.”🔽And so they are all reborn in the Brahmā-world by means of the jhāna acquired in the deva world.

original: sabbepi brahmaloke nibbattanti. Vassupacchedato pana uddhaṃ dīghassa addhuno accayena

translated: but in the light of the sun of the aeon’s end the sky is clear and cloudless, like a looking-glass.

original: ādāsamaṇḍalaṃ viya nimmalaṃ hoti nabhaṃ ṭhapetvā gaṅgā, yamunā, sarabhū, aciravatī,

analyzed: anotattadaho chaddantadaho kuṇāladaho ti ime satta mahā sarā sussanti tatas dīghassa  addhunaḥ accayena pañcamaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā anupubbena mahā samuddaḥ

Then, after the passing of a long period, a sixth sun appears,

analyzed: sūriyaḥ pātubhavati yasmin pātubhāve sakala cakkavāḷam eka dhūmam hoti pariyādinna sineha dhūmena

analyzed: yathā ca evam koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷam pi tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena sattamaḥ

analyzed: sūriyo pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā sakala cakkavāḷam eka jālam hoti saddhim koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷehi

translated: to become one flaming mass. The peaks of Sineru, a hundred leagues high, etc., fall away and disappear in the sky.🔽That mass of fire

original: gaṇhāti etenūpāyena yāva paṭhamajjhānabhūmi gaṇhāti. Tattha tayopi brahmaloke jhāpetvā
analyzed: gaṇhāti etena upāyena yāva paṭhamajjhāna bhūmi gaṇhāti brahmaloke jhāpetvā
translated: rises up and seizes the realm of the Four Kings, there it burns up the golden palaces and the jewel palaces, and then it seizes the realm of the Thirty-three. In this way it seizes the realms up to the plane of the first jhāna. There it burns up the three brahmalokas,

original: ābhassare āhacca aṭṭhāsi. Sā yāva aṇumattampi saṅkhāragataṃ atthi, tāva nanibbāyi.
analyzed: ābhassare āhacca aṭṭhāsi sā yāva aṇumattam pi saṅkhāra gatam atthi tāva nanibbāyi
translated: and then it stands still, having reached the Ābhassara gods. It does not die out as long as there is the subtlest trace of formations left.

original: Sabbasaṅkhāraparikkhayā pana sappitelajhāpanaaggisikhā viya chārikampi anavasesetvā
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāra parikkhayā pana sappi tela jhāpana aggi sikhā viya chārikam pi an avasesetvā
translated: But when all formations have been exhausted, it dies out without leaving even ashes,🔽like a flame burning ghee or oil.

original: nibbāyi. Heṭṭhā ākāsena saha upari ākāso eko hoti mahandhakāro. Evaṃ kappavināsakamahāmeghato
analyzed: nibbāyi heṭṭhā ākāsena saha upari ākāsaḥ ekaḥ hoti mahandhakāraḥ evam kappa vināsaka mahā meghato
translated: and the space above became one vast darkness. Thus the destruction of the world by water lasts for one incalculable age.

original: yāvajālaparicchedā saṃvaṭṭo nāma ekamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ nāma. Atha dīghassa addhuno accayena🔽mahāmegho vuṭṭhahitvā paṭhamaṃ sukhumaṃ vassati. Anupubbena kumudanāḷayaṭṭhimusalatālakkhandhādippamāṇāhi
analyzed: yāvajāla paricchedā saṃvaṭṭaḥ nāma ekam asaṅkhyeyyam nāma atha dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena  mahā meghaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā paṭhamam sukhumam vassati anupubbena kumuda nāḷa yaṭṭhi musala tāla kkhandha ādi ppamāṇāhi
translated: Then, after the passing of a long period,🔽a great cloud appears and first showers gently. Gradually,

original: dhārāhi vassanto koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷesu sabbaḍaḍḍhaṭṭhānaṃ pūretvā antaradhāyati.
analyzed: dhārāhi vassantaḥ koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷesu sabba ḍaḍḍha ṭṭhānam pūretvā antaradhāyati
translated: raining with drops as large as mustard seeds, kidney beans, jujube stones, bamboo stems, and so on, it fills up all the places that have been emptied in the ten-thousand world-element.

original: Taṃ udakaṃ heṭṭhā ca tiriyañca vāto samuṭṭhahitvā ghanaṃ karoti. Parivaṭumaṃ paduminipatte🔽udakabindusadisaṃ. Evaṃ aggijālanibbāyanato yāva koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparipūrato
analyzed: tam udakam heṭṭhā ca tiriyañca vātaḥ samuṭṭhahitvā ghanam karoti parivaṭumam  udaka bindu sadisam evam aggi jāla nibbāyanataḥ yāva koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa paripūrataḥ
translated: Then the water subsides, and the wind that has arisen below and all around gathers it together into one, making it compact like the water in a puddle that has been reduced by evaporation.🔽Thus the great cloud that has appeared and the great flood that has arisen and the great cloud that has disappeared all last for one incalculable age.

original: sampattimahāmegho, idaṃ saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī nāma, dutiyamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ nāma. Kathaṃ tāva
analyzed: sampatti mahā meghaḥ idam saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī nāma dutiyam asaṅkhyeyyam nāma katham tāva
translated: How is it that the world remains destroyed?

original: mahantaṃ udakarāsiṃ vāto ghanaṃ karotīti ce. Vivarasampadānato taṃ vā tena piṇḍiyamānaṃ
analyzed: mahantam udaka rāsim vātaḥ ghanam karoti iti tam vā tena piṇḍiyamānam
translated: If it be said that the wind compresses the great mass of water,

original: ghanaṃ kariyamānaṃ parikkhayamānaṃ anupubbena heṭṭhā otarati. Otiṇṇotiṇṇe udake pubbe
analyzed: ghanam kariyamānam parikkhayamānam anupubbena heṭṭhā otarati otiṇṇa utiṇṇe udake pubbe
translated: then it is because of the perfection of the interstices that the water is compressed, is compressed together, is exhausted, and gradually descends below.🔽In the water that has descended,

original: brahmalokaṭṭhāne brahmapāri sajja-brahmapurohitamahābrahmāvasena paṭhamajjhānabhūmi
analyzed: brahma loka ṭṭhāne brahmapāri sajja brahma purohita mahābrahma avasena paṭhamajjhāna bhūmi
translated: the plane of the first jhāna appears first in the place of the Brahma-world,

original: paṭhamaṃ pātubhavati. Tato otiṇṇotiṇṇe udake catukāmāvacaradevalokaṭṭhāne anukkamena
analyzed: paṭhamam pātubhavati tatas otiṇṇa utiṇṇe udake catu kāmāvacara deva loka ṭṭhāne anukkamena
translated: and then, in the water that has descended, the four planes of the sense-sphere divine worlds appear in order,

original: paranimmitavasavattī, nimmānaratī, tusitā, yāmāti cattāro kāmāvacaradevalokā pātubhavanti.
analyzed: cattāraḥ kāmāvacara deva lokā pātubhavanti
translated: namely, the Paranimmitavasavatti, the Nimmānarati, the Tusita, and the Yāma.

analyzed: tato purima patha viṭṭhānam otiṇṇe pana udake balava vātāḥ uppajjanti te tam pidahita dvāre  dhama karaṇe ṭhita odakam iva nirussāsam katvā nirujjhanti madhura udakam parikkhayam
translated: But when the water has descended to the extent of the former earth’s extent, strong winds arise. They blow away the water as though it were scattered,🔽as though it were sucked up, as though it were drunk, as though it were dissolved. The sweet water,

original: gacchamānaṃ upari rasapathaviṃ samuṭṭhāpeti sā vaṇṇasampannāceva hoti gandharasasampannā
analyzed: gacchamānam upari rasa pathavim samuṭṭhāpeti sā hoti gandha rasa sampannā
translated: being exhausted, produces above it a sweet-flavoured earth that is perfect in colour and smell and taste,

original: ca, nirudakapāyāsassa upari paṭalaṃ viya tadā ca ābhassarabrahmaloke paṭhamatarābhinibbattā
analyzed: ca upari paṭalam viya tadā ca ābhassara brahmaloke paṭhamatara abhinibbattā
translated: and like a lid over a pot of water, the beings who first arose in the Brahmā-world of Streaming- radiance

original: sattā āyukkhayā vā puññakkhayā vā tato cavitvā idhūpapajjanti. “Puññakkhayā vā”ti

analyzed: tesu pi asuññakappo pañcavidhaḥ hoti sārakappaḥ maṇḍakappaḥ varakappaḥ sāramaṇḍakappo  bhaddakappo ti tesu yasmin kappe ekaḥ va buddhaḥ uppajjati saḥ sārakappaḥ nāma yasmin  kappe dve buddhāḥ uppajjanti saḥ maṇḍakappaḥ nāma yasmin kappe tayaḥ uppajjanti saḥ

analyzed: kevalam panidhe otiṇṇa utiṇṇe udake ābhassara brahma lokam ādim katvā loka pātubhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: But here the appearance of the world should be understood beginning with the Brahmā-world of Streaming- radiance, which is the first to be reached by those beings who have come down here.

original: Subhakiṇhato cavitvā ābhassaraṭṭhānādīsu sattā nibbattanti etthāpi kappavināsakamahāmeghato
analyzed: subha kiṇhataḥ cavitvā ābhassara ṭṭhāna ādīsu sattāḥ nibbattanti ettha api kappa vināsaka mahā meghato
translated: When beings die in the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world and are reborn in the Brahmā-world of Streaming- radiance, etc., then here too the aeon of dissolution lasts for an incalculable, and the aeon of continuation for an incalculable, making two in all.🔽The aeon of creation is one incalculable.

original: yāva kappavināsakaudakaparicchedo saṃvaṭṭo nāma paṭhamamasaṅkhyeyyakappo nāmāti cattāriasaṅkhyeyyakappāni
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭaḥ nāma paṭhamam asaṅkhyeyya kappaḥ nāma ati cattāri asaṅkhyeyya kappāni
translated: So there are four incalculables.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.

original: vuttasadisāni evaṃ satta mahākappāni sattakkhattuṃ agginā vilīyitvā aṭṭhame mahākappe
analyzed: vutta sadisāni evam satta mahākappāni satta kkhattum agginā vilīyitvā aṭṭhame mahākappe
translated: After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.

original: udakenapi vināso ca saṇṭhahanañca veditabbaṃ, evaṃ sattasattamahākappo sattasattavāraṃ
analyzed: udakena api vināsaḥ ca saṇṭhahanam ca veditabbam evam satta satta mahākappo satta satta vāram
translated: And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.

original: agginā vilīyitvā aṭṭhame aṭṭhame vāre āpena vilīyitvā anukkamena tesaṭṭhimahākappāni
analyzed: agginā vilīyitvā aṭṭhame aṭṭhame vāre āpena vilīyitvā anukkamena tesaṭṭhi mahākappāni
translated: After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.🔽After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.🔽And the seven great aeons are of the same reckoning.

original: paripuṇṇāni tadā āpavāraṃ paṭibāhitvā catusaṭṭhime mahākappe vātena vinassati tadā
analyzed: paripuṇṇāni tadā āpavāram paṭibāhitvā catusaṭṭhime mahā kappe vātena vinassati tadā
translated: After the seven great aeons have thus been dissolved by fire, in the eighth great aeon the dissolution is by water.

original: ādito kappavināsakamahāvāto vuṭṭhahitvāti sabbaṃ pubbe vuttanayameva. Ayaṃ pana viseso
analyzed: āditas kappa vināsaka mahā vātaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā ti sabbam pubbe vutta nayam eva ayam pana viseso
translated: The great wind that destroys the world at the end of the aeon arises at the beginning. All the rest is as already stated. But there is this difference:

original: yathā agginā vināsakappe dutiyasūriyo, evamidhāpi kappavināsanatthaṃ vāto samuṭṭhāti
analyzed: yathā agginā vināsa kappe dutiya sūriyaḥ evam idha api kappa vināsana attham vātaḥ samuṭṭhāti
translated: Just as the second sun arises to destroy the world by fire, so the wind arises to destroy it by wind.

original: so paṭhamaṃ sukhumarajaṃ uṭṭhāpeti, tato thūlarajaṃ saṇharajaṃ sukhumavālikaṃ sakkharapāsāṇādayoti
analyzed: saḥ paṭhamam sukhuma rajam uṭṭhāpeti tatas thūla rajam saṇha rajam sukhuma vālikam sakkhara pāsāṇa ādayo ti
translated: It first raises up fine dust, then coarse dust, then sand, then gravel, then stones.

original: yāva kūṭāgāramatte pāsāṇepi visamaṭṭhāne ṭhitamahārukkheca uṭṭhāpeti, te pathavito
analyzed: yāva kūṭāgāra matte pāsāṇe pi visama ṭṭhāne ṭhita mahā rukkhe ca uṭṭhāpeti te pathavito
translated: It raises up even stones as big as a workshop, and even great trees standing on uneven ground. They rise up from the earth

original: nabhamuggatā na puna patanti, tattheva cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā abhāvaṃ gacchanti. Yathānukkamena🔽heṭṭhā mahāpathaviyā vāto samuṭṭhahitvā pathaviṃ parivattetvā uddhaṃmūlaṃ katvā ākāse
analyzed: nabha muggatāḥ na puna patanti tattha iva cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā abhāvam gacchanti yathā anukkamena  heṭṭhā mahā pathaviyāḥ vātaḥ samuṭṭhahitvā pathavim parivattetvā uddhaṃmūlam katvā ākāse
translated: and do not fall again but are smashed to smithereens and vanish in that very place.🔽In due course🔽the wind arises from the great earth below, turns the earth over, and hurls it into the air. Even places in the earth a hundred leagues wide

original: khipati yojanasatappamāṇāpi pathavippadesā dviyojanatiyojanacatuyojanapañcayojanachayojanasattayojanappamāṇāpi
analyzed: khipati yojana sata ppamāṇā api patha vippadesā dvi yojana ti yojana catu yojana pañca yojana cha yojana satta yojana ppamāṇā api
translated: are thrown up into the air two, three, four, five, six, seven leagues.

original: bhijjitvā te vegakkhittā ākāseyeva cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā abhāvaṃ gacchanti cakkavāḷapabbatampi
analyzed: bhijjitvā te vega khittāḥ ākāseya iva cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā abhāvam gacchanti cakkavāḷa pabbatam pi
translated: and they are smashed to smithereens and vanish into nothingness in the sky.

original: vāto ukkhipitvā ākāse khipati te aññamaññaṃ ghaṭṭayantā cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā vinassanti
analyzed: vātaḥ ukkhipitvā ākāse khipati te aññam aññam ghaṭṭayantā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā vinassanti
translated: The wind lifts up the world-sphere mountains and hurls them into space, where they collide and are smashed to smithereens and vanish into nothingness.🔽In the same way, it destroys the celestial palaces of the sense-sphere gods,

original: eteneva bhūmaṭṭhakavimānāni ākāsaṭṭhakavimānāni ca vināsento chakāmāvacaradevaloke🔽nāsetvā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷāni vināseti. Tattha cakkavāḷā cakkavāḷehi, himavantā
analyzed: etena iva bhūma ṭṭhaka vimānāni ākāsa ṭṭhaka vimānāni ca  nāsetvā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷāni vināseti tattha cakkavāḷā cakkavāḷehi himavantā
translated: and it destroys the divine worlds of the six sense-sphere heavens.

original: himavantehi, sinerū sinerūhi aññamaññaṃ samāgantvā cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā vinassanti.🔽Pathavito yāva parittasubhā, appamāṇasubhā, subhaṇiṇhāti tayopi tatiyajjhānabhūmī
analyzed: himavantehi sinerū sinerūhi aññamaññam samāgantvā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā vinassanti  pathavitaḥ yāva paritta subhā appamāṇa subhā tayo pi tatiya jhāna bhūmī
translated: Then the world-sphere mountains collide with one another, the Himalayas with the Himalayas, Sineru with Sineru, and they are smashed to smithereens and vanish into nothingness.🔽The wind takes hold of the earth as far down as the plane of access concentration of the third jhāna, the plane of the first and second jhānas, and the plane of the first jhāna, and it destroys the three divine worlds of the fine-material sphere, the Parittasubha, the Appamāṇasubha, and the Subhakiṇha, which are the planes of the third, fourth, and fifth jhānas respectively.

original: vāto gaṇhāti tattha tayopi brahmaloke vināsetvā vehapphalaṃ āhacca aṭṭhāsi. Evaṃ
analyzed: vātaḥ gaṇhāti tattha tayo api brahmaloke vināsetvā vehapphalam aṭṭhāsi evam
translated: Then it stops at the Vehapphala Brahma-world.

original: sabbaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ vināsetvā sayaṃ vinassati, heṭṭhā ākāsena saha upari ākāso eko
analyzed: sabbam saṅkhāra gatam vināsetvā sayam vinassati heṭṭhā ākāsena saha upari ākāsaḥ ekaḥ
translated: Thus it destroys all formations and then itself is destroyed. The space below it and the space above it become one.

original: hoti mahandhakāroti sabbaṃ vuttasadisaṃ. Idha pana subhakiṇhabrahmalokaṃ ādiṃ katvā
analyzed: hoti mahandhakāro ti sabbam vutta sadisam idha pana subha kiṇha brahmalokam ādim katvā
translated: “There is a great darkness” , all is as already stated. But here the world comes into being beginning with the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world.

original: loko pātubhavati. Vehapphalato cavitvā subhakiṇhādīsu sattā nibbattanti, tatthakappavinā
analyzed: loko pātubhavati vehapphalataḥ cavitvā subha kiṇha ādīsu sattā nibbattanti tatthakappavinā
translated: Beings are reborn in the Subhakiṇha and other worlds after they have died in the Vehapphala Brahma-world. The aeon’s dissolution

original: sakamahāmeghato yāva kappavināsakavātupacchedo, idaṃ saṃvaṭṭo nāma, paṭhamamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ
analyzed: saka mahā meghataḥ yāva kappa vināsaka vāta upacchedaḥ idam saṃvaṭṭaḥ nāma paṭhamam asaṅkhyeyyam
translated: lasts from the time of the great cloud that heralds the aeon’s dissolution up till the time of the final wind. This is called the “dissolution,” and it is the first incalculable.

original: nāmāti cattāri asaṅkhyeyyakappāni eko mahākappo nāmāti sabbaṃ tejosaṃvaṭṭe vuttanayameva.
analyzed: nāma ati cattāri asaṅkhyeyya kappāni ekaḥ mahākappaḥ nāma ati sabbam tejosaṃvaṭṭe vutta nayam eva
translated: Four incalculables make up one “great aeon” . All is as stated in the case of the fire- dissolution.

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam
translated: And this is said:

original: “Satta satta gginā vārā, aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā;
analyzed: satta satta gginā vārā aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā
translated: Seven times seven times seven, and once eight times,

original: Catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇā, eko vāyuvaro siyā.
analyzed: catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇāḥ ekaḥ vāyu varaḥ siyā
translated: When the sixty-four are full, there is one aeon of wind.

original: Agginā’bhassarā heṭṭhā, āpena subhakiṇhato;
analyzed: agginā abhassarā heṭṭhā āpena subha kiṇhataḥ
translated: Below the Brahmā-world by fire, and from the Subhakiṇha by water,

original: Vehapphalato vātena, evaṃ loko vinassatī”ti.
analyzed: vehapphalataḥ vātena evam lokaḥ vinassati iti
translated: From the Vehapphala by wind, so the world is destroyed.

original: Tasmā tiṇṇampi paṭhamajjhānatalānaṃ ekakappepi avināsābhāvato sakalakappe tesaṃ sambhavo
analyzed: tasmā tiṇṇam pi paṭhamajjhāna talānam eka kappe pi avināsa abhāvato sakala kappe tesam sambhavaḥ
translated: So since the three kinds of beings in the first-jhāna level do not all perish in one aeon, their existence extends over an entire great aeon.

original: natthīti asaṅkhyeyya kappavasena tesaṃ āyuparicchedo daṭṭhabbo. Dutiyajjhānatalato
analyzed: natthi iti asaṅkhyeyya kappa vasena tesam āyu paricchedo daṭṭhabbo dutiya jhāna talato
translated: “No” means that their life-span should be regarded as incalculable eons.

original: paṭṭhāya pana paripuṇṇamahākappavasena āyuparicchedo daṭṭhabbo, na asaṅkhyeyyakappavasena.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya pana paripuṇṇa mahākappa vasena āyu paricchedaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ na asaṅkhyeyya kappa vasena
translated: But from the second jhāna level onward it should be regarded as a life-span of a complete great eon, not an incalculable eon.

original: Yadi dutiyajjhānatalato paṭṭhāya paripuṇṇamahākappavasena āyuparicchedo siyā, kathaṃ
analyzed: yadi dutiya jhāna talataḥ paṭṭhāya paripuṇṇa mahākappa vasena āyu paricchedaḥ siyā katham
translated: If it is a complete great eon from the second jhāna level onward, how

original: ābhassarādīsu brahmūnaṃ aṭṭhamahākappādivasena āyu paripuṇṇaṃ siyā, tathā hi paṭhamajjhānatalaṃ🔽sattasu vāresu agginā vinassati. Aṭṭhame vāre yāva ābhassarā udakena vinassati puna
analyzed: ābhassara ādīsu āyu paripuṇṇam siyā tathā hi paṭhamajjhāna talam  sattasu vāresu agginā vinassati aṭṭhame vāre yāva ābhassarā udakena vinassati puna
translated: can the life-span of the Brahmās in the Ābhassara and other Brahmā worlds be complete for eight great eons, and so on?🔽For the first jhāna level is destroyed by fire seven times over.🔽Then in the eighth turn the Ābhassara Brahmā world is destroyed by water.

original: sattavāresu agginā paṭhamajjhānatalaṃ, puna aṭṭhamevāre udakena dutiyajjhānatalaṃ
analyzed: satta vāresu agginā paṭhama jhāna talam puna aṭṭhame vāre udakena dutiya jhāna talam
translated: Then the first jhāna level is destroyed by fire seven times over again, and then in the eighth turn the second jhāna level is destroyed by water.

original: vinassatīti evaṃ aṭṭhame vāre āpavāraṃ paṭibāhitvā yāva subhakiṇhā vātena vinassati
analyzed: vinassati iti evam aṭṭhame vāre āpavāram paṭibāhitvā yāva subha kiṇhā vātena vinassati
translated: Thus after the eighth turn has been completed, the Parittābha Brahmā world is destroyed by wind.

original: evaṃ catusaṭṭhi paripuṇṇā hotīti saccaṃ, heṭṭhāvivaṭṭaṭṭhāyī asaṅkhyeyyakappavasena
analyzed: evam catusaṭṭhi paripuṇṇā hoti iti saccam heṭṭhā vivaṭṭa ṭhāyī asaṅkhyeyya kappa vasena
translated: Thus sixty-four turns are completed.

original: eko satta mahākappāni cāti aṭṭha kappāni ābhassarabrahmūnaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ hoti. Catusaṭṭhikappesupi
analyzed: eko satta mahākappāni ca ati aṭṭha kappāni ābhassara brahmūnam āyu ppamāṇam hoti catusaṭṭhi kappesu pi
translated: and one great aeon, making eight aeons, is the life span of the Brahmā of Streaming Radiance.

original: vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīasaṅkhyeyyakappavasena eko te saṭṭhimahākappāni cāti catusaṭṭhikappāni
analyzed: vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī asaṅkhyeyya kappa vasena ekaḥ te saṭṭhi mahā kappāni ca ati catur aṭṭhi kappāni
translated: And in the case of the sixty-four aeons,

original: subhakiṇhānaṃ brahmūnaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ hoti tena vuttaṃ porāṇehi.
analyzed: subha kiṇhānam brahmūnam āyu ppamāṇam hoti tena vuttam porāṇehi
translated: making sixty-four great aeons, is the life span of the Subhakinna Brahmās. Hence it was said by the Ancients:

original: Satta satta’gginā vārā, aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā;
analyzed: satta sattagginā vārā aṭṭhame aṭṭhame dakā
translated: Seven times by fire, and by water The eighth, and by air,

original: Catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇā, eko vāyuvaro siyā’ti.
analyzed: catusaṭṭhi yadā puṇṇāḥ ekaḥ vāyu varaḥ siyāti
translated: When the sixty-four are complete, There is one aeon of wind.

original: Keci pana.
analyzed: keci pana
translated: But some say:

original: “Agginā’bhassarā heṭṭhā, āpena subhakiṇhato;
analyzed: agginā abhassarā heṭṭhā āpena subha kiṇhataḥ
translated: By fire below the Streaming Radiance, By water the Subhakinna,

original: Vehapphalato vātena, evaṃ loko vinassatī”ti.
analyzed: vehapphalataḥ vātena evam lokaḥ vinassati iti
translated: By air the Vehapphala— Thus the world is destroyed.

original: Imissā gāthāya “ābhassarāti”ca “subhakiṇhato”ti ca “vehapphalato”ti ca abhividhivasena
analyzed: imissā gāthāyaḥ ca ca abhividhi vasena
translated: In this stanza, the words “Streaming Radiance,” “Subhakinna,” and “Vehapphala” are stated🔽by way of a special method of exposition.

original: vuttabhāvañca samatalabhāvepi seṭṭhabhūmittā paṭṭhānavasena vuttabhāvañca amaññitvā
analyzed: vutta bhāvañca sama tala bhāve pi seṭṭha bhū mittā paṭṭhāna vasena vutta bhāvañca a maññitvā
translated: But without considering the fact that they are stated by way of a special method of exposition,🔽and that they are stated by way of a special method of exposition in order to show the superiority of the plane of the Abhassara Brahmās,

original: suddhāvāsabhūmīsu viya uparūparivasena bhūmikkamoti maññitvā.
analyzed: suddhāvāsa bhūmīsu viya upari upari vasena bhūmikkamaḥ ti maññitvā
translated: some people think that the order of the planes is according to the order of the upper and lower abodes, as in the case of the Suddhāvāsa planes.

original: “Pañcabhūmi naṭṭhā aggi, aṭṭha bhūmi naṭṭhā dakā;
analyzed: pañcabhūmi naṭṭhā aggi aṭṭha bhūmi naṭṭhā dakā
translated: “The fire destroyed five planes, the water destroyed eight planes,

original: Navabhūmi naṭṭhā vātā, lokanaṭṭhā tadā siyuṃ.
analyzed: naṭṭhāḥ vātāḥ loka naṭṭhā tadā siyuṃ
translated: The wind destroyed nine planes, and then the world was destroyed.

original: Paṭhame aggi dvattiṃsa, dutiye ādi soḷasa;
analyzed: paṭhame aggi dvattiṃsa dutiye ādi soḷasa
translated: In the first, the fire was thirty-two, in the second, the first sixteen,

original: Dutiyabhūme majjhe aṭṭhamaṃ, taṃ chappaññāsa vārakaṃ.
analyzed: dutiya bhūme majjhe aṭṭhamam tam chappaññāsa vārakam
translated: In the middle of the second plane, the eighth, that is fifty-three times.

original: Ābhassaramhi catutthaṃ, parittasubhamhi dve jalaṃ;
analyzed: catuttham paritta subhamhi dve jalam
translated: In the Ābhassara, the fourth, in the Parittasubha, two waters,

original: Appamāṇasubhaṃ ekavāraṃ, mataṃ udakasattama”nti.
analyzed: appamāṇa subham eka vāram matam
translated: The Appamāṇasubha once, the water is the seventh.”

original: Vadanti tesaṃ vāde ābhassarato heṭṭhā pañcabhūmi agginaṭṭhā, subhakiṇhato heṭṭhā
analyzed: vadanti tesam vāde ābhassarataḥ heṭṭhā pañcabhūmi subhakiṇhataḥ heṭṭhā
translated: They say that in their doctrine, below the Ābhassara, the fire destroyed five planes, below the Subhakiṇha,

original: aṭṭhabhūmi udakanaṭṭhāti vadanti. Samataladīpanatthaṃ sandehacchedanatthaṃ evaṃ gahitāti🔽ekabhavapariyosānaṃ sandhāya paṭisandhibhavañcāti ādi vuttanti. Imissāpi atthaṃ duggahitena
analyzed: aṭṭha bhūmi udakanaṭṭhā ti vadanti sama tala dīpana attham sandeha chedana attham evam gahitā iti  eka bhava pariyosānam sandhāya paṭisandhi bhavañca ati ādi vuttan ti imissā api attham duggahitena
translated: the water destroyed eight planes. They say. In order to illustrate the evenness and in order to resolve the doubt, it is taken thus.🔽With reference to the end of a single becoming and to rebirth-linking and the life-continuum, etc., are stated. By misapprehending the meaning of this,

original: gahetvā paṭisandhibhavaṅgavasena sadisabhāvameva sandhāya vuttanti parikappenti so
analyzed: gahetvā paṭisandhi bhavaṅga vasena sadisa bhāvam eva sandhāya vuttan ti parikappenti so
translated: they imagine that it is stated with reference to mere similarity in the rebirth-linking and life-continuum.

original: ayuttarūpo viya dissati ativiya micchāgāho ca hoti aggaññasuttavisuddhimaggādīhi🔽virujjhanato saṃvaṭṭasīmāpi viruddhā tattha paṭhamajjhānatalaṃ upādāya agginā, dutiyajjhānatalaṃ
analyzed: ayutta rūpaḥ viya dissati ati viya micchāgāho ca hoti aggañña sutta visuddhi magga ādīhi  virujjhanataḥ saṃvaṭṭa sīmā api viruddhā tattha paṭhama jhāna talam upādāya agginā dutiya jhāna talam
translated: and it appears as if it were not so, and it is a very wrong view, since it is contradicted by the Suttas such as the Aggan- ññasutta and the Visuddhimagga.

original: upādāya udakena, catutthajjhānatalaṃ upādāya vātena vinassatīti vuttavacanenāpi virujjhateva🔽tasmā “ābhassarā”ti ca “subhakiṇhato”ti ca “vehapphalato”ti ca etthābhividhivasena

analyzed: atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ aññathā upari pabbatā devaḥ vassati iti ettha viya ābhassara subha kiṇha vehapphalānam

original: 3. Nibbānakaṇḍo

translated: The Chapter on Nibbana

translated: for the True Idea is of three kinds, that is to say, the True Idea as the True Object, the True Idea as True Practice, and the True Idea as True Realization.🔽Herein, the True Idea as the True Object is the three Baskets of the Buddha’s Word.
