who attains the state of a stream-enterer in the human world

original: te bhavaṃ aṭṭhamamādiyantī”ti pāḷiyā virodhattā. Apica dvibhavaparicchinno sakadāgāmīpi
analyzed: te bhavam aṭṭhamam ādiyanti iti apica dvi bhava paricchinnaḥ
translated: because of the contradiction with the text. Moreover, the once-returner, who is limited to two kinds of becoming,

original: dvikkhattuṃ manussalokaṃ āgato bhaveyya, tassapi tattha ekaṃ, idha ekanti vārassa
analyzed: dvi kkhattum manussa lokam āgataḥ bhaveyya tassa api tattha ekam idha ekam ti vārassa
translated: would have to come to the human world twice, and it would be necessary to say that he has one birth in that world and one here,

original: labbhitabbato na panevaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sakiṃ imaṃ manussalokaṃ āgacchatīti sakadāgāmī🔽idha patvā idha parinibbāyī, tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyī, tattha patvā idha parinibbāyī,
analyzed: labbhitabbataḥ na pana evam daṭṭhabbam sakim imam manussa lokam āgacchati iti sakadāgāmī  idha patvā idha parinibbāyī tattha patvā tattha parinibbāyī tattha patvā idha parinibbāyī
translated: but that is not so. He is called a once-returner because he returns once to this human world.

original: idha patvā tattha parinibbāyīti pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu pañcamako idha adhippeto. Yadi
analyzed: idha patvā tattha parinibbāyi iti pañcasu sakadāgāmīsu pañcamakaḥ idha adhippetaḥ yadi
translated: The fifth of the five kinds of once-returners, namely, the one who “returns here and attains nibbāna here,” is intended here.

original: evaṃ idha patvā idha parinibbāyīti ādayo cattāro kathaṃ sakadāgāmīnāmāti. Te sakiṃ
analyzed: evam idha patvā idha parinibbāyī iti ādayo cattāro katham te sakim
translated: If that is so, how can the other four, namely, the one who “returns there and attains nibbāna there,” the one who “returns there and attains nibbāna here,” the one who “returns here and attains nibbāna there,” and the one who “returns here and attains nibbāna here,” be once-returners?

original: puna āgacchatīti vacanatthena sakadāgāmī nāma. Kāmataṇhāya sabbaso pahīnattā imaṃ
analyzed: punar āgacchati iti vacana atthena sakadāgāmī nāma kāma taṇhāya sabbaso pahīna ttā imaṃ
translated: They are called once-returners because of the meaning of the word sakadāgāmī, namely, “he comes back once.”

original: kāmadhātuṃ anāgacchatīti anāgāmī, niccaṃ brahmalokeyeva paṭisandhi vasena āgacchatīti
analyzed: kāmadhātum an āgacchati iti anāgāmī niccam brahma lokeya iva paṭisandhi vasena āgacchati iti
translated: The non-returner does not come back to this world of sensual pleasures because he has completely abandoned craving for sensual pleasures. He comes back by way of rebirth in the Brahmā-world alone.

original: adhippāyo. Jhānikassa evaṃ hotu, sukkhavipassakassa kathanti sopi jhānikova hutvā
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ jhānikassa evam hotu sukkha vipassakassa katham ti saḥ api jhānikaḥ eva hutvā
translated: This is the intention. Let it be so for one who has jhāna. But how is it for one who is a bare-insight worker? He too should be a jhana man.

original: gacchati tassa hi maggantare sīhabyagghādīhi hatassāpi lakkhaṇattayaṃ āropetvā jhāniko
analyzed: gacchati tassa hi magga antare sīha byaggha ādīhi hatassa api lakkhaṇa ttayam āropetvā jhānikaḥ
translated: The intention is this: “Let it be so for one who is a jhāyic contemplator; but what about one who is a bare-insight worker?” He goes on to say that “he too becomes a jhāyic contemplator and dies as such after establishing the three characteristics in the jhāna. ”

original: hutvāva maraṇaṃ hoti ayaṃ pana rūpārūpabhavena ekakkhattuparamo nāma. Sattakkhattuparamādayo
analyzed: maraṇam hoti ayam pana rūpa arūpa bhavena ekakkhattuparamaḥ nāma satta kkhattuparama ādayaḥ
translated: For he has the characteristic of one who is a jhāyic contemplator. This one is called “at most one-seeder” because of the single rebirth in the fine-material or immaterial kinds of becoming.

original: ariyā rūpārūpalokesu anekakkhattupaṭisandhikāpi brahmalokasāmaññena ekapaṭisandhikā
analyzed: ariyāḥ rūpa arūpa lokesu aneka kkhattu paṭisandhikā api brahmaloka sāmaññena eka paṭisandhikā
translated: Those called “at most seven-seeder” and the rest are noble persons who have had rebirths in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming in more than one place, but they are called “one-seeder” because of the similarity of rebirth in the Brahmā-world.

original: nāma honti. Arahā pana pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvā dakkhiṇaṃ arahattā puna bhavā bhinibbattiyārahābhāvātyādinā🔽vacanatthena arahā nāma. Sopi tividho jhānika sukkhavipassaka samasīsīvasena. Tattha
analyzed: nāma honti arahā pana pāpa karaṇe raha abhāvā arahattā puna bhavā bhinibbattiyā araha abhāva atyādinā  vacana atthena arahā nāma saḥ api tividhaḥ jhānika sukkha vipassaka samasīsī vasena tattha
translated: But the Arahant is called “one-seeder” in the sense of the verbal root a-ra-ha, “to be worthy,” because he is worthy of the highest offerings of the world with its deities, and because he is worthy of the requisites of robes, alms food, etc., and because he is worthy of the homage of all the world.🔽He too is of three kinds as a jhāyic contemplator, a bare-insight worker, and one who is neither.

original: jhāniko maggeneva āgato, so paṭisambhidāppatto nāma. Aparopi puthujjanasekkhasantāne
analyzed: jhānikaḥ maggena iva āgataḥ so paṭisambhidāppattaḥ nāma aparaḥ api puthujjana sekkha santāne
translated: Herein, the jhāyic contemplator is one who has arrived at the path by means of jhāna. He is called “one who has attained the analytical insights.” Another is one who has attained the analytical insights in the continuity of a worldling or trainer.

original: jhāniko hutvā jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā maggaṃ uppādeti, sopi jhānikova. Sukkhavipassako
analyzed: jhānikaḥ hutvā jhānam pādakam katvā maggam uppādeti saḥ api jhānikaḥ va sukkha vipassako
translated: He generates the path by making jhāna the basis for it. He too is called “one who has jhāna as head.”

original: pana kilesakkhayamattameva maggena saha anāgatajhānaṃ nāma natthi, taṃ pacchā parihāyatītipi
analyzed: pana kilesa khaya mattam eva maggena saha anāgata jhānam nāma natthi tam pacchā parihāyati iti pi
translated: But the bare insight worker has no jhāna called “head” in the future, they say, which is generated together with the path and which he will subsequently attain.

original: vadanti. Samasīsī pana tividho hoti iriyāpathasamasīsī, rogasamasīsī, jīvitasamasīsīti.
analyzed: vadanti samasīsī pana tividhaḥ hoti iriyāpatha samasīsī roga samasīsī jīvita samasīsī iti
translated: The “one of equal length of life” is of three kinds: one of equal length of life as regards posture, one of equal length of life as regards disease, and one of equal length of life as regards span of life.

original: Tattha yo ṭhānādīsu iriyāpathesu yeneva iriyapathena samannāgato hutvā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: tattha yaḥ ṭhāna ādīsu iriyāpathesu yena iva iriyapathena samannāgataḥ hutvā vipassanaṃ
translated: Herein, one who begins insight with any one of the postures, standing, sitting, etc.,

original: ārabhati, teneva iriyāpathena arahattaṃ patvā parinibbāyati ayaṃ iriyāpathasamasīsī🔽nāma. Yo pana ekaṃ rogaṃ patvā antoroge eva vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ patvā
analyzed: ārabhati tena iva iriyāpathena arahattam patvā parinibbāyati ayam iriyāpatha samasīsī  nāma yaḥ pana ekam rogam patvā antoroge eva vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā arahattam patvā
translated: and attains Arahantship with that same posture is called one of equal length of life as regards posture.🔽But one who begins insight when afflicted with any one of the diseases, and attains Arahantship with that same disease is called one of equal length of life as regards disease.🔽But one who begins insight with any one of the thirteen kinds of consciousness beginning with the supramundane consciousness and attains Arahantship with that same kind of consciousness is called one of equal length of life as regards span of life.

original: teneva rogena parinibbāyati ayaṃ rogasamasīsi nāma. Yo pana terasasu sīsesu kilesasīsaṃ
analyzed: tena iva rogena parinibbāyati ayam rogasamasīsi nāma yaḥ pana terasasu sīsesu kilesa sīsam
translated: Herein, the supramundane consciousness is the head of the defilements,

original: avijjaṃ arahattamaggo pariyādiyati, pavattisīsaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ cuticittaṃ pariyādiyati,
analyzed: avijjam arahatta maggo pariyādiyati pavatti sīsam jīvitindriyam cuti cittam pariyādiyati
translated: the Arahant path supersedes ignorance; the consciousness of death supersedes the life faculty.

original: ayaṃ jīvitasamasīsīnāma. Tattha terasa sīsāni katamāni terasa sīsāni. Palibodhasīsaṃ,
analyzed: ayam tattha terasa sīsāni katamāni terasa sīsāni palibodha sīsam
translated: Herein, what are the thirteen heads? The head of obstruction,

original: taṇhābandhanasīsaṃ, mānaparāmāsasīsaṃ, diṭṭhivikkhepasīsaṃ, uddhaccakilesasīsaṃ,
analyzed: taṇhā bandhana sīsam māna parāmāsa sīsam diṭṭhi vikkhepa sīsam uddhacca kilesa sīsam
translated: the head of the bonds of craving, the head of the conceit “I am,” the head of the distraction of views, the head of the defilement of agitation,

original: avijjāadhimokkhasīsaṃ, saddhāpaggahasīsaṃ, vīriyaupaṭṭhānasīsaṃ, satiavikkhepasīsaṃ,
analyzed: avijjā adhimokkha sīsam saddhā paggaha sīsam vīriya upaṭṭhāna sīsam sati avikkhepa sīsam
translated: the head of the concealment of ignorance, the head of the overestimation of faith, the head of the support of energy, the head of the distraction of mindfulness,

original: samādhidassanasīsaṃ, paññāpavattisīsaṃ, jīvitindriyagocarasīsaṃ, vimokkhasaṅkhārasīsanti.
analyzed: samādhi dassana sīsam paññā pavatti sīsam jīvitindriya gocara sīsam vimokkha saṅkhāra sīsanti
translated: the head of the seeing of concentration, the head of the occurrence of understanding, the head of the province of the life faculty, and the head of the formations of deliverance.

original: Ettha ca avijjā pariyādāyakaṃ maggacittaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ pariyādātuṃ sakkoti, jīvitapariyādāyakaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca avijjā pariyādāyakam magga cittam jīvita indriyam pariyādātum sakkoti jīvita pariyādāyakam
translated: And here the life faculty is able to obstruct the path consciousness that obstructs ignorance,

original: cuticittaṃ avijjaṃ pariyādātuṃ na sakkoti, avijjā pariyādāyakaṃ cittaṃ aññaṃ, jīvitindriyapariyādāyakaṃ
analyzed: cuti cittam avijjam pariyādātum na sakkoti avijjā pariyādāyakam cittam aññam jīvitindriya pariyādāyakam
translated: but the death consciousness that obstructs life is unable to obstruct ignorance. The consciousness that obstructs ignorance is one thing,

original: cittaṃ aññaṃ. Kathaṃ panidaṃ sīsaṃ samaṃ hotīti. Vārasamatāya, yasmiñhi vāre maggavuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: cittam aññam katham pana idam sīsam samam hoti iti vāra samatāya yasmin hi vāre magga vuṭṭhānam
translated: and the consciousness that obstructs the life faculty is another. But how is this a head? It is a head by virtue of the equality of the turn. For in the turn in which the path arises,

original: hoti, sotāpattimagge maggaphalanibbānapahīnasesakilesapaccavekkhaṇāvasena pañca paccavekkhaṇāni,🔽tathā sakadāmimagge pañca, anāgāmimagge pañca, arahattamagge sesakilesābhāvā cattārīti
analyzed: hoti sotāpatti magge magga phala nibbāna pahīna sesa kilesa paccavekkhaṇā vasena pañca paccavekkhaṇāni  tathā sakadāmi magge pañca anāgāmi magge pañca arahatta magge sesa kilesa abhāvā cattāri iti
translated: There are five kinds of reviewing in the case of the path of stream-entry, namely, reviewing of the defilements abandoned by the path of stream-entry, reviewing of the path, reviewing of fruition, reviewing of Nibbāna, and reviewing of the remaining aggregates.🔽Similarly there are five in the case of the path of once-return, five in the case of the path of non-return, and four in the case of the path of Arahantship, omitting the reviewing of the remaining aggregates since there are no more defilements remaining to be abandoned.

original: ekūnavīsatime paccavekkhaṇañāṇe patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅgaṃ otaritvā parinibbāyato imāya
analyzed: ekūnavīsatime paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇe patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅgam otaritvā parinibbāyato imāya
translated: So when one who has reached the nineteen reviewing knowledges enters upon the life of purity and attains Nibbāna,🔽this is called the exhaustion of both ends by the equality of moments.

original: vārasamatāya idaṃ ubhayasīsa pariyādānampi samaṃ hoti nāma. Arahattamagge ca pavattisīsaṃ🔽jīvitindriyaṃ pavattito vuṭṭhahanto maggo cutito uddhaṃ appavattikaraṇavasena yadipi
analyzed: vāra samatāya idam ubhaya sīsa pariyādānam pi samam hoti nāma arahatta magge ca pavatti sīsam  jīvitindriyam pavattitaḥ vuṭṭhahantaḥ maggo cutitaḥ uddham appavatti karaṇa vasena yadi api
translated: And in the case of the path of Arahantship, the life faculty is exhausted by the end of occurrence,🔽for although the path, in the sense of preventing any more occurrence after death, exhausts the life faculty,🔽nevertheless, as long as there is death, the life faculty, which is the essence of occurrence, is exhausted by the death consciousness,

original: pariyādiyati. Yāva pana cuti, tāva pavattisabhāvato pavattisīsaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ cuticittaṃ🔽pariyādiyati nāma. Kilesapariyādānena maggacittena attano anantaraṃ viya nipphādetabbā
analyzed: yāva pana cuti tāva pavatti sabhāvataḥ pavatti sīsam jīvitindriyam cuti cittam 🔽pariyādiyati nāma kilesa pariyādānena magga cittena attanaḥ anantaram viya nipphādetabbā
translated: which is what brings about the death.

original: paccavekkhaṇavārāva paripuṇṇā. Paripuṇṇavasena pahīnakilese paccavekkhaṇato kilesapariyādānasseva
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa vārā va paripuṇṇā paripuṇṇa vasena pahīna kilese paccavekkhaṇato kilesa pariyādānassa eva
translated: The section on reviewing is completed. As to the meaning of “completed”: the defilements that are given up by reviewing are completed.

original: vārāti vattabbataṃ arahanti, teneva kilesasīsaṃ avijjāpariyādānañca pavattisīsaṃ🔽jīvitindriyapariyādānañca samaṃ katvā imāya vārasamatāya kilesapariyādānaṃ jīvitapariyādānānaṃ🔽apubbacarimatā veditabbāti vuttaṃ. Saṃyuttaṭhakathāyaṃ pana yassa puggalassa apubbaṃ
analyzed: vārā ati vattabbatam arahanti tena iva kilesa sīsam avijjā pariyādānam ca pavatti sīsam  jīvita indriya pariyādānam ca samam katvā imāya vāra samatāya kilesa pariyādānam jīvita pariyādānānam  apubba carima tā veditabbā iti vuttam saṃyutta ṭhakathāyam pana yassa puggalassa apubbam
translated: The section on the exhaustion of defilements is fit to be called a section because it is a section on the exhaustion of defilements.🔽The exhaustion of ignorance is the head of the defilements, and the exhaustion of the life faculty is the head of the round.🔽The exhaustion of defilements is equal to the exhaustion of the life faculty in terms of the equality of the section.🔽It should be understood that the exhaustion of defilements is equal to the exhaustion of the life faculty in terms of the equality of the section.

original: acarimaṃ āsavapariyādānañca hoti jīvitapariyādānañca, ayaṃti puggalo samasīsī. Ettha
analyzed: acarimam āsava pariyādānam ca hoti jīvita pariyādānam ca ayam ti puggalo ettha
translated: But in the Connected Discourses Commentary it is said: “The person in whom the exhaustion of defilements and the exhaustion of the life faculty occur simultaneously is called ‘one with a level head.’🔽And here there are two heads: the head of the round and the head of the defilements.

original: ca pavattisīsaṃ kilesasīsanti dve sīsāni. Tattha pavattisīsaṃ nāma jīvitindriyaṃ.
analyzed: ca pavatti sīsam kilesa sīsanti dve sīsāni tattha pavatti sīsam nāma jīvitindriyam
translated: Herein, the head of the round is the life faculty,

original: Kilesasīsaṃ nāma avijjā. Tesu jīvitindriyaṃ cuticittaṃ khepeti. Avijjaṃ maggacittaṃ.
analyzed: kilesa sīsam nāma avijjā tesu jīvita indriyam cuti cittam khepeti avijjam magga cittam
translated: and the head of the defilements is ignorance. Of these, the life faculty is cut off by the death consciousness, and ignorance by the path consciousness.

original: Dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ ekato uppādo natthi. Maggānantaraṃ pana phalaṃ, phalānantaraṃ bhavaṅgaṃ,
analyzed: dvinnam cittānam ekatas uppādaḥ natthi magga anantaram pana phalam phala anantaram bhavaṅgam
translated: There is no arising of two consciousnesses together. But after the path there is fruition, and after fruition there is the life-continuum,

original: bhavaṅgato vuṭṭhāya paccavekkhaṇaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ hoti, taṃ aparipuṇṇaṃ vāti. Tikhiṇena
analyzed: bhavaṅgataḥ vuṭṭhāya paccavekkhaṇam paripuṇṇam hoti tam a paripuṇṇam vāti tikhiṇena
translated: and when it arises from the life-continuum the reviewing is complete, and it is incomplete when it does not. Even when a man is having his head cut off with a sharp sword,

original: asinā sīse chindantepi hi eko vā dve vā paccavekkhaṇavārā avassaṃ uppajjantiyeva,
analyzed: asinā sīse chindante pi hi ekaḥ vā dve vā paccavekkhaṇa vārāḥ avassam uppajjantiyā iva
translated: two or three impulsions of reviewing consciousness occur, it is said.

original: cittānaṃ pana lahuparivattitāya āsavakkhayo ca jīvitapariyādānañca ekakkhaṇe viya
analyzed: cittānam pana lahu parivatti tāya āsava kkhayaḥ ca jīvita pariyādānam ca eka khaṇe viya
translated: But because of the swift succession of consciousnesses, the exhaustion of taints and the end of the life process occur as though simultaneously,

original: sañjāyatī’ti vuttaṃ. Taṭṭīkāyañca “dvinnaṃ cittānanti cuticittamaggacittānaṃ. Tanti
analyzed: sañjāyati iti vuttam tad ṭīkāyan ca dvinnam cittānam ti cuti citta magga cittānam
translated: it is said. And in the commentary it is said, “Two consciousnesses: death consciousness and path consciousness. That:

original: paccayavekallaṃ. Paripuṇṇaṃ javanacittānaṃ sattakkhattuṃ pavattiyā. Aparipuṇṇaṃ pañcakkhattuṃ🔽pavattiyā. Kiñcāpi eko vā dve vā ti vuttaṃ, taṃ pana vacana siliṭṭhavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya vekallam paripuṇṇam javana cittānam satta kkhattum pavattiyā aparipuṇṇam pañca kkhattum  pavattiyā kiñcā api ekaḥ vā dve vā ti vuttam tam pana vacana siliṭṭha vasena vuttam
translated: the deficiency of conditions. Complete: by the occurrence of the seven impulsions of fruition consciousness. Incomplete: by the occurrence of the five impulsions.🔽Although it is said, ‘two or three,’ that is said according to the maximum.

original: Yāva ekaṃ vā dve vā tadārammaṇacittānīti heṭṭhimantena dve pavattantīti vadantī”ti
analyzed: yāvaḥ ekam vā dve vā tad ārammaṇa cittāni iti heṭṭhimantena dve pavattanti iti vadanti iti
translated: But they say that two occur at the most, according to the words, ‘One or two consciousnesses of the same kind do not arise with a single object’ . ”

original: vuttaṃ. Ettha ca “paripuṇṇaṃ javanacittānaṃ sattakkhattuṃ pavattiyā, aparipuṇṇaṃ🔽pañchakkhattuṃ pavattiyā”ti iminā aṭṭhakathāṭīkāvacanena samasīsīnaṃ paccavekkhaṇāvasena
analyzed: vuttam ettha ca paripuṇṇam javana cittānam satta kkhattum pavattiyā a paripuṇṇam  pañcha kkhattum pavattiyā ti iminā aṭṭhakathā ṭīkā vacanena samasīsīnam paccavekkhaṇā vasena
translated: This has been said. And here, by the words of the commentary and subcommentary, “When the seven impulsions of a complete thought-unit occur, it is complete;

original: maraṇāsannavīthiyaṃ paripuṇṇavasena sattakkhattuṃ, aparipuṇṇavasena pañcakkhattuṃ🔽kriyajavanāni javantīti sanniṭṭhānametthāva gantabbaṃ. “Asammūḷho kālaṃ karotī”ti
analyzed: maraṇa āsanna vīthiyam paripuṇṇa vasena satta kkhattum a paripuṇṇa vasena pañca kkhattum  kriya javanāni javanti iti sanniṭṭhānam ettha ava gantabbam a sammūḷhaḥ kālam karoti iti
translated: when the five impulsions of an incomplete thought-unit occur, it is incomplete,” it should be understood that the seven impulsions of a complete thought-unit occur in the death consciousness of one who is not confused,🔽and the five impulsions of an incomplete thought-unit occur in the death consciousness of one who is confused.

original: vuttattā ca viññāyati sattakkhattuṃ paripuṇṇavasena maraṇāsannakāle javanapavatti.
analyzed: vutta ttā ca viññāyati satta kkhattum paripuṇṇa vasena maraṇa āsanna kāle javana pavatti
translated: And since it is said that “he dies unconfused,” it is evident that the impulsions occur in the death consciousness of one who is not confused for seven thought-units.

original: Evañca sati “mandappavattiyaṃ pana maraṇakālādīsu pañcavāramevā”ti ettha “mandappavattiya”nti🔽visesanaṃ sātthakaṃ siyā. “Pañcavāramevā”ti ettha evakārena mandappavattikāle chasattakkhattuṃ
analyzed: evam ca sati pana maraṇa kāla ādīsu pañca vāram eva ati ettha manda ppavattiyan ti  visesanam sātthakam siyā pañca vāram evā ti ettha evakārena manda ppavatti kāle cha satta kkhattum
translated: And when that is so, then the qualification “in the case of slow occurrence” in the passage, “In the case of slow occurrence, however, only five times at the time of death, etc.,”

original: nivatteti. Asammūḷhakāle pana chasattakkhattumpi anujānāti. Kāmāvacarajavanānañca
analyzed: nivatteti a sammūḍha kāle pana cha satta kkhattum pi anujānāti
translated: has a purpose. And the word “only” in the passage, “only five times” excludes more than five and six times in the case of slow occurrence. But in the case of one who is not confused it allows six or seven times.🔽And the impulsions of the sense sphere

original: aniyataparimāṇā balavakālepi parisampuṇṇabhāvā tathā hi “kāmāvacarajavanānibalavakāle
analyzed: aniyata parimāṇā balava kāle api parisampuṇṇa bhāvā tathā hi
translated: and the number of impulsions is not fixed. For at the time of the strong occurrence of the sense-sphere impulsions,

original: sattakkhattuṃ chakkhattuṃ vā, mandappavattiyaṃ pana maraṇakālādīsu pañcavārameva.
analyzed: satta kkhattum cha khattum vā manda ppavattiyam pana maraṇa kāla ādīsu pañca vāram eva
translated: there are seven or six impulsions, but at the time of the weak occurrence, such as at the moment of death, there are only five.

original: Bhagavato yamakapāṭihāriyakālādīsu lahukappavattiyaṃ cattāri pañcavā paccavekkhaṇajavanacittāni
analyzed: bhagavataḥ yamaka pāṭihāriya kāla ādīsu cattāri paccavekkhaṇa javana cittāni
translated: At the time of the Blessed One’s Twin Marvel, etc., when the occurrence is quick, there are four or five reflex-impulsions.

original: bhavantī”ti aniyamitappamāṇavasena uppattibhāvo āgato imasmiṃ samasīsiniddesavārepi🔽maraṇāsannavīthicittassa visuṃ alabbhanato paccavekkhaṇanteyeva bhavaṅgacittena parinibbānato
analyzed: bhavanti iti aniyamita pamāṇa vasena uppatti bhāvaḥ āgataḥ imasmin samasīsiniddesa vāre pi  maraṇa āsanna vīthi cittassa visum a labbhanato bhavaṅga cittena parinibbānato
translated: So the arising is not fixed in respect of the number of impulsions. In this section on the definition of the mind’s end of the thought unit,🔽since the consciousness in the cognitive series at the moment of death is not separately mentioned, it is to be understood that there are seven impulsions in full number,

original: paripuṇṇavasena satta javanacittāni pāṭikaṅkhitabbānīti amhākaṃ khanti vīmaṃsitvā
analyzed: paripuṇṇa vasena satta javana cittāni pāṭikaṅkhitabbāni iti amhākam khanti vīmaṃsitvā
translated: because of the occurrence of the life-continuum consciousness at the end of the reflex-impulsions and because of the Blessed One’s attainment of Nibbāna.🔽This is our opinion. It should be accepted after consideration.

original: gahetabbo ito yuttataro vā pakāro labbhamāno gavesitabbo. Evaṃ paramatthasaṅghavasena
analyzed: gahetabbaḥ itas yuttataraḥ vā pakāraḥ labbhamānaḥ gavesitabbaḥ evam paramattha saṅgha vasena
translated: Or some other more suitable method should be sought. This is the method according to the ultimate sense of the Community.

original: cattāri purisayugāni, aṭṭha purisapuggalā, cattālīsampipuggalā aṭṭhasatampi purisapuggalāti
analyzed: cattāri purisa yugāni aṭṭha purisa puggalā cattālīsam pi puggalā aṭṭhasatam pi purisa puggalā ati
translated: forty persons, and eight hundred persons:🔽all these, when they are gathered together,🔽are called the Saṅgha in the world.

original: sabbaṃ samodhānetvā imasmiṃ loke saṅghopi dullabhoti veditabbo tathā hi ariyapuggalā
analyzed: sabbam samodhānetvā imasmin loke saṅghaḥ api dullabhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ tathā hi ariya puggalā
translated: The Saṅgha is hard to find in the world,🔽for the noble persons are very hard to find.🔽Even during the time that the Dispensation exists,🔽stream-enterers are not found everywhere.

original: atidullabhāva sāsanassa vijjamānakālepi idāni sotāpannassāpi avijjamānato ayaṃ paramatthasaṅghavicāraṇā.
analyzed: sāsanassa vijjamāna kāle api idāni sotāpannassa api a vijjamānataḥ ayam paramattha saṅgha vicāraṇā
translated: This is the consideration of the ultimate Saṅgha.

original: Sammutisaṅgho pana ñatticatutthena upasampanno puthujjanasaṅghova, sopi dullabhoyeva.
analyzed: sammuti saṅgho pana ñatti catutthena upasampannaḥ puthujjana saṅghaḥ uva saḥ pi dullabhaḥ yā iva
translated: But the conventional Saṅgha, which consists of ordinary persons who have been ordained by means of a proclamation repeated three times, is also hard to find.🔽For it is found only when a Buddha has arisen.

original: Kasmā buddhuppādakāleyeva labbhanato tathā hi anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhānaṃ satasahassādigaṇane🔽uppajjamānepi tesaṃ santike upasampadābhāvassa alabbhamānato paccekabuddhānañhi santike
analyzed: kasmā buddha uppāda kāleya iva labbhanato tathā hi anuppanne buddhe paccekabuddhānam sata sahassa ādi gaṇane  uppajjamāne pi tesam santike upasampadā bhāvassa a labbhamānataḥ paccekabuddhānam hi santike
translated: For even though hundreds of thousands of paccekabuddhas arise when a Buddha has not arisen,🔽they cannot be found in the Saṅgha,

original: pabbajitānaṃ kulaputtānaṃ saraṇagamanakammaṭṭhānassāpi dātuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā. Paccekabuddhā
analyzed: pabbajitānam kula puttānam saraṇa gamana kammaṭṭhānassa api dātum a sakkuṇeyya ttā paccekabuddhāḥ
translated: because those clansmen who have gone forth in their presence cannot be taught the refuges and the meditation subject.

original: ca nāma mūgassa supinadassanaṃ viya attanā paṭiladdhasaccadhamme paresaṃ ācikkhituṃ🔽na sakkonti, tasmā te pabbājetvā kammaṭṭhāne niyojetuṃ asamatthā “evaṃ te nivāsetabbaṃ,
analyzed: ca nāma mūgassa supina dassanam viya attanā paṭiladdha sacca dhamme paresam ācikkhitum  na sakkonti tasmai te pabbājetvā kammaṭṭhāne niyojetum asamatthāḥ evam te nivāsetabbam
translated: and they were unable to teach others the True Idea which they themselves had attained,

original: evaṃ te pārupitabba”nti ādinānayena abhisamācārikameva sikkhāpesuṃ tasmā buddhuppādakāleyeva
analyzed: evam te pārupitabbam ti ādinā anayena abhisamācārikam eva sikkhāpesum tasmā buddhuppāda kāleya iva
translated: like the dream of a dumb man. Therefore they were unable to give them the Going-forth and to set them to work on meditation subjects. They only taught them the training in the higher virtue, saying, “You should dress like this, you should eat like this,” and so on. That is why

original: sammutisaṅgho labbhati. Apica na te dullabhāyeva honti, atha kho tasmiṃ uddissa appamattakassāpi
analyzed: sammuti saṅghaḥ labbhati apica na te dullabhāya iva honti atha kho tasmin uddissa appamattakassa api
translated: the conventional Sangha is available only at the time of the arising of a Buddha. Besides, it is not only that it is not hard to find,

original: katākārassa asaṅkhyeyyaphalāpi honti vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā “bhavissanti kho panānanda
analyzed: kata ākārassa asaṅkhyeyya phalā api honti vuttam ha etam bhagavatā bhavissanti kho pana ānanda
translated: but also that it is of incalculable fruit even when the act of giving is done with reference to it and with only a little of the right manner. This is said by the Blessed One: “There will be, Ānanda,

original: anāgatamaddhānaṃ gotrabhuno kāsāvakaṇṭhā dussīlā pāpadhammā tesu dussīlesu saṅghaṃ
analyzed: anāgata maddhānam gotrabhuno kāsāvakaṇṭhā dussīlā pāpa dhammā tesu dussīlesu saṅghaṃ
translated: in the future, clansmen with shaven heads and wearing the yellow robe who are unvirtuous, of evil character. To those unvirtuous ones, Ānanda,

original: uddissa dānaṃ dassanti, tadā pāhaṃ ānanda saṅghagataṃ dakkhiṇaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ appameyyaṃ
analyzed: uddissa dānam dassanti tadā pāham ānanda saṅgha gatam dakkhiṇam asaṅkhyeyyam appameyyam
translated: a gift given with reference to the Sangha will be of great fruit” .

original: vadāmi na tvevāhaṃ ānanda kenaci pariyāyena saṅghagatā dakkhiṇā pāṭipuggalikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: vadāmi na tu eva aham ānanda kenacid pariyāyena saṅgha gatā dakkhiṇā pāṭipuggalikam dakkhiṇam
translated: I say that in no way can a gift to the Community be equal to a gift to a person.🔽I say that a gift to a person is more fruitful than a gift to the Community.”

original: mahapphalanti vadāmī”ti. Tathā hi uparipaṇṇāsake dakkhiṇavibhaṅgavaṇṇanāyaṃ “kāsāvakaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: mahapphalanti vadāmi iti tathā hi upari paṇṇāsake dakkhiṇa vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā ayam kāsāvakaṇṭhānam
translated: For in the explanation of the distribution of gifts in the last section of the Great Forty, it is said:

original: saṅghe dinne dakkhiṇāpi guṇāsaṅkhyāya asaṅkhyeyyā”ti vuttaṃ. Saṅghagatadakkhiṇā hi🔽saṅghe cittīkāraṃ kātuṃ sakkontassa hoti. Saṅghe pana cittīkāro dukkaro yo hi “saṅghagataṃ
analyzed: saṅghe dinne dakkhiṇā api guṇa asaṅkhyāya asaṅkhyeyyā ti vuttam saṅgha gata dakkhiṇā hi  saṅghe cittīkāram kātum sakkontassa hoti saṅghe pana cittīkāraḥ dukkaraḥ yaḥ hi saṅgha gatam
translated: “When a gift is given to the Community, the merit is incalculable because of the incalculable number of special qualities in the Community.”🔽For a gift to the Community is for one who is able to arouse reverence for the Community.

original: dakkhiṇaṃ dassāmī”ti deyyadhammaṃ paṭiyādetvā vihāraṃ gantvā bhante saṅghaṃ uddissa
analyzed: dakkhiṇam dassāmi iti deyya dhammam paṭiyādetvā vihāram gantvā bhante saṅgham uddissa
translated: But it is difficult to arouse reverence for the Community. If someone thinks, “I shall give a gift to the Community,” and he prepares a gift and goes to the monastery and says, “Venerable sirs, give this to the Community,”

original: ekaṃ theraṃ dethā’ti vadati, atha saṅghato sāmaṇeraṃ labhitvā “sāmaṇero me laddho”ti🔽aññathattaṃ āpajjati, tassa dakkhiṇā saṅghagatā na hoti. Mahātheraṃ labhitvā pi “mahāthero
analyzed: ekam theram detha iti vadati atha saṅghataḥ sāmaṇeram labhitvā sāmaṇeraḥ me laddhā uti  aññathattam āpajjati tassa dakkhiṇā saṅgha gatā na hoti mahā theram labhitvā pi mahā thero
translated: and if the Community gives a novice to him, thinking he is worthy of it, and he is disappointed, thinking, “I have got a novice,”🔽then his gift is not given to the Community. And if he gets an elder, thinking he is worthy of it, and he is pleased, thinking, “I have got a great elder,”

original: me laddho”ti somanassaṃ uppādentassāpi na hotiyeva. Tassa dakkhiṇā saṅghagatā na
analyzed: me laddhaḥ ti somanassam uppādentassa api na tassa dakkhiṇā saṅgha gatā na
translated: then his gift is not given to the Community either.

original: hoti. Yo pana sāmaṇeraṃ upasampannaṃ vā daharaṃ vā theraṃ vā bālaṃ vā paṇḍitaṃ vā
analyzed: hoti yaḥ pana sāmaṇeram upasampannam vā daharam vā theram vā bālam vā paṇḍitam vā
translated: But if anyone, having received something from the Sangha, whether a novice or a fully ordained monk, whether young or old, whether ignorant or learned,

original: yaṃkiñci saṅghato labhitvā nibbematiko hutvā “saṅghassa dammī”ti saṅghe cittīkāraṃ
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci saṅghataḥ labhitvā nibbematikaḥ hutvā saṅghassa dammi iti saṅghe cittīkāram
translated: and being free from doubt, is able to make a mental dedication to the Sangha, saying, “I give this to the Sangha,”

original: kātuṃ sakkoti, tassa dakkhiṇā saṅghagatā nāma hoti. Parasamuddavāsino kira evaṃ karonti
analyzed: kātum sakkoti tassa dakkhiṇā saṅgha gatā nāma hoti para samudda vāsinaḥ kira evam karonti
translated: then that offering is called “given to the Sangha”. They do this, it seems, in the countries beyond the ocean.

original: tattha hi eko vihārassāmikuṭumbiko “saṅghagataṃ dakkhiṇaṃ dassāmī”ti saṅghato uddisitvā
analyzed: tattha hi ekaḥ vihāra ssāmikuṭumbiko saṅgha gatam dakkhiṇam dassāmi iti saṅghataḥ uddisitvā
translated: For there a certain householder who was the owner of a dwelling, thinking, “I will give an offering given to the Sangha,” had a monk appointed from the Sangha

original: “ekaṃ bhikkhuṃ dethā”ti yācitvā so ekaṃ dussīlabhikkhuṃ labhitvā nisīdanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ekam bhikkhum detha iti yācitvā saḥ ekam dussīla bhikkhum labhitvā nisīdana ṭṭhānam
translated: and asked, “Give me a monk.” He got an immoral monk. He had a seat prepared in a place for sitting,

original: opuñjāpetvā āsanaṃ paññapetvā upari vitānaṃ bandhitvā gandhadhūmapupphehi pūjetvā
analyzed: opuñjāpetvā āsanam paññapetvā upari vitānam bandhitvā gandha dhūma pupphehi pūjetvā
translated: had a canopy stretched out above, made offerings of incense, lights, and flowers,

original: pāde dhovitvā makkhetvā buddhassa nipaccakāraṃ karonto viya saṅghe cittīkārena deyyadhammaṃ
analyzed: pāde dhovitvā makkhetvā buddhassa nipaccakāram karontaḥ viya saṅghe cittīkārena deyya dhammam
translated: and made an offering of requisites to the Sangha by way of a mental dedication, as if he were doing it out of respect for the Buddha.

original: adāsi so bhikkhu pacchābhattaṃ vihāraṃ jagganatthāya “kudālakaṃ dethā”ti gharadvāraṃ
analyzed: adāsi so bhikkhu pacchābhattam vihāram jaggana atthāya kudālakam detha ati ghara dvāram
translated: That monk went to the householder’s door after the meal, saying, “Give me a bowl.”

original: āgato upāsako nisinnova kudālaṃ pādena khipitvā “gaṇhā”ti adāsi tamenaṃ manussā āhaṃsu
analyzed: āgataḥ upāsakaḥ nisinnaḥ iva kudālam pādena khipitvā gaṇhāti adāsi tam enam manussāḥ āhaṃsu
translated: The lay follower came and, without even sitting down, kicked the spade with his foot and said, “Take it.” People said to him,

original: “tumhehi pātova etassa katasakkāro vattuṃ na sakkā, idāni apacayamattakampi natthi,
analyzed: tumhehi pātova etassa kata sakkāraḥ vattum na sakkā idāni apacaya mattakam pi natthi
translated: “You cannot say that you have done him a service from the very beginning. Now there is not even a little left to decay.

original: kiṃ nāmeta”nti. Upāsako “saṅghassa so ayyo cittīkāro, na etassā”ti āha. Kāsāvakaṇṭhasaṅghadinnadakkhiṇaṃ
analyzed: kim nāma etat ti upāsako saṅghassa so ayyo cittīkāraḥ na etassa ati āha kāsāva kaṇṭha saṅgha dinna dakkhiṇam
translated: What is it?” The lay follower said, “That was a service to the Community, not to him.”

original: pana ko sodheti, sāriputtamoggalānādayo asītimahātherā sodhenti api ca therā ciraparinibbutā,
analyzed: pana kaḥ sodheti sāriputta moggalāna ādayaḥ asīti mahā therā sodhenti api ca therā cira parinibbutā
translated: But who is there to purify the offering made to the Community with its throat yellow ? The great elders Sāriputta, Moggallāna, and the rest purify it. But the elders have long since attained final Nibbāna.

original: there ādiṃ katvā yāvajjatanā dharamānakhīṇāsavā sodhentiyeva, tathā hi dāyakato paṭiggāhatopi🔽mahapphalaṃ hoti dānaṃ. Dāyakato vessantarajātakaṃ kathetabbaṃ vessantaro hi dussīlassa
analyzed: there ādim katvā yāvajjatanāḥ dharamāna khīṇa āsavā tathā hi dāyakataḥ paṭiggāhato pi  mahapphalam hoti dānam dāyakataḥ vessantara jātakam kathetabbam vessantaraḥ hi dussīlassa
translated: Beginning with the elders, all those who have reached the destruction of the taints and are still living, purify it. For thus it is said:🔽“The gift is fruitful for the giver according to the recipient, if he is worthy or unworthy” . The story of Vessantara should be told here. For Vessantara, by giving two fawn-skin quivers worth the price of a kingdom to the unrighteous brahmin Jujaka, caused the earth to quake.

original: jūjakābrāhmaṇassa nayanasadise dve jālīkaṇhājine putte datvā pathaviṃ kampesi. Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: jūjakā brāhmaṇassa nayana sadise dve jālī kaṇha ajine putte da tvā pathavim kampesi sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: The knowledge of omniscience

original: ārabbha pavattacetanāya mahantabhāvena pathaviṃ kampesi. Evaṃ dāyakatopi mahapphalaṃ
analyzed: ārabbha pavatta cetanāya mahanta bhāvena pathavim kampesi evam dāyaka to pi mahapphalam
translated: and he shook the earth through the greatness of the thought that arose in him. So it is fruitful for the giver too.

original: hoti. Paṭiggāhakato pana sāriputtattherassa dinnacoraghātakavatthu kathetabbaṃ coraghātako
analyzed: hoti paṭiggāhakataḥ pana sāriputta therassa dinna cora ghātaka vatthu kathetabbam cora ghātako
translated: But as regards the receiver, the story of the gift to the Elder Sāriputta of the murderer of a robber should be told.

original: nāma hi sāvatthiyaṃ eko janapadapuriso pañcavīsati vassāni coraghātakakammaṃ katvā
analyzed: nāma hi sāvatthiyam ekaḥ janapada purisaḥ pañcavīsati vassāni cora ghātaka kammam katvā
translated: For a certain man of the provinces, it seems, had been a murderer of robbers for twenty-five years at Sāvatthi.

original: mahallakakālepi tiṃsa vassāni nāsikavāteneva kaṇṇanāsādīni chinditvā coraghātakakammaṃ
analyzed: mahallaka kāle pi tiṃsa vassāni nāsika vātena iva kaṇṇa nāsā ādīni chinditvā cora ghātaka kammam
translated: And when he was an old man he had been doing the same work for thirty years, cutting off the ears, nose, etc., of robbers with a knife.

original: karontasseva pañcapaññāsa vassāni vītivattāni. So maraṇa mañce nipannova attano kammabalena
analyzed: karontassa iva pañca paññāsa vassāni vītivattāni saḥ maraṇa mañce nipannaḥ uva attano kamma balena
translated: Fifty-five years had passed while he was doing this work.

original: mahāniraye nibbatto viya mahāsaddaṃ katvā dukkhito hoti, tassa saddena bhītā manussā🔽ubhato passe gehaṃ chaḍḍetvā palāyiṃsu. Tadā sāriputtatthero dibbacakkhu nā lokaṃ
analyzed: mahāniraye nibbattaḥ viya mahā saddam katvā dukkhitaḥ hoti tassa saddena bhītāḥ manussā  ubhatas passe geham chaḍḍetvā palāyiṃsu tadā sāriputta thero dibba cakkhu nā lokaṃ
translated: When he lay on his deathbed, he was as though reborn in the Great Hell through the force of his kamma. He was miserable, making a great noise,🔽and the people were frightened by the noise and abandoned their houses on both sides and fled.

original: volokento taṃ disvā tassa anukampaṃ paṭicca tassa gehadvāre aṭṭhāsi. So kujjhitvā
analyzed: volokento tam disvā tassa anukampam paṭicca tassa geha dvāre aṭṭhāsi so kujjhitvā
translated: Then the Elder Sāriputta, who was looking over the world with his mind’s eye, saw him. Out of compassion for him he stood at the door of his house.🔽The man, who was still making a great noise, became angry and said,

original: tikkhattuṃ nāsikavātena vissajjamānopi vissajjituṃ asakkonto ativirocamānaṃ theraṃ🔽disvā ativiya pasīditvā attano atthāya sampāditaṃ pāyāsaṃ adāsi. Theropi maṅgalaṃ
analyzed: tikkhattum nāsika vātena vissajjamānaḥ api vissajjitum a sakkontaḥ ativirocamānam theram  disvā ativiya pasīditvā attanaḥ atthāya sampāditam pāyāsam adāsi theraḥ api maṅgalaṃ
translated: and he could not blow his nose.

original: vaḍḍhetvā pakkami. Coraghātako therassa dinnadānaṃ anussaritvā sagge nibbatti, evaṃ🔽paṭiggāhakatopi mahapphalaṃ hoti. Ubhayatopi mahapphalaṃ, anāthapiṇḍikavisākhādayo
analyzed: vaḍḍhetvā pakkami cora ghātakaḥ therassa dinna dānam anussaritvā sagge nibbatti evam  paṭiggāhakataḥ upi mahat phalam hoti ubhayatas pi mahat phalam anāthapiṇḍika visākha ādayo
translated: Seeing the Elder shining with splendor, he was confirmed in faith. He gave the milk-rice he had prepared for himself to the Elder. The Elder increased the merit of the giver by pronouncing a blessing and departed. The robber- executioner, recollecting the gift he had made to the Elder, was reborn in a happy destination.🔽Thus it is fruitful for the receiver.

original: buddhappamukhassa dinnadānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: buddha ppamukhassa dinna dānam veditabbam
translated: It is fruitful for both. The gift given to the Buddha and the Community headed by the Buddha by Anathapindika, Visakha, and others, should be understood as fruitful for both.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā.🔽“Tathāgate ca sambuddhe, athavā tassa sāvake;
analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā  tathāgate ca sambuddhe athavā tassa sāvake
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

translated: “When one has confidence in the Buddha, the Enlightened One, Or in his disciple, then any offering, however small, Is not of trifling fruit.

analyzed: acintiye pasannānam vipākaḥ hoti acintiya uti
translated: Thus the Buddhas are inconceivable, The Buddha-Dhamma is inconceivable, The fruit of confidence is inconceivable For those who have confidence in the inconceivable.”🔽Thus the fruitfulness should be understood as twofold.

original: Evaṃ ubhayavasena mahapphalabhāvo veditabbo. Dāyakatopi paṭiggāhakatopi nipphalameva.
analyzed: evam ubhaya vasena mahat phala bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ dāyakataḥ api paṭiggāhakataḥ api nipphalam eva
translated: It is fruitless for both the giver and the receiver.

translated: May eat his fill of food;🔽He does not equal one-sixteenth

translated: Of one who practises this Dhamma.”

translated: That is why the Blessed One said, “There are these four kinds of purification of offering” . These three, namely, the Enlightened One, the True Idea, and the Community, are called “jewels” because they are the delight of the good.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ.

translated: Hard to find, and fit for worship,

analyzed: maṇi ratanam yam vā pana aññam pi anindriya baddha suvaṇṇa rajata ādi sa viññāṇakam hatthi assa ratana ādi pariṇāyaka ratana pariyosānam
translated: And a “jewel” is of two kinds, that is to say, animate and inanimate. original: ādi vacanato pana sammāsambuddhoyeva sabbākārasampanno kalyāṇamitto nāma. Taṃ alabhantena🔽sāriputtamoggalānādayo ariyapuggalā vā. Tepi alabhantena ekantajahitaṃ sivaṭṭhikaṃ🔽kalyāṇamittaṃ labhitabbaṃ, vuttañhetaṃ porāṇehi.🔽“Piyo garu bhāvanīyo, vattā ca vacanakkhamo;
analyzed: ādi vacanato pana sammāsambuddhaḥ yeva sabba ākāra sampanno kalyāṇamittaḥ nāma tam a labhantena  ariya puggalāḥ vā te pi a labhantena ekanta jahitam sivaṭṭhikam  kalyāṇa mittam labhitabbam vuttam ha etam porāṇehi  piyaḥ garu bhāvanīyaḥ vattā ca vacana kkhamaḥ
translated: Now the turn has come for the commentary on “Good men are hard to find in the world” . For good men are indeed very hard to find in the world. Good men are men of noble qualities, excellent men. Beings subject to birth are freed from birth, and beings subject to death are freed from death, by depending on them. For this is said by the Blessed One: “Ānanda, by coming to good men beings subject to birth are freed from birth, beings subject to ageing are freed from ageing, beings subject to death are freed from death” . And it is the Fully Enlightened One who is endowed with all noble qualities that is called “a good man” in all ways. If he cannot be found, then one of the noble persons such as Sāriputta or Moggallāna should be sought. If they cannot be found, then one should seek a good man who has abandoned the defilements completely, as it is said by the ancients: “Dear, respected, worthy of being heeded, A speaker, and one who can be spoken to,

translated: It is not easy to count it thus: ‘So many years, so many hundreds of years, so many thousands of years, so many hundreds of thousands of years.’ But a simile I shall give you for the matter.

original: “Sakkā bhikkhū”ti bhagavā avoca. Seyyathāpi bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho
analyzed: sakkā bhikkhū iti bhagavā avoca seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsatikhārikaḥ kosalakaḥ tila vāho
translated: “‘Yes, venerable sir,’ the monk replied. The Blessed One said this: “Suppose, monk, there was a Kosalan cartload of twenty measures of sesamum seed.

original: hoti, tato puriso vassasatassa vassasahassassa accayena ekamekaṃ tilaṃ uddhareyya,🔽khippataraṃ kho so bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ🔽pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva eko abbudo nirayo. Seyyathāpi bhikkhu vīsa abbudo
analyzed: hoti tatas purisaḥ vassa satassa vassa sahassassa accayena ekam ekam tilam uddhareyya  khippataram kho saḥ bhikkhu vīsati khārikaḥ kosalakaḥ tila vāhaḥ iminā upakkamena parikkhayam  pariyādānam gaccheyya na tu eva ekaḥ abbudaḥ nirayaḥ seyyathā api bhikkhu vīsa abbudaḥ
translated: and if a man were to remove one grain of rice every hundred or a hundred years,

original: nirayo, evameko nirabbudo nirayo”ti ādi. Vīsatikhāriko ti māgadhikena patthena cattāro🔽patthā kosalaraṭṭhe eko pattho hoti. Tena patthena cattāro patthā āḷhakaṃ. Cattāri
analyzed: nirayaḥ evam ekaḥ nirabbudaḥ nirayaḥ ti ādi vīsatikhāriko ti māgadhikena patthena cattāro  patthā kosala raṭṭhe ekaḥ patthaḥ hoti tena patthena cattāro patthāḥ āḷhakam cattāri
translated: that heap of grain would be sooner exhausted than the suffering of one single hell-state of Avīci. Just as there are twenty hell-states of Abbuda, so there is one hell-state of Nirabbuda.”🔽A “twenty-khārī heap of sesame” is four khārīs in Magadha measure,

original: āḷhakāni doṇaṃ. Catudoṇā mānikā. Catumānikā khārī. Tāyakhāriyā vīsatikhāriko tilavāho.🔽Tilavāhoti tilasakaṭaṃ. Abbudo nirayoti abbudo nāma eko paccekanirayo natthi, avīcimhi
analyzed: āḷhakāni doṇam catudoṇā mānikā catumānikā khārī tāyakhāriyā vīsatikhārikaḥ tilavāhaḥ  tilavāho ti tila sakaṭam abbudaḥ nirayo ti abbudaḥ nāma ekaḥ paccekanirayaḥ natthi avīcimhi
translated: which is one khārī in Kosala country. Four khārīs of that make one āḷhaka. Four āḷhakas make one doṇa. Four doṇas make one mānika. Four mānikas make one khāri. Twenty of those make a “twenty-khārī heap of sesame.”

original: eva pana abbudagaṇanāya paccanokāso “abbudo nirayo”ti vutto. Esa nayo nirabbudādīsupi.
analyzed: eva pana abbuda gaṇanāya paccanokāsaḥ abbudaḥ nirayo ti vuttaḥ esa nayaḥ nirabbuda ādīsu pi
translated: “Heap of sesame” is a cart-load of sesame. “Abbuda hell” is not a separate hell called Abbuda. But the place in Avīci where beings are counted as “abbuda” is called “Abbuda hell.” The same method applies in the case of Nirabbuda, etc.

original: Tattha vassagaṇanāpi evaṃ veditabbā yathāha “sataṃsatasahassāni koṭi hoti evaṃ sataṃsahassakoṭiyo
analyzed: tattha vassa gaṇanā api evam veditabbā yathā āha evam evam
translated: Herein, the reckoning of the years should be understood in this way. As it is said: “A hundred times a hundred thousand is a koṭi ; a hundred times a hundred thousand koṭis is

original: pakoṭi nāma. Sataṃsatasahassapakoṭiyo koṭipakoṭi nāma. Sataṃ satasahassakoṭipakoṭiyo
analyzed: pakoṭi nāma satam sata sahassa pakoṭiyaḥ koṭi pakoṭi nāma satam sata sahassa koṭi pakoṭiyaḥ
translated: a pakoli ; a hundred times a hundred thousand pakoli is a koṭipakoli ; a hundred times a hundred thousand koṭipakoli is a

original: nahutaṃ. Sataṃsatasahassanahutāni ninnahutaṃ. Sataṃsatasahassaninnahutāni eko abbudo.
analyzed: nahutam satam sata sahassa nahutāni ninna hutam satam sata sahassa ninna hutāni ekaḥ abbudaḥ
translated: nahuta ; a hundred times a hundred thousand nahutas is a ninnahuta ; a hundred times a hundred thousand ninnahutas is an abbuda ;

original: Tato vīsatiguṇo nirabbudo. Esa nayo sabbattha ayañca gaṇanā aparicitānaṃ dukkarā”ti🔽vuttaṃ taṃ na sukaraṃ saṅkhātu’nti keci pana tattha paridevanānattenapi kammakaraṇanānattenapi
analyzed: tatas vīsati guṇaḥ nirabbudaḥ esa nayaḥ sabbattha ayam ca gaṇanā a paricitānam dukkarā ti  vuttam tam na sukaram saṅkhātunti keci pana tattha parideva nānattena api kamma karaṇa nānattena api
translated: twenty times an abbuda is a nirabbuda . The same method applies in each case. But this reckoning is difficult for those who have not learnt it” .

original: imāni nāmāni laddhānīti vadanti. Aparepi vānakāraṇehīti ṭīkānetti. Yathā ca dīghavidassaāghātā🔽ca buddhantaraṃ saṭṭhiyojanamattena attabhāvena uttāno patito mahāniraye paccati
analyzed: imāni nāmāni laddhāni iti vadanti apare pi yathā ca 🔽ca buddha antaram saṭṭhi yojana mattena atta bhāvena uttānaḥ patitaḥ mahāniraye paccati
translated: Some say that the names are obtained by the different kinds of lamentations and the different kinds of actions there. Others say that the names are given because of the different reasons for the burning there. The commentary explains it thus: “And just as the Dīgha Nikāya states that the Dīgha-vicikicchā hell is so wide that a man takes a hundred years to cross it with a speed like that of lightning,🔽so too it is a hundred leagues in breadth and a hundred leagues in length. And the Mahā-niraya hell is so wide that a man takes a hundred years to cross it with a speed like that of a whirlwind.

original: yathā ca, tassa diṭṭhiabhirucitāni pañca kulasatāni tasseva sahabyataṃ uppannāni
analyzed: yathā ca tassa diṭṭhi abhirucitāni pañca kula satāni tassa iva sahabyatam uppannāni
translated: and the five hundred families who were devoted to his view were reborn in the Great Hell

original: mahāniraye paccanti. Vuttañcetaṃ bhagavatā “seyyathāpi bhikkhave naḷāgāraṃ vā tiṇāgāraṃ🔽vā aggiphuṭṭho kūṭāgārāni dahati ullittāvalittāni nivātāni phusitaggaḷāni pihita
analyzed: mahāniraye vuttam ca itam bhagavatā seyyathā api bhikkhave naḷāgāram vā tiṇa āgāram  vā aggi phuṭṭhaḥ kūṭāgārāni dahati ullitta avalittāni nivātāni phusita ggaḷāni pihita
translated: together with him. And this was said by the Blessed One: “Monks, just as a house or a hall that is roofed but not floored burns when set on fire,

original: vātapānāni evameva kho bhikkhave yānikānici bhayāni uppajjanti, sabbāni bālato uppajjanti,
analyzed: vāta pānāni evam eva kho bhikkhave yānikānici bhayāni uppajjanti sabbāni bālataḥ uppajjanti
translated: so too, monks, all the fears that arise, all the terrors that arise, all the horrors that arise, all the calamities that arise,🔽all the misfortunes that arise, all the troubles that arise, all the dangers that arise, all the troubles and dangers that arise,

original: no paṇḍitato yekeci upaddavā uppajjanti, no paṇḍitato, yekeci upasaggā…pe… no paṇḍitato.🔽Iti kho bhikkhave sappaṭibhayo bālo appaṭibhayo paṇḍito saupaddavo bālo anupaddavo
analyzed: no paṇḍitataḥ yekeci upaddavāḥ uppajjanti no paṇḍitataḥ yekeci upasaggāpe no paṇḍitataḥ  iti kho bhikkhave sa paṭibhayaḥ bālaḥ appaṭibhayaḥ paṇḍitaḥ sa upaddavaḥ bālaḥ anupaddavaḥ
translated: all these arise from the fool, not from the wise man.

original: paṇḍito, saupasaggo bālo anupasaggo paṇḍitoti. Api ca pūtimacchasadiso bālo, pūtimacchabaddhapatta
analyzed: paṇḍito sa upasaggaḥ bālaḥ an upasaggaḥ paṇḍitaḥ iti api ca pūtimaccha sadisaḥ bālaḥ pūtimaccha baddha patta
translated: Thus, monks, the fool is fearful, the wise man is fearless; the fool is with danger, the wise man is without danger; the fool is with misfortune, the wise man is without misfortune.🔽Moreover, the fool is like a rotten fish, the fool is like a bound criminal, the fool is like a diseased person, the fool is like a dead body, the fool is like a poisoned arrow, the fool is like a burning house.

original: putisadiso hoti tadupasevī. Chaḍḍanīyataṃ jigucchanīyatañca āpajjati viññūnaṃ vuttampi cetaṃ nāradajātake.
analyzed: puti sadisaḥ hoti tad upasevī chaḍḍanīya tam jigucchanīya tañca āpajjati viññūnam vuttam pi ca itam nāradajātake
translated: and he becomes like the corpse. He becomes one to be rejected and despised by the wise. This is stated in the Nārada Jātaka.

original: “Pūtimacchaṃ kusaggena, yo naro upanayhati;
analyzed: pūtimat śam kusaggena yaḥ naraḥ upanayhati
translated: “The man who draws a rotten fish out with a blade of kusa grass

original: Kusāpi pūti vāyanti, evaṃ bālūpasevanā”ti.
analyzed: pūti vāyanti evam
translated: —the kusas give off a stench. So it is with the fool’s companionship.”

original: Akattipaṇḍitocāpi sakkena devānamindena vare diyyamāne evamāha🔽“Bālaṃ na passe na suṇe, na ca bālena saṃvase;
analyzed: sakkena devānamindena vare diyyamāne evam āha  bālam na passe na suṇe na ca bālena saṃvase
translated: The wise man Akatti said this to Sakka, the king of the gods, when the latter was offering him a boon:🔽“I will neither see nor hear the fool, nor will I live with the fool.

original: Bālenā’llāpasallāpaṃ, na kare na ca rocaye.
analyzed: bālena āllāpa sallāpam na kare na ca rocaye
translated: I will neither speak nor converse with the fool, nor will I approve of him.

original: Kiṃnu te akaraṃ bālo, vada kassapa kāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: kim nu te akaram bālaḥ vada kassapa kāraṇam
translated: What has the fool done to you? Tell me, Kassapa, the reason why

original: Kena kassapa bālassa, dassanaṃ nābhikaṅkhasi.🔽Anayaṃ nayati dummedho, adhurāyaṃ niyuñjati;
analyzed: kena kassapa bālassa dassanam na abhikaṅkhasi  anayam nayati dummedhaḥ adhurā ayam niyuñjati
translated: you do not want to see the fool.🔽The unintelligent one leads to misfortune, he employs the unfit.

original: Dunnayo seyyaso hoti, sammā vutto pakuppati;
analyzed: dunnayaḥ seyyasaḥ hoti sammā vuttaḥ pakuppati
translated: The bad-natured one becomes the worst, when spoken to rightly, he becomes angry.

original: Vinayaṃ so na jānāti, sādhu tassa adassana”nti.
analyzed: vinayam saḥ na jānāti sādhu tassa adassananti
translated: He does not know the discipline. It is good not to see him.”

original: Evaṃ bāladujjanasaṃsaggavaseneva sabbāni bhayupaddavāni uppajjanti, no paṇḍitasevanavasenātisabbaso sappurisā atidullabhāva.
analyzed: evam bāla dujjana saṃsagga vasena iva sabbāni bhaya upaddavāni uppajjanti no paṇḍita sevana vasena ati sabbaso sappurisāḥ
translated: So all dangers and calamities arise only through association with bad people, not through association with the wise. Thus good people are extremely rare.

original: Idāni.
analyzed: idāni
translated: Now,🔽“Human birth is hard to get,

original: “Dullabhañca manussattaṃ, buddhuppādo ca dullabho;
analyzed: dullabham ca manussattam buddhuppādaḥ ca dullabhaḥ
translated: The arising of a Buddha is hard to find,🔽The opportunity is hard to get,

original: Dullabhā khaṇasampatti, saddhammo paramadullabho”ti.
analyzed: dullabhā khaṇa sampatti saddhammo parama dullabhaḥ ti
translated: The true Dhamma is extremely hard to find.”

original: Imissā gāthāya vaṇṇanākkamo sampatto. Tattha dullabhañca manussattanti manussabhāvopi
analyzed: imissā gāthāya vaṇṇanā kkamaḥ sampatto tattha dullabham ca manussa ttan ti manussa bhāvaḥ api
translated: The order of the commentary on this verse has been reached. Here, “Human birth is hard to get” means that the state of being a human being

original: dullabhoyeva manussassa dullabhabhāvo kāṇakacchapopamādīhi veditabbo eko kira kassako🔽gaṅgātīre tīṇi saṃvaccharāni kasitvā kiñcimattampi alabhitvā naṅgalaphālaṃ dvedhā🔽bhinditvā gaṅgāyaṃ khipi tena gaṅgānadiyā vāhena eko uddhaṃ eko heṭṭhāti evaṃ dve
analyzed: dullabhaḥ yeva manussassa dullabha bhāvaḥ kāṇa kacchapa upama ādīhi veditabbaḥ ekaḥ kira kassakaḥ  gaṅgā tīre tīṇi saṃvaccharāni kasitvā a labhitvā naṅgala phālam dvedhā  bhinditvā tena gaṅgā nadiyā vāhena ekaḥ uddham ekaḥ heṭṭhā ati evam dve
translated: is also hard to get. The difficulty of being a human being should be understood through similes such as the blind turtle and the yoke. It is said that a farmer🔽ploughed for three years on the banks of the Ganges but did not get even a little. He broke the ploughshare in two🔽and threw it into the Ganges. By the flow of the Ganges river, one went upstream and one downstream. Thus two

original: naṅgalaphālakā gaṅgāyaṃ vuyhantā cirena eko uddhaṃ eko heṭṭhāti dve ekato hutvā pākatikā
analyzed: naṅgalaphālakā gaṅgā ayam vuyhantā cirena ekaḥ uddham ekaḥ heṭṭhā ati dve ekatas hutvā pākatikā
translated: ploughshares were carried away in the Ganges. After a long time, one went upstream and one went downstream, and the two came together as before.

original: yujjanti tasmiṃ khaṇe vassasatavassasahassaccayena ekavāraṃ ummujjamāno kāṇakacchapo
analyzed: yujjanti tasmin khaṇe vassa sata vassa sahassa ccayena eka vāram ummujjamānaḥ kāṇa kacchapaḥ
translated: At that time, the blind turtle would come up once every hundred or a thousand years.

original: ummujjamānakkhaṇe tassa gīvā dvinnaṃ naṅgalaphālānamantare hoti ayaṃ kālo dullabhova
analyzed: ummujjamāna kkhaṇe tassa gīvā dvinnam naṅgala phālānam antare hoti ayam kālaḥ dullabhaḥ uva
translated: At the time of coming up, his neck would be between the two yokes. This is the time that is difficult to get.

original: evameva manussattabhāvopi dullabhoyeva tathāhi manussattabhāvaṃ alabhitvāva nirayapetaasurakāyatiracchānabhūmīsuyeva🔽saṃsaritvā sīsampi ukkhipituṃ alabhantā ekabuddhantarā dve buddhantarā tayo buddhantarā
analyzed: evam eva manussatta bhāvaḥ api dullabhaḥ yeva tathā hi manussatta bhāvam a labhitvā ava  saṃsaritvā sīsam pi ukkhipitum a labhantāḥ eka buddha antarāḥ dve buddha antarā tayaḥ buddha antarā
translated: In the same way, the human state is also difficult to get. Thus, without obtaining the human state, having transmigrated only in the hells, ghost, titan, animal realms,🔽and not being able to raise their heads, two, three, four,

original: cattāro buddhantarā ekāsaṅkhyeyyavasena niraye paccanakasattānaṃ gaṇanapathaṃ vītivattā,🔽tathā petaasurakāyatiracchānabhūmīsupi atikhuddakena attabhāvena tilabījasāsapabījassa
analyzed: cattāraḥ buddhantarāḥ eka asaṅkhyeyya vasena niraye paccanaka sattānam gaṇana patham  tathā peta asura kāya tiracchāna bhūmī supi ati khuddakena atta bhāvena tila bīja sāsapa bījassa
translated: or one asaṅkheyyas of beings in the hells have passed beyond the count of those who have cooked their food,🔽in the same way, in the ghost, titan, animal realms, with a very small body, the size of a sesame seed or mustard seed,

original: catupañcachasattaaṭṭhakalabhāgamatteneva aṅguliyā patiṭṭhitaṭṭhānamatteyeva bhūmipadese
analyzed: catu pañca cha satta aṭṭha kala bhāga mattena iva aṅguliyā bhūmi padese
translated: only the size of the tip of a finger,

original: nisinnānaṃ atikhuddakasattānaṃ gaṇanapathampi vītivattā te hi gaṇituṃ iddhimantapuggale
analyzed: nisinnānam ati khuddaka sattānam gaṇana patham pi vītivattā te hi gaṇitum iddhimanta puggale
translated: And those who are born as animals, who are so small that they are beyond counting, are even more numerous than those who are born as humans. For even those who possess psychic power cannot count them.

original: ṭhapetvā añño ko nāma sakkhissati tehi mohandhabhāvena kaṇhasukkapakkhampi ajānantā
analyzed: ṭhapetvā aññaḥ kaḥ nāma sakkhissati tehi moha ndha bhāvena kaṇha sukka pakkham pi a jānantā
translated: Who else, except for those who are overpowered by delusion, could count them? They do not even know whether the world is round or flat.

original: anekesu buddhasatesu vā buddhasahassesu vā uppajjamānesupi buddhotisaddaṃ asutvā
analyzed: anekesu buddha satesu vā buddha sahassesu vā uppajjamānesu pi buddha uti saddam a sutvā
translated: They have passed by many hundreds and thousands of Buddhas without hearing the word “Buddha.”

original: vītivattā, evaṃ manussattabhāvopi dullabhoyeva. Manussattabhāve labhamānepi buddhuppādakālo
analyzed: vītivattā evam manussatta bhāvaḥ api dullabhaḥ yeva manussatta bhāve labhamāne pi buddhuppāda kālaḥ
translated: Human birth is also difficult to obtain. Even when one obtains human birth, the time of the arising of a Buddha is extremely difficult to encounter.

original: atidullabhova. Buddhuppādakālepi sammādiṭṭhi hutvā kusalūpapattisaṅkhātā khaṇasampatti
analyzed: ati dullabhā uva buddhuppāda kāle pi sammādiṭṭhi hutvā kusala upapatti saṅkhātā khaṇa sampatti
translated: Even when a Buddha has arisen, the opportunity of being reborn in a favorable state, which is called the opportunity of wholesome kamma, is difficult to obtain.

original: dullabhāva, saddhammadesakassāpi dullabhattā, tasmimpi sati aṅgavikalabhāvena saddhammasavanassāpi
analyzed: dullabha bhāva saddhamma desakassa api dullabha ttā tasmim pi sati aṅga vikala bhāvena saddhamma savanassa api
translated: Even when that has been obtained, the opportunity of hearing the true Dhamma is difficult to obtain, because one may lack one or more of the necessary factors.

original: dullabhattāti evamādippabhedā manussattabhāvādikā khaṇasampattiyo dullabhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: dullabha ttā ti evamādi ppabhedā manus satta bhāva ādikā khaṇa sampattiyaḥ dullabhā ati veditabbā
translated: Thus, the opportunities such as human birth, etc., which are of various kinds, should be understood as difficult to obtain.

original: Dullabhā khaṇasampattīti kusalūpapattisaṅkhātā khaṇasampatti dullabhāyeva tathā hi
analyzed: dullabhā khaṇa sampatti iti kusala upapatti saṅkhātā khaṇa sampatti dullabhāya iva tathā hi
translated: The attainment of a moment is hard to find: The attainment of a moment called “the opportunity for wholesome rebirth” is indeed hard to find.🔽For in the border regions, in the formless worlds, among the nonpercipient beings, among animals, among ghosts, and among hell-beings,

original: paccantavisaya arūpaasaññasattatiracchānapetanerayikakāle vā majjhimadesepi cakkhādiaṅgavikalevā
analyzed: arūpa asañña satta tiracchāna peta nerayika kāle vā majjhima dese pi cakkha ādi aṅga vikale vā
translated: or even in the Middle Country, among those who are blind, deaf, and dumb,

original: paripuṇṇaaṅgabhāvepi micchādiṭṭhibhūtā vā kusalūpapattisaṅkhātā khaṇā na honti paccantavisaye
analyzed: paripuṇṇa aṅga bhāve pi micchādiṭṭhi bhūtāḥ vā kusala upapatti saṅkhātā khaṇāḥ na honti paccanta visaye
translated: or even among those whose faculties are complete, there are none who have the opportunity called “wholesome rebirth” because of their wrong views.

original: hi pavattā janā pāṇātipātādidasaakusalakammapatheyeva ramanti abhiramanti, caṇḍasabhāvā
analyzed: hi pavattā janā ramanti abhiramanti caṇḍa sabhāvā
translated: For the people who live in the border regions delight in and enjoy the ten unwholesome courses of action such as killing, and they are of a violent nature.

original: ca te honti, ratanattayaguṇampi na jānanti. Arūpinopi puggalā paratoghosavirahitattā
analyzed: ca te honti na jānanti arūpinaḥ pi puggalā
translated: They do not know the qualities of the Three Jewels. The formless beings, because they are devoid of hearing from others,

original: sotāpattimaggapaṭilābhopi tesaṃ natthi, buddhadassanādīnipi na labhanti. Asaññasattatiracchānapetanerayikakālesu
analyzed: sotāpatti magga paṭilābhaḥ api tesam natthi buddha dassana ādīni pi na labhanti asañña satta tiracchānapeta nerayika kālesu
translated: do not attain the path of stream-entry, and they do not obtain seeing the Buddha, etc. In the periods of the nonpercipient beings, animals, ghosts, and hell-beings,

original: pana pageva pūritapāramīnaṃ sattānaṃ pavattanampi abbohārikaṃ, sammādiṭṭhikule jāyamānāpi
analyzed: pana pagā iva pūrita pāramīnam sattānam pavattanam pi abbohārikam sammādiṭṭhi kule jāyamānā api
translated: even the appearance of beings who have fulfilled the perfections is rare, and even if one is born in a family with right views,

original: cakkhuvikalena buddhasaṅgharatanānaṃ adassanaṃ, sotavikalena dhammasavanatopi hāyati
analyzed: cakkhu vikalena buddha saṅgha ratanānam adassanam sota vikalena dhamma savanataḥ pi hāyati
translated: If the eye is defective, one does not see the Buddha and the Sangha, which are the Jewel . If the ear is defective, one does not hear the Dhamma.

original: eḷamūgādibhāvena kusalasamādānā na honti. Aṅgasampannepi micchādiṭṭhibhāvena dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇaasītianubyañjanabyāmappabhāparikkhittaṃ🔽sabbajanānaṃ nayanarasāyatanabhūtaṃ sabbaññubuddhampi disvā pasādasommena cakkhunā
analyzed: eḷa mūga ādi bhāvena kusala samādānāḥ na honti aṅga sampanne pi micchādiṭṭhi bhāvena dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa asīti anubyañjana byāma ppabhā parikkhittam  sabba janānam nayana rasa āyatana bhūtam sabbaññu buddham pi disvā pasāda sommena cakkhunā
translated: If one is born as a dumb animal, one cannot undertake the practice of the good .🔽Even if one is born with all the limbs, if one has wrong views, one does not see the Buddha, who is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, the eighty minor characteristics, the radiance that emanates from his body, and who is the object of the eye-faculty of all people, who is omniscient.

original: oloketabbampi na maññanti manopadosavaseneva yugaggāhā hutvā yamakapāṭihāriyakālādīsu
analyzed: oloketabbam pi na maññanti manaḥ upadosa vasena iva yuga ggāhāḥ hutvā yamaka pāṭihāriya kāla ādīsu
translated: Even if one sees the Buddha, one does not look at him with a mind of faith, but with a mind of hatred, as if one were looking at a yoke-fellow.

original: anekepi micchādiṭṭhino mahāniraye uppajjanti. Evaṃ kusalūpapattikhaṇasampattipi dullabhāyeva.
analyzed: aneke api micchādiṭṭhinaḥ mahāniraye uppajjanti evam kusala upapatti khaṇa sampatti pi dullabhāya iva
translated: At the time of the Twin Miracle and on other occasions, many people with wrong views were reborn in the Great Hell. Thus the opportunity to be reborn in a favorable state for the practice of the good is difficult to obtain.

original: “Dullabhañca manussattaṃ, buddhuppādo ca dullabho;
analyzed: dullabham ca manussattam buddhuppādaḥ ca dullabhaḥ
translated: “Human birth is difficult to obtain; the appearance of a Buddha is difficult to encounter;

original: Dullabhā khaṇasampatti, saddhammo paramadullabho”ti.
analyzed: dullabhā khaṇa sampatti saddhammo parama dullabhaḥ ti
translated: The opportunity to practice the good is difficult to obtain; the true Dhamma is difficult to hear.”

original: Imissā gāthāya attho vuttoyeva.
analyzed: imissā gāthāya atthaḥ vuttaḥ yā iva
translated: The meaning of this verse has been explained.

original: Iti sāgarabuddhittheraviracite sīmavisodhane
analyzed: iti sāgara buddhitthera viracite sīmavisodhane
translated: This concludes the purification of the boundary composed by the Elder Sāgarabuddhi.

original: Pakiṇṇakakaṇḍo nāma pañcamo paricchedo.🔽Evaṃ satthuparinibbānato vassasataccayena patiṭṭhite isinā kāritattā’ isinagara’nti
analyzed: pakiṇṇakakaṇḍaḥ nāma pañcamaḥ paricchedo  evam satthu parinibbānataḥ vassa sata cayena patiṭṭhite isinā kārita ttā isinagaranti
translated: The fifth chapter called “The Miscellaneous Section.”

original: laddhanāme dvattapādibhūpālānaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānabhūte sīrikhettanagare erāvatiyā nadiyā🔽pārimatīrabhūte pabbatasānumhi patiṭṭhitassa kañcanavaramahāthūpassa dāyakassa satvivamahādhammarañño
analyzed: laddha nāme dvattapa ādi bhūpālānam nivāsa ṭṭhāna bhūte sīrikhetta nagare erāvatiyā nadiyā  pārima tīra bhūte pabbata sānumhi patiṭṭhitassa kañcana vara mahā thūpassa dāyakassa satviva mahā dhamma raññaḥ
translated: Thus, after the Teacher’s final Nibbana, when a hundred years had elapsed, and the Dispensation had been established, in the city of Siriketta, which was named “Isi-nagara” because it was built by the Seer (Buddha), and which was the residence of the kings of the Dvatta race, on the slope of a mountain, on the other side of the river Eravathi, there was built a great golden Thupa.

original: kāle sāsanassa dvisahassasatādhikaekatiṃsatime vasse sāsane paṭiladdhasaddhānaṃ kulaputtānaṃ
analyzed: kāle sāsanassa dvi sahassa sata adhika ekatiṃsatime vasse sāsane paṭiladdha saddhānam kula puttānam
translated: At the time of the great king Satva, the giver of that great golden Thupa, when thirty-one thousand two hundred and fifty years had elapsed since the establishment of the Dispensation, the young men of good families, who had obtained faith in the Dispensation,

original: mahājānikaraṇavasena vimativinodaniyā vuttavacanaṃ saddayuttiatthayuttivasena sādhukaṃ
analyzed: mahā jāni karaṇa vasena vimati vinodaniyā vutta vacanam sadda yutti attha yutti vasena sādhukam
translated: without properly examining the words of the Vimativinodani, which were spoken for the purpose of making them understand the great Jataka, by means of the words of the Suttas and the reasons,

original: avicinitvā nadiyā udakukkhepaṃ akatvā upasampadā kammassa kāritattā sāsane parājayamāpanne
analyzed: a vicinitvā nadiyāḥ uda kukkhepam a katvā upasampadā kammassa kārita ttā sāsane parājayam āpanne
translated: without throwing them into the water of the river, and without having the ceremony of Upasampada performed for them, were defeated in the Dispensation.

original: kulaputte upārambhakaraṇavasena sīmavipattihārako sīmasampattippakāsako gantho pavattati.
analyzed: kula putte upārambha karaṇa vasena sīma vipatti hārako sīma sampatti pakāsakaḥ gantho pavattati
translated: In order to rebuke those young men who were defeated in the Dispensation, and in order to make known the rules of the boundaries, a treatise was composed.

original: ṭhānārahena ñatticatutthena kammena upasampadāya vīsativassena sāgarabuddhīti garūhi
analyzed: ṭhāna arahena ñatti catutthena kammena upasampadāya vīsati vassena sāgarabuddhī iti garūhi
translated: The elder Sāgarabuddhi, who had twenty years of seniority, was given the name by the preceptors at the time of his full ordination by a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements.

original: gahitanāmadheyyena bhikkhunā racito sāsanavipattihārako sīmavisodhanī nāma gantho samatto.
analyzed: gahita nāmadheyyena bhikkhunā racitaḥ sāsana vipatti hārako sīmavisodhanī nāma gantho samatto
translated: The text called “The Purification of the Monastery Zone” has been composed by the monk named Sāgarabuddhi, who has the name given to him by the preceptors, and who has removed the obstacles to the Dispensation.

original: Ettāvatā vibhattā hi, sappabhedappavattikā;🔽Sīmavisodhanīhesā, nipuṇā sādhucintitā.
analyzed: ettāvatā vibhattā hi sa ppabheda ppavattikā
translated: So far, the various kinds of monastery zones have been explained,🔽This text called “The Purification of the Monastery Zone” has been composed well and is skillful.

original: Sirikhettāti paññāte, pure aparanāmake;🔽Dakkhiṇeyyadisābhāge, uccanena katālaye.
analyzed: sirikhettā ti paññāte pure apara nāmake  dakkhiṇeyya disā bhāge uccanena kata ālaye
translated: In the city called Sirikhettā, in the southern direction,🔽in the upper region, it was composed

original: Vasanto bhikkhu nāmena, sāgarabuddhīti vissuto;
analyzed: vasantaḥ bhikkhu nāmena sāgarabuddhī iti vissutaḥ
translated: by the monk named Sāgarabuddhi, who is well-known,

original: Puṇṇe vīsativassamhi, ganthoyaṃ sādhucintito.
analyzed: puṇṇe vīsati vassamhi ganthaḥ yam sādhu cintito
translated: when he was twenty years old. This text has been composed well.

original: Mayāyaṃ racito gantho, niṭṭhappatto anākulo;
analyzed: mayā ayam racitaḥ ganthaḥ niṭṭhappattaḥ an ākulaḥ
translated: This text, which has been composed by me, has been completed without difficulty;

original: Evaṃ pāṇinaṃ sabbe, sīghaṃ sijjhantu saṅkappā.
analyzed: evam pāṇinam sabbe sīgham sijjhantu saṅkappā
translated: May all living beings quickly accomplish their intentions.

original: Yāva buddhotināmampi lokajeṭṭhassa tādino;
analyzed: yāva loka jeṭṭhassa tādinaḥ
translated: For as long as the name “Buddha” exists for that One of Ten Powers, the Chief of the World,

original: Tāva tiṭṭhatu yaṃ gantho, sāsane hārayaṃ tamaṃ.
analyzed: tāva tiṭṭhatu yam sāsane hārayam tamam
translated: for that long may this text remain, removing the darkness from the Dispensation.

original: Uddhaṃ yāva bhavaggā ca, adho yāva avīcito;
analyzed: uddham yāva bhavaggā ca adhas yāva avīcitaḥ
translated: From above to the peak of existence, and from below to Avīci,

original: Samantā cakkavāḷesu, ye sattā pathavīcarā.
analyzed: samantā cakkavāḷesu ye sattā pathavī carā
translated: May all the beings who live on the earth in the world systems in the ten directions

original: Tepi sabbe mayā hontu, samasamavipākino;🔽Ciraṃ jīvatu no rājā, sāsanassa ujjotako.
analyzed: te pi sabbe mayā hontu sama sama vipākinaḥ  ciram jīvatu naḥ rājā sāsanassa ujjotakaḥ
translated: become equal to me in the ripening of their karma.🔽May our king live long, the light of the Dispensation.

original: Dibbanto rājadhammena, arogo saha ñātibhi;
analyzed: dibbantaḥ rāja dhammena arogaḥ saha ñātibhi
translated: May he be happy with his relatives, through the king’s righteous Dhamma.

original: Anena puññakammena, bhaveyyaṃ jātijātiyaṃ.
analyzed: anena puñña kammena bhaveyyam jāti jātiyam
translated: By this meritorious deed, may I be in every birth.

original: Sāsanaṃ jotayantova, sakyaputtassa sāsane;
analyzed: sāsanam jotayantaḥ iva sakya puttassa sāsane
translated: Shining the Dispensation of the Son of the Sakyans,

original: Yadā nassati saddhammo, andhībhūto mahītale;
analyzed: yadā nassati saddhammaḥ andhībhūtaḥ mahī tale
translated: when the true Dhamma has disappeared, and the earth is blind,

original: Devaloke tadā hessaṃ, tusite ṭhānamuttameti.
analyzed: deva loke tadā hessam tusite ṭhānam uttamā iti
translated: then I will be in the deva world, in the supreme place in the Tusita heaven.

original: Sīmavisodhanī niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sīmavisodhanī niṭṭhitā
translated: The Purification of the Monastic Boundary is finished.
